examples.vernacular: Se poðe pom accatar teint ogtoç solt a cascun.
examples.english: You could buy apples for eighteen pence each.

et: literally "to each one", in idiomatic use attested from the twelfth century. The phrase's use extended beyond financial and census-taking contexts through the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries.

examples.vernacular: Y melody dy sanfoin me hamtau a plaç entarn.
examples.english: The bagpipe tune grew on me eventually.

et: phrase meaning "at (a) position inside", used idiomatically from as early as the fourteenth century. The noun plaç "position" is an Old Borlish borrowing via Old French place "location" from Latin platea "courtyard". The adverb entarn "inside", which corresponds to the preposition ne "in", descends directly from Latin adjective internus "internal, interior".

examples.vernacular: J'aye spien ig l'oç madarc no fos a squid.
examples.english: I hoped that that cop wasn't on the take.

examples.vernacular: Masctig por cors a tug teyen boncop.
examples.english: Tickets for friendly games were cheap.

ge: for the love of the game
et: Middle Borlish idiom, literally "to passion". As a conjunction (attested from the sixteenth century) the construction requires someone's explicit agency in a way which the near-synonyms por and a fin do not.
Middle Borlish, noun derivation from abattr "fight, make war".

examples.vernacular: Ubicqtað ablegau mell'yam deur Ommad.
examples.english: Ubiquity drove my uncle from Ommad.

examples.vernacular: L'oc enonç es abrangent a my nom ou?
examples.english: Does this list have my name on it?

et: Middle Borlish, via Latin from Portingale abranger

examples.vernacular: Y pascman abrange zaquesc e desc assovent y dou.
examples.english: The eatery had both snacks and full meals.

et: via Scholastic Latin abrangeō "I include" from Portingale abranger "include", itself of obscure origin. Possibly related to Old French rengier "to line up, form rows", from Frankish (either hring "ring" or ranc "upright"); otherwise perhaps an unconventional descendant of Latin vergō "I bend, am situated".
via Old Borlish from Latin abbreviō

examples.vernacular: M'orruðe l'ouger er nos abrevant auvorn.
examples.english: I thought the host gave us lots to drink.

et: from Old Borlish abrevar "to water", likely borrowed from Old French synonymous abrever in Old French. This is a metathetic variant of abevrer, which descends from Vulgar Latin abbiberō "I water" (which the Old Borlish may alternatively reflect directly), a derivative of Classical bibō "I drink". The word's association with alcohol and social gatherings shows influence from slang term abrevað "tipsy, squiffy, somewhat drunk", literally "watered".

examples.vernacular: Y justiçour absoloirn my grandmaðr poll'ig delit a blasmant.
examples.english: [i ˌʒɪstɪˈʣʊː‿ˌʀabzʊˈlɔjɐŋ mi gʀɐmˈmaðɐ pʊˌlaj dɪˈlɪt a blɐˈzmant]

et: Old Boral absovre, absolvre “to absolve”, a semi-learned descendant/borrowing from Latin absolvō “I loosen, untie”.
Old Borlish, deverbal noun from accatar
Old Borlish < Latin, regular descendant of Latin accedo "I advance, join"

examples.vernacular: Mell'acquetta er çarvinot ramenant starc.
examples.english: My liqueur tasted strongly of raspberries.

et: Middle Borlish < Latin; reborrowing from Latin acquiēscō "I rest".

examples.vernacular: The bassoons played in the first big tutti section.
examples.english: The bassoons played in the first big tutti section.

et: descendant of Old Borlish aðaun, extended variant of synonymous aun "together, at the same time". This comes either from a Late Latin phrase ad ūnum "at one" or from a deverbal of adūnō "I unite". Current in the language until the early modern period, it has fossilised in legal and musical uses; the interjection appears to have been reborrowed in the twentieth century from rural dialects that retained the term.

examples.vernacular: Y duc nos dau l'acconnosc de sell'aðm.
examples.english: The duke introduced us to his mistress.

et: from Old Borlish aðm "concubine, paramour; (poss.) treasure" (the object sense is contemporaneously unattested, but later use suggests a retention), alteration of presumed *maðm via rebracketing with Old Borlish m(e) "my". It was borrowed from Old English māþm "precious object, jewel". Until the advent of the last sense in the twentieth century, the word had usually been restricted to possessive constructions.

examples.vernacular: Cay un adolescenç a them d'alumn ne Tecamau.
examples.english: It's a coming-of-age tale about Tecamaw schoolkids.

et: Middle Borlish, a borrowing from Scholastic Latin adolēscentia "maturation, growing up", nominal derivative of Classical verb adolēscō "I grow up, become an adult". In the meaning of a type of tradition, the word is a clipping of former phrase rit d'adolescenç "coming-of-age rite". The term was first used for the literary genre in the early 20C to describe the works of London author Dorotha Quistack.

examples.vernacular: Nos som travodant posc je semman ados!
examples.english: We've been in negotations since last week!

examples.vernacular: L'ec imascry voun l'Issambr a Lappier æternar.
examples.english: These statues will commemorate the Lappier Massacre.

et: early modern borrowing from Latin aeternō "I perpetuate, make renowned", a verbal derivative of aeternus "eternal, immortal" (compare much earlier adjective æternal "endless, eternal"). Made popular in the last senses after the Millstone War in the early twentieth century by its use in a Faðig war poem.

examples.vernacular: Jo no poð lou affaçar pre vienn y flottisc.
examples.english: I can't confront them until reinforcements arrive.

et: Middle Borlish, from faç "face" < Late Latin facia

examples.vernacular: Un min d'affr sclarisceu sur y justicer.
examples.english: Fear flashed across the judge's face.

et: borrowed into Middle Borlish from French affre "horror, terror". This descends via Old Vascon affre from a Gothic root reflecting Classical German æbras "bitter, violent". The term has been used also for the emotion's cause since the eighteenth century.
adjective from affr "fright", or directly from French.

ge: in the pit of one's stomach

et: Middle Borlish, legal Latin āfuit "he/she was not there"

examples.vernacular: L'Agathin a Famigl soloy ombisc je Viendr.
examples.english: The Minister for Family resigned on Friday.

et: from Middle Borlish, a borrowing from Scholastic Latin agathīnus "minister". This was altered by analogy to Greek ᾰ̓γᾰθός • agathós "good, noble, useful" from contemporary words like Italian agazzino and Barcelon agutzir "bailiff, sheriff". These originate in Arabic الوزير • al-wazīr "the minister", from which the chess sense also derives.
adjective from agathin, or directly from Latin agathīnārius.

examples.vernacular: L'agent dy Majon Roug souseyeu l'ig scard commoðer.
examples.english: The Red House agent dealt with that resistance group.

ge: snatch victory from the jaws of defeat
et: Middle Borlish idiom first attested in Kigman's poetry, literally "to rescue the lamb from the wolf".
Old Borlish < Old French < Vulgar Latin

examples.vernacular: Orruð ig alcun hom parceveus y catastroph ahoy.
examples.english: No-one seemed to notice the imminent disaster.

et: originally in the first sense, used as an exclamation to attract attention or hail another ship. The extended uses are seen from the nineteenth century, initially restricted to colloquial or humorous contexts.

derived from ajoutar "gratify, help out, please" with the somewhat-pejorative or diminishing suffix -aç (from Latin -āceus "shaped like"). This root verb descends via Old Borlish aioftar from post-Classical Latin adiuvitō "I help out, assist, am useful", from earlier synonymous adiuvō with a frequentative derivation.

examples.vernacular: Y fabr nou scenað t'ajoutaç ou?
examples.english: Do you think the new play's fun?

et: eighteenth-century verbal derivation from ajoutaç "gratification, enjoyment, satisfaction"
borrowed in the Old Borlish period from Old English ġelendan "approach, arrive".

examples.vernacular: Nos coum alant a haun posc tan semman.
examples.english: We made landfall after so many weeks.

et: Old Borlish, a deverbal from alandar "arrive, turn up, dock".

collocation originating in Kigman's fifteenth-century poetry, literally meaning "docking at a haven". The phrase was used by Kigman already to mean a return to a metaphorical homeland; it had become synonymous with safe places more generally by the end of the following century.

examples.vernacular: Quippe l'oc havara un hom alcant aposc.
examples.english: Surely someone will notice eventually.

et: idiom found in this form since the eighteenth century, literally "once later". The adverb alcant "once" is an analogical form derived from cant "when" with the word element alc- < Latin aliquī "some". The adverb aposc "later" is from the preposition posc "after", from Latin post quid "after what". As an interjection it is only securely attested in the twentieth century.

examples.vernacular: Posc cay prinvir porreu nos alcheðr.
examples.english: Next spring we can start over.

et: Middle Borlish extension of now-obsolete eðr "again, twice, repeatedly" after various function words like alcant "once", alcun "none" and alcot "how much". The element alc- descends from Latin determiner aliquī "some, any", while the adverb eðr is either a direct reflection of Latin iterum "again, a second time" or a deverbal of eðrar "to repeat", from related Latin iterō "I repeat, I do again".
Middle Borlish < Medieval Latin < Arabic < Ancient Greek
Middle Borlish < Medieval Latin < Arabic < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Fort alcot i quotta y jacquot me souprene.
examples.english: I was surprised how well the coat suited him.

et: in medical texts from as early as the twelfth century; translated from Arabic, a borrowing from الْجَبْر • al-jabr "restoration, compulsion".

examples.vernacular: Lou stove l'os a cois algebrar toð pront.
examples.english: They had to set the thighbone at once.

et: Middle Borlish, borrowed from Scholastic Latin algebrō "I set (a bone)" along with noun algebr < algebra "bone-setting; restitution". Financial use is attested from the seventeenth century; political from the late nineteenth (in the run-up to the Millstone War).
Noun from alleyar, or directly from French alliance
Old Borlish < Old French alier < Latin alligō

examples.vernacular: Ma comoscon l'oc alligar con melodram?
examples.english: But how does this relate to musicals?

et: Middle Borlish, borrowed from Latin alligō "I bind to, tie, fetter". Thus, this word is a doublet of inherited alleyar "ally, collaborate, partner". Formerly used for physical ties and links (as related ligar "bind, bandage" still is), but now restricted to abstract usage.

examples.vernacular: Lor rou y diac ouð y ley vel y taus terren allocquar.
examples.english: The journo then asks if the law will affect land tax.

et: Middle Borlish, borrowed (with regularised conjugation modelled after collocquar "converse") from Latin alloquor "I address, greet", derived from the root loquor "I speak". The term is seen in metaphorical use from the eighteenth century, and in romantic contexts from around the same time.

examples.vernacular: I port jamay allors de fustagn ou?
examples.english: Does he wear anything but jeans?

et: Old Borlish < Old French < Vascon < Arabic
via Mostara or other Spanish amazgato "nursery, flowerbed, place for growing plants", from Andalus Arabic اَلْمَسْقَى‎ <al-másqa> "seedbed".

examples.vernacular: Cay l'ig muncef un amaçgat ðescant vars huivaç.
examples.english: That district is a hotspot of mob activity.

et: collocation first attested in the late nineteenth century, literally a "nourishing nursery". The noun amaçgat "nursery, childcare" is borrowed via Mostara amazgato "flowerbed; nursery" from Morrove Arabic اَلْمَسْقَى‎ <al-másqa> "seedbed". The adjective is the present participle of ðescar "nourish, feed, fuel", which descends directly from Latin adēscō "I feed, fatten up".
Old Borlish < Old Aquitain < Latin < Gothic
"Old Borlish < Medieval Latin, Old English, Old Saxon"
deverbal from verb annexar "to supplement, append, boost, refine", which comes via Scholastic Latin annexō from Classical annexus "attachment".

examples.vernacular: L'oc sorty enter sta tor annex denover.
examples.english: This whole party was sort of last-minute.

et: idiom attested from the nineteenth century, literally "final-stage addition".

examples.vernacular: Y reloðeç ag tarner sta aplattiscent.
examples.english: The host's gentility was irritating.

examples.vernacular: Y cat venoirn aç seðel aposc.
examples.english: The cats came forth in droves.

et: adverbial derivation from prepostion posc "after, since" < Late  Latin posque < post quem "after which". This word was originally  restricted to taking complements "after I get back" rather than nominal arguments "after the wedding", for which one would use now-obsolete pos < Latin post "after, behind"; the former had displaced the latter by  the fifteenth century.
from Medieval Latin apparāculum "tools, equipment", a derivation of apparō "I prepare, equip".

examples.vernacular: Nossell'appragl phasm n'a ceu alcun grastum.
examples.english: Our television set is almost completely flat.

et: twentieth-century collocation, from appragl "device, machine, tool" and phasm "(the technology of) television, image transmission".
Scholastic Latin argentifico "I turn to silver"

examples.vernacular: My dois nou yent es arreloðeçað auvorn.
examples.english: My new phone has loads of new features.

et: participle of arreloðeçar "to dress finely, to trick out"

verbal derivation from reloðeç "splendour; finery". This comes from reloð "fancy, refined", a descendant (with pleonastic re- seen already in the Vulgar period) from Latin lautus "washed; luxurious, splendid, fashionable".

examples.vernacular: Gevou bro, tu's l'oc duel renent un pog arrhenosarc.
examples.english: Heads up dude, you're making this duel a bit homoerotic.

et: ineteenth century coinage from Ancient Greek, originally used in artistic criticism to discuss current trends in painting and sculpture. The term derives from ἄρρην (árrhēn), Attic variant of ᾰ̓́ρσην (ársēn) "male, masculine", as well as σάρξ (sárx) "flesh, lust". Both gendered forms appear to have been coined at roughly the same time.
Old Borlish < Old French < Classical German

from Arabic الرمح <ar-rumh> "the spear, the shaft". The word is spelt arrhumb in the English languages and some others, by mistaken analogy to rhumb (as in rhumb line, line which crosses successive meridians at a constant angle).
directly from Latin arbitrium "judgement, decision; discretion". In the sense of unpredictability the word is attested from the late eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Jo fey paupieðr an spaiðoir arveiðrous con hast.
examples.english: I hurriedly opened a random drawer.

et: seventeenth century, adjectival derivative from arveiðr "impulse, whim, caprice".
past participle of asculdar "to indebt, obligate".
directly from synonymous asinus in Latin.
Old Borlish < Old French < Medieval Latin < Arabic
Middle Borlish < Medieval Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Stou dou trevold assignar all'ec alumn.
examples.english: You must set this class two novels.

et: Middle Borlish, borrowed from Latin assignō "I assign, distribute". The legal sense appears to be a clipping of legal Latin brevem assignō "I give out a writ". In the last sense the word is a backformation from earlier assignaçon "tryst", borrowed in the early modern period from French.

examples.vernacular: Nos s'asseyau tras port e conteyau assuvar.
examples.english: We sat outside and counted shooting stars.

et: from Scholastic Latin assūvāris "meteor; meteoric", and specifically from the thirteenth-century work Dē Assūvāribus "On Meteoric (Phenomena)". This is a borrowing from Arabic شُهُب • shuhub "shooting stars", plural of شِهَاب • shihāb "blaze, brand; shooting star". In the last senses it reflects a long history of comets and similar celestial appearances being used to foretell the future.

examples.vernacular: J'er astr mirant all'hour dou je ados.
examples.english: I was stargazing until two last night.

et: phrase meaning "to look at stars", employing the poetic term astr "celestial body, star", borrowed from synonymous astrum in Latin. This sense of mirar "be amazed by, marvel at" to mean "look at" is also somewhat formal or poetic. In metaphorical use the phrase is seen as early as the fifteenth century.

ge: in the form of an atom
from one side to the other

et: verb from aubon "dawn, sunrise", originally from Latin albus "white".
Middle Borlish < Old French < Medieval Latin < Arabic
Middle Borlish verbal derivation of augrim
Old Borlish < Old English; originally borrowed from Borland English ahtan "to send, give", presumably a reworking of āgan "to (cause to) own" according to aht-, the past tense root.

examples.vernacular: L'er asseyent eð un aujon survolant.
examples.english: He was sat leafing through a magazine.

et: originally in the last sense, a Middle Borlish adaptation of Medieval Latin ausiō "mobilisation, deployment, the readying of troops for battle". This is a noun from audeō "I dare, venture, risk"; the meaning passed via "(risky) manoeuvre, the act of putting (oneself or troops) in harm's way". Use outside of a military context is attested from the seventeenth century; in the (now most common) first sense it is attested from the early nineteenth.

examples.vernacular: Jo vis y fabr all'Auspeç Impareïbr noncupað.
examples.english: I saw the self-styled Peerless Seer's stage show.

et: Middle Borlish < Latin; an early Middle Borlish reborrowing from Latin auspex "augur, priest".

examples.vernacular: Y malvaç cof auteç ag vanc nell'askouð!
examples.english: The bad guy got hold of the vault's treasure!

et: from Old Borlish afteç "possession, ownership", used predominated in a legal context and reflecting a parallel formation to synonymous habititia in Medieval Latin: it is a nominal derivation from aft (modern aut), past participle of aeir "to have" (modern aïr). In the latter two senses (it is often difficult to distinguish them in examples) the word is attested from the twelfth century.

examples.vernacular: Jo pos parolar coll'autour ou?
examples.english: May I speak to the owner?

et: conflation of two unrelated words. Partly from aut "had, owned, possessed" and auteç "ownership, possession, control" with an agentive suffix, and partly a borrowing via Old French from Latin auctor "vendor; author".
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Old French

examples.vernacular: L'er mell'yam sleghant avant my rau!
examples.english: He was shamelessly slandering my uncle!

et: Etymology: from early Middle Borlish au sy rau [əu si rəu] "brazenly, in a way that provokes ire", literally "in front of the disdain (of someone)". The preposition au "in front of", from Latin apud "by, near, unto", had obsolesced and been supplanted by synonymous avant (from ab ante "from before") by the nineteenth century. Synchronically the idiom is usually misinterpreted as containing the unrelated word rau "uncooked vegetables, salad" (from Kentish raw "raw"), as though avant my rau meant "in front of my salad".

examples.vernacular: Banc redirigent machinal receveurn magn averjon.
examples.english: Automated redirection banks were met with significant opposition.

et: from Middle Borlish aversion "opposition, resistance", seemingly the confluence of the two Latin roots āvertō "I turn away, repulse" and non-classical advertō "I oppose, fight against" (a backformation from adversārius "opponent"). In the last sense used especially for Collusion-supported movements through the twentieth century in regions dominated by Ubiquitous administration.

examples.vernacular: Sceye all'oç asc poy avoccaçon a phasm.
examples.english: There wasn't much TV entertainment then.

et: nominal derivation from avoccar "divert, amuse, entertain" or directly from Latin āvocātiō "distraction". The meaning was influenced by contrast to its traditional counterpart voccaçon "career, occupation".
from Latin āvocō "I call away, distract, dissuade". Possibly a backformation from avoccaçon "entertainment".

examples.vernacular: Nos depostau l'eç taflot an bacaget.
examples.english: We keep these board games in a closet.

et: Middle Borlish, from contemporary French metathetic variants bacaget, cabbagès "cupboard; lean-to, cabin, hut". The first part of this word is related to cabbas "basket; storeroom" Latin capāx "spacious", while the second may reflect ajouster "to add" (in dialect form agestir) or jeter "to throw".

examples.vernacular: L'aye min baðaspat de my vestið vabian closnautr.
examples.english: He looked nonplussed at my bedraggled appearance.

et: first mentioned in the eighteenth century as a new piece of fashionable slang, probably of dialectal origin. Thought to be a compound; the first part is a form of baðar, local variant of sbayar "gawp, goggle" descending from Medieval Latin (ex)batō, exbadō "I gape, yawn". The second part spat is presumably a variant of spait, past participle of spagir "frightened, scared" and descending from Vulgar Latin expaveō "I am terrified of".
Old Borlish < Insular Latin < Borland Celtic

examples.vernacular: J'oyeu ne Horð il pascn for bakilau.
examples.english: I heard that in Horth they only eat cod.

et: contested. Extant from 9C as cabeilau, bacalau (among other variants), from Middle Dutch (Mi-Willem), cf. French cabillaud “cod”. Entered Middle Dutch either from some derivation of baculum “stick, rod”, or else from Basque kabailao “cod”. Formerly assumed to be a direct loan from Vask into Boral – see also other naval/fishing terminology like hagr “mast" – but this is now considered phonetically untenable.
from a variety of Germanic sources and potentially via Medieval Latin—cf. Old English beall, Old Norse bòllr, Frankish bal "ball".
Old Borlish < Old French < Medieval Latin

examples.vernacular: Nos stoun balis sobottal luicessem.
examples.english: We need stronger radio transmitters.

et: a borrowing via Middle French balise "beacon; buoy" from contemporary Portingale baliza "buoy". This appears to be from an unattested Late Latin pālītia, related to pālus "stake, post". In the sense "lighthouse" it is clipped from the phrase tour balis "beacon tower"; in the last sense it is attested from the early twentieth century.

examples.vernacular: Banc redirigent machinal receveurn magn aversion.
examples.english: Automated redirection banks were met with significant opposition.

et: Old Borlish < Old English < Classical German

examples.vernacular: Banc redirigent machinal receveurn magn aversion.
examples.english: Automated redirection banks were met with significant opposition.

et: Old French < Old Dutch < Classical German
Medieval Latin banleuca, influenced by band "band"

partial calque of Old English bānfȳr “bonfire”, literally “bone fire”, meaning a fire in which to dispose of rubbish (such as bones). Generalisation to any temporary fire built outdoors attested from 15C.

examples.vernacular: Nos voum partir je Maucr, donc toð je Mart stoura banfoy quïr.
examples.english: We'll leave on Wednesday, so we need all Tuesday to pack.

et: Literally “to extinguish (the) campfire”, refers by metonymy to the entire disassembly of a campsite, or more generally to any preparation made for a journey.
Old Borlish < Old Norse < Classical German
Middle Borlish < Scholastic Latin < Italian < Arabic

examples.vernacular: Y visn brasser ag port me barricheyau y man.
examples.english: The brass doorknob gave me an electric shock.

et: nineteenth century, verbal derivative with the causative suffix -eyar < Latin -idiō, -izō "I make _" from adjective barric "electric" (formerly also a noun, now displaced by astraphor "electricity", from Greek). In metaphorical or emotional use the word is attested almost at once.

examples.vernacular: I sta quemant com babe ne barrougl.
examples.english: He was as cosy as a baby in a pram.

et: via Old Borlish beroȝl "handcart, trolley" from synonymous birocla in Vulgar Latin. This reflects birotula, a diminutive from late Latin birota "two-wheeled cart" which comes from bi- "double" and rota "wheel". Compare Tuscan baroccio and Old French beroue, brouette, both meaning "cart". The term was likely influenced by the unrelated Old English bearwe "basket, handcart". In more general use the term is comparatively recent, only seen from the late ninteenth century.
Middle Borlish < Middle Dutch < Classical German

examples.vernacular: Y soldart eð y barvier vencoirn y dragon e soulor allagr vescoirn il.
examples.english: The soldier and the shepherdess killed the dragon and lived happily ever after.

et: many forms are attested in Old Boral (approximately 7C-11C); barviar and varvȝair, for example. All are from Vulgar Latin vervecārius, from Latin vervēx “wether, castrated ram”

examples.vernacular: L'oc alleyanç intermandra bastegl contr y Pologn.
examples.english: This alliance will be a bulwark against Poland.

et: a borrowing from Middle French bastille "fortress", itself from early Docian [Occitan] bastida "fortress, edifice" adapted to the -ille suffix < Latin īle "enclosure". This comes from Late Latin bastiō "I build; I sew", a borrowing from Frankish. In metaphorical usage the word is in evidence from the eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Jo me cou battuð d'un hom raðant ag los.
examples.english: I got hit by someone cycling on the pavement.

examples.vernacular: Indigneð mey noc dell'oc baugl van.
examples.english: Don't hold this bad set-up against me.

et: from Old Borlish bauȝl (probably /bawʎ/) "tent, campsite", cognate with Cambrick pabell "tent" in coming via a Kelt form (the Borland reflex exhibiting characteristic initial voicing) from Latin pāpiliō "butterfly, (later) tent". In the latter sense the word is seen from the sixteenth century, originally with reference to a room's hasty arrangement of appliances/furniture or similar processes that resemble the ad-hoc set-up of a campsite.
noun from baugl "camp" or the obsolete verb bauglar "to camp"
directly from Latin beccus "beak, bill", a borrowing from Gaulish.

examples.vernacular: Nos bechettaum jug posc l'elocquy.
examples.english: We dug in straight after the speech.

et: nineteenth century verbal derivative of the noun bec "beak, snout, muzzle; (colloquial, of people) mouth". In metaphorical usage the word is seen from the early twentieth century.
Etym: idiom from the eighteenth century, literally "beautiful demeanour at danger".
Old Borlish, from Latin benedīcō "I commend, praise; I bless"

examples.vernacular: Sy benjamin a cedr sta imminuð sad.
examples.english: He'd overdone the cedarwood perfume.

et: from the late fifteenth century and originally in the first sense, borrowed from Vascon benjamin "benzoin, frankincense". This is a folk-etymological corruption of earlier benjavin, lo benjavi, itself a reanalysis of Arabic لُبَان جَاوِيّ‎ (lubān jāwiyy), literally "Javanese frankincense". As a general term for perfumes it is seen since the eighteenth century; in chemistry the jargon use is borrowed from the Cambrick practice in the early twentieth century.

examples.vernacular: Y souspect patronneyau l'oc benoyour je Mart.
examples.english: The suspect visited this medium on Tuesday.

et: agentive derivation from now-obsolete benoïr "to receive blessings; (specifically) to receive communications from the deceased". This verb was formed in the early Middle Borlish period by analogy with bendigr "to bless" (itself obsolete by parallel beneïr, both from Latin benedīcō "I commend, praise; I bless") from the root oïr "to hear" < Latin audiō "I hear". The word enjoyed some use in lay Christian practice before dropping out of use in the Revitalist period of the early sixteenth century; it was revived in reference to non-Christian roles as well as to rites of the Novomundine "Prodigal Faiths" during the late eighteenth century.
Old Borlish < Old French < Classical German
a regular adjectival derivation from betraf "beet, beetroot", which itself is a combination of earlier bet < beta "beet", raf < rapum "turnip".

examples.vernacular: Pieç beuscr son tijon svingant sur y lançbal.
examples.english: Some louts are up in arms about the lineball.

et: somehwat muddled. The -scr ending likely descends from Latin diminutive suffix -usculus, here used in either a belittling or euphemistic sense. The rest is thought to reflect Latin bēlua "wild animal, beast", although the development of the /l/ is irregular. In ironic usage it is attested from the early twentieth century; as a generic intensifier somewhat later. The derived comparative beuscerrem "to an even greater extent" is seen only very occasionally as a one-off neologism.
apparently an Old Borlish backformation from short-lived abiolar "to form a cavity, ?to awl", via Medieval Latin albiolō from Classical alveolus "small hollow; trough, basin".

examples.vernacular: Veleð l'oc smaraut beyollir ne my çondr.
examples.english: Please set this emerald into my pendant.

et: Middle Borlish, derivation via the change-of-state suffix -ir, -isc < Latin -ēscō "I become _" from noun beyol "socket, cavity; dimple, divot". The word has been used for forming electrical connections since the late nineteenth century.
Old Borlish < Old French < Old Aquitain < Vulgar Latin
Middle Borlish < Portingale < Barcelon < Arabic < Syriac < Greek < Latin

examples.vernacular: Me stove pieç parol bisan dar a my fraðr.
examples.english: I had to tell my brother some hard truths.

et: originally in the first sense, a Middle Borlish derivation from now-obsolete bis "cold air; specifically, a north wind". This is borrowed via French bise "north wind", of uncertain origin. Possible connections include Tuscan bigio "grey, cloudy" or Classical German *bibō "I shiver".
Old Borlish < Medieval Latin < Old Dutch
borrowing from Saxon blad "leaf, page; playing card"
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Classical German

examples.vernacular: Racont mey dy domn bland voscon encontrað.
examples.english: Tell me about the interesting woman you met.

et: Middle Borlish, a borrowing from Latin blandus "pleasant, agreeable; fawning, flattering". In the first senses the word originally had a somewhat negative or insincere connotation; by the eighteenth century the word is mostly seen in uncomplicatedly positive use.
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Ancient Greek
Old Borlish < Old French < Old Dutch

examples.vernacular: Bouð y viker ða i no's ac yent pre haçol.
examples.english: Text the deputy if he's not here by noon.

et: from Old Borlish, a verbal derivative of bouð (also boðour) "messenger, courier" (modern "signal, message"), which is borrowed from Old English boda "messenger".
borrowed from Old Norse bogi "bow". The word displaces native arc < Latin arcus, relegated in the modern language to the senses "arch (architecture), curve, part of a circle".
a regular agentive derivation of bog

examples.vernacular: My granmaðr noloy se bojar cas scadom pascr.
examples.english: My gran wouldn't reconsider eating tomatoes.

et: from Old Borlish bojar "move, shift", originally in both intransitive (it moved) and transitive (I moved it) use but by the Middle Borlish period only in the latter. This is a borrowing from synonymous Old French bougier, from Vulgar Latin bullicō "I boil, bubble up", a frequentative from bulliō (whence Borlish boglir "to boil").

examples.vernacular: Infeliç, my sour poð noc boleð pascr, dec i lou support noc.
examples.english: Unfortunately, my sister cannot eat mushrooms as she is intolerant.

et: Latin bōlētus “mushroom”. Can refer by extension to other objects with a similar shape.

examples.vernacular: Cayen orðenjanç theoretic plusour descovart par bonaventur.
examples.english: Many scientific inventions were discovered by chance.

et: a borrowing via a French language (in which the semantic shift occurred) from Romaine bunaventura "good fortune, luckiness".
Middle Borlish < Middle Dutch < Classical German
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Old French < Classical German
cognate with Old French burjon "bud, sprout". This is either from Frankish burio "offshoot, descendant", or from Latin burriō "down, fluff" (or both)

examples.vernacular: Skig d'aular ag quarf ða cay ploy borjonnant.
examples.english: Don't walk to the station if it looks like rain.

et: Middle Borlish verb from borjon "bud; beginning, first sign". Proscribed in the latter senses by sticklers, although attestations are widespread from the 19th century.
Late Old Boral borse “purse” (11C), from Late Latin bursa “oxhide, purse” via Old French. Originally from Greek βύρσα “hide, wine-skin”.

examples.vernacular: Il voun calscon stovent fair por l'oc bors scholer cavir.
examples.english: They will do whatever it takes to get this grant.

et: first attested 15C in reference to the New School in Vithor (Viðor).
Middle Borlish < Old French < Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Jo montau ag tabr e clignau my bos yert a haut.
examples.english: I got up on the table and fired my gun into the air.

et: clipping of armbos, arm bos "boss weapon", folk-etymological borrowing (after arm "weapon") from Dutch armbósz "gun, (originally) crossbow". This is itself adapated from earlier forms such as arbalst under the influence of arm "arm (limb)", and these forms reflect Medieval Latin arbalista "crossbow".

examples.vernacular: Dou madarc interromoirn un bosaç ny routel.
examples.english: Two cops interrupted a shoutout in the alley.

et: 20C, pejorative or augmentative derivation from bos "gun"; attested almost immediately in the metaphorical senses.
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Classical German

examples.vernacular: Y desc bot teyen boncoppessem sur ig l'aus hougr.
examples.english: The set menu was cheaper than she'd feared.

et: Middle Borlish, borrowed from contemporary Dutch bote "bundle of flax; tuft". This is likely a derivation from the verb bóten "beat", a descendant of Classical German bautō "I beat, knock, push". In attributive use the word is seen from the late nineteenth century, originally in hotels as a calque from Welsh scub seggo "set menu, (lit.) bundle of dishes".
from Old Borlish boucle "loop, bracelet" (modern boucr), via Old French from Latin buccula "chinstrap".

examples.vernacular: Un bougr insuet vien de laurar ag haprman.
examples.english: A new guy's just started at the grocer's.

et: only recently (early twentieth century) ameliorated from an insult, via Middle Borlish bougr "villain, criminal, enemy; pagan, apostate, non-believer" from Old Borlish bougre "heretic, evildoer". This reflects Medieval Latin Bulgarus "from Bulgaria", from Old Slavonic, and was probably introduced via contemporary French legal codes.

examples.vernacular: I me quistau por m'addocir ig bount son il ag quarf.
examples.english: She phoned me to say they're en route to the station.

et: from Old Borlish boun "ready, willing", altered to bount by analogy with the present participle ending -nt by the early modern period. This is a borrowing from Old Norse búinn "adapted, fit", the past participle of búa "reside, prepare, decorate". In archaic or poetic use the word may be used as a preposition meaning "about to; approaching".
Middle Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Classical German
Old Borlish < Old English < Classical German
Old Borlish < Old Norse < Classical German

examples.vernacular: No scerraun alcun imprefait ny brevier je posc.
examples.english: There won't be any surprises in tomorrow's report.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin breviārium "short piece of writing", from brevis "short". Originally restricted to legal contexts, the word had entered common usage by the sixteenth century.
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin; clipped from earlier arbriscel, from a presumed Vulgar Latin arboriscellus "small tree-like plant".
Middle Borlish < French < Italian < Vulgar Latin
Middle Borlish < Old Aquitain < Italian < Latin
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Classical German

examples.vernacular: Jo vole pogntar apar ma jo broncau.
examples.english: I meant to flirt but I chickened out.

et: from Old Borlish broncar "stumble, misstep", cognate with synonymous bronchier in Old French but of unknown further origin. Perhaps connected to Latin broccus "buck-toothed" or truncus "docked, cut off", but neither is particularly semantically tempting. Unhelpful also are the equally unsourceable examples of Lombard bronco "thorny branch" and Barcelon bronc "knot in wood".

examples.vernacular: Jo kiglau l'oç seyon rovað dec j'er bucol hamtant.
examples.english: I missed what he asked because I was daydreaming.

et: Middle Borlish, a backformation from earlier adjective bucolic "idyllic, peaceful". The word had broadened from the first senses by the late eighteenth century, and has been used for purely mental peace since the early twentieth.
late medieval borrowing from Spanish related to Arabic قطرات <qaṭarāt> “droplets”, in reference to the process of distillation.
Old Borlish < Old French < Medieval Latin
Middle Borlish < Norman < Old French < Frankish
a Middle Borlish borrowing, originally in a naval context, from synonyous caihute in Middle Dutch. This is possibly a portmanteau of Old French cabane and hutte, both meaning "hut, shack".

examples.vernacular: Caye trencaç yon jo venoy primer n'Ausbagn.
examples.english: It was freezing when I first came to Axbane.

et: Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Panel jattove parlocan y cambr.
examples.english: Teak panels lined the bedroom.

examples.vernacular: Hamtour ny cambr pijon teyen dessur d'ogtant.
examples.english: The boarding house had over eighty lodgers.

et: collocation first used in the eighteenth century, from cambr "bedroom" and pijon "rent".
Old Borlish, extension of canfe < Late Latin canava < Latin cannabis

examples.vernacular: J'am çamoc sciftar ag tostuð.
examples.english: I like to have jam on toast.

examples.vernacular: J'ay my pan sciftað a çamoc demay.
examples.english: I've spread too much jam on my bread.

et: late Middle Borlish borrowing from contemporary Markish chammock "pulp, jam". This is presumably a derivative of verb chammen "chew, chomp", which is thought to be of imitative origin. In figurative use it derives from the use of jam to sweeten bitter medicines.
The idiom dates to the eighteenth century, literally "jam to convention".

examples.vernacular: Soldart vessonnað descenoirn des y camul.
examples.english: Soldiers in uniform spilled out of the jeep.

et: mid-twentieth century, genericised from Drengot military jargon but of uncertain further origin. Possibly an alteration of camel "camel" in reference to transporting soldiers and materiel; perhaps based on Latin chamūlcus "a kind of chariot". The term has been used to describe other "battle-ready" gear (usually consumer goods like backpacks and drinks bottles) since the 1980s.
from canç "luck" and the adjective derivational suffix -ous < -osus
Middle Borlish < Old French < Medieval Latin
descendant of Latin carduus or cardō "wild thistle".

examples.vernacular: Tu vel nos aïðar a l'ec fil cardonnar ou?
examples.english: Can you help us untangle these wires?

et: verbal derivative from Old Borlish cardon "carding tool". The verb has been used for metaphorical disentangling since at least the fourteenth century.
noun from car "dear, expensive" or from Medieval Latin cāritia < cārus
Old Borlish, past participle of carir

examples.vernacular: I laundau cant i descene dy carrot.
examples.english: He tripped as he got out of the carriage.

et: diminutive of Old Borlish car "wagon", which descends from Latin carrus "cart, wagon; load" (the suffix may have been added to distinguish the word from car "dear, darling", although the root survives as car "car, automobile" nonetheless). Use for trains is seen with their invention in the nineteenth century; metaphorical extension from that sense is seen in the twentieth.

ge: put the cart before the horse

et: Old Borlish cartle < Medieval Latin chartula < charta

examples.vernacular: Mell'acquetta er çarvinot ramenant starc.
examples.english: My liqueur tasted strongly of raspberries.

et: further diminutive of obsolete çarvin, cervin, itself abbreviated from Old Borlish baȝ cervin "raspberry, lit. fawn berry". The Old Borlish cervin "fawn, young deer" is a derivative of çarf "deer", from synonymous cervus in Latin.

examples.vernacular: Nos som gran sviðour a conemir cas sar.
examples.english: We're big fans of online shopping.

et: phrase first attested in the 1980s, from the preposition cas "pertaining to, on the subject of, at the home of, with respect to, when it comes to" (via Old Borlish cas from Latin casa "house") and the noun sar "fishnet, mesh, network" (from the synonmous Vask). The noun sar in this usage ("the Internet") is shortened from the phrase sar pistol "lit. the message mesh", itself translating Roun French mail pistre /maʒ piːtə/ in the same sense. This was first used in 1968 work of fiction Starsail, by Ashford Pasquier.
Old Borlish, directly from Vulgar Latin cascūnum "each one", a conflation of Classical quisque ūnum and Late Latin cata ūnum "each one".
Middle Borlish < Latin cathedrālis "pertaining to a bishop's seat"

examples.vernacular: Lor luïsceum nos caugtrbal jois y loub.
examples.english: Then we played football near the shops.

et: eighteenth-century compound from caugtrar "to kick" and bal "ball". The verb descends from Latin calcitrō "I strike with the heel", itself from calx "heel". Used predominantly of various amateur activities until the introduction of (multiple sets of) standardised rules in the twentieth century.

examples.vernacular: Jo componoy l'oc caum por cinq baðr.
examples.english: I arranged this piece for five musicians.

et: disputed. Semantically it should derive from Latin carmen "poem, incantation, prayer", but the phonological development is troublesome. Vocalisatio of /r > u/ is otherwise only attested in the presence of following /r̩/, as in Maucr "Wednesday" < *Marcre < Mercuriī; this has led some scholars to postulate an Insular Latin variant *carmus, carmera, but this is unattested.
via Old Borlish ça(r)veȝal "pillow" from synonymous cervīcal in Latin (the loss of /r/ is irregular but compare çavel "brain" < cerebellum).

seventeenth-century backformation from noun çaveyal "cushion, pillow". In the last sense the verb is especially seen in the phrase y los çaveyar "to sweeten the pill", literally "to cushion the slab".

examples.vernacular: Jo me cou battuð d'un hom raðant ag los.
examples.english: I got hit by someone cycling on the pavement.

ge: reach a state of being somehow

examples.vernacular: J'attenoy cos infruniscent tandic y grimmour cave yert.
examples.english: I waited impatiently while the computer booted up.

et: early Modern Borlish idiom literally meaning "to get awake". The verb cavir "get" is a direct descendant of capiō "take, pick, recieve", used in the sense "become" since the Middle Borlish period. The adjective yert "awake, alert; (of a business) open" descends via Old Borlish yerte "standing, upright, vertical" and synonymous ērctus in Vulgar Latin from Classical ērēctus "raised, built, erected". Extended from people to machinery and thence to businesses by the nineteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Sy femn es y frottour de cedar y faverrem ny muncef.
examples.english: Her wife is the best guitar player in the borough.

et: Middle Borlish, borrowed from early Jean cedara "guitar", a descendant of Latin cithara "lyre, lute" which was repurposed to refer to a related instrument of Morrove descent imported via Spain. The term has been used in the last sense since the nineteenth century (cf earlier ray a cedar "guitar ray") in reference to the shape of these fish.

examples.vernacular: Sy benjamin a cedr sta imminuð sad.
examples.english: He'd overdone the cedarwood perfume.

et: abbreviation of celaminour attested from as early as 1891.

examples.vernacular: Icon alcot a tu fait coll'oc celaminour?
examples.english: How many photos have you taken with this camera?

et: nineteenth century, agentive derivative of Scholastic Latin celāminō "I create an image, I depict". This is related to Classical cælāmen "bas-relief, engraving".
from Old Boral cemiteȝr, from Latin cœmētērium “burial ground”, from Greek κοιμητήριον “sleeping chamber”.

examples.vernacular: Remanen ceu alcun toscivr ag platabac.
examples.english: There were hardly any sandwiches left on the buffet table.

et: from Middle Borlish, original a legal term of art used to distinguish an act from a legally distinct act with the same consequences or punishment. In this use it was borrowed from Latin ceu "just like, just as if, as (if) it were". By the eighteenth century it had moved into general use, along with the innovated negative sense (originally restricted to the phrase ceu rien "barely anything, almost nothing").

examples.vernacular: My sour nil pausar ne parolar de sy cigl.
examples.english: My sister keeps talking about her boyfriend.

et: from Old Borlish cigle /tsiɣlə ~ tsiʎə/ "trinket, tchotchke, proverbially worthless object", from synonymous *cīculus in Vulgar Latin. This is a diminutive from Latin cīccum "trinket", from an Ancient Greek form κίκκος which is probably imitative. Semantic drift to the modern sense (via the term of address) is evidenced from the eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Jo vusca caldour de souscen neðan cous cingr.
examples.english: I hoped tomorrow was warm so it wouldn't hail.

et: from the late Old Borlish period originally restricted to naval usage, from Vask chingor "hail, hailstones". In the last sense it is a clipping of cingr acier "steel hailstone", apparently a direct calque from Cambrick deurkeseir "ball bearing".

examples.vernacular: Mame me dis de plu luy me cirteyar.
examples.english: Mum told me to stop mithering her.

et: originally in the first sense, an extension from early old Borlish ceȝrtar "peddle, itinerate" with a causative suffix. This in turn descends from Late Latin circitō "I peddle, frequent", from circō "I traverse, wander through". In reflexive use the word is attested from the early modern period.

examples.vernacular: Y belem ny forest se mis afaç con ec ciscr d'aucel.
examples.english: The forest scene opened with shrieks from birds.

et: attested in Old Borlish ciscle "shriek", a deverbal from cisclar "to shriek, scream" (now obsoleted by ciscr fair "to do a shriek"). This descends from a synonymous cistulō in Vulgar Latin reflected also in Vascon chillar "creak" and Parisian gicler "spurt". In turn this is presumed to be an alteration of Classical Latin fistulō "I whistle, play the flute" via assimilation or sound symbolism.

examples.vernacular: Jo sveilau des y clacqment a jarry jusser.
examples.english: I woke to the clatter of plates downstairs.

et: noun formation from clacquar "rattle, clatter, cause a disturbance". Used for gunfire since the eighteenth century, and for general disruption from the nineteenth.
This was borrowed in the Middle Borlish period from contemporary French clacquer "clap, slap, slam", or directly from that word's Germanic origin (compare Willem or Kentish clacken "whack, shake").
Old Borlish < Old French < Medieval Latin

examples.vernacular: N'entrant la jo lou veu cleunfeyant ag soufa.
examples.english: I walked in on them cuddling on the sofa.

et: sixteenth century, verbal derivative of cleun "clump, lump" (now obsolete). This noun reflects Old Borlish cliun "ball, lump", a borrowing from synonymous clīewen in Old English which also gives e.g. Merch clewn "yarn".

examples.vernacular: Jo montau ag tabr e clignau my bos yert a haut.
examples.english: I got up on the table and fired my gun into the air.

et: Old Borlish < Medieval Latin < Gaulish < onomatopoeia
from Old Borlish closnautre "surrounded, beset", adverbial derivation from clos "closed" < Latin clausus reflecting a putative Latin *clausiōnāliter.

examples.vernacular: Il aun cascun dou clou a vastel ja paut.
examples.english: They've eaten two pieces of cake each.

et: from Old Borlish clou /klu(v)/ "clove (of garlic)", borrowed from synonymous clufu in Old English. The meaning was extended to other portions of things in the Middle Borlish period; in the phrase clou politic "political party" it is attested from the seventeenth century.

an initialism for catener a mitigor muriac “chained muriac mitigor”. Catener “polymer” is a direct borrowing of Latin catēnārius “of a chain”, referring to the molecular structure thereof; mitigor** is likewise from mītigōr “ripener”, after its ability to ripen fruits; muriac*** is from muriacus “briny”.
thirteenth-century borrowing either from Vascon çocle "plinth" or perhaps directly from Mostara zocolo, both from Latin socculus "little shoe".

examples.vernacular: Sy coðelostað er ençant a nos tardir.
examples.english: His caution was starting to slow us down.

examples.vernacular: I tirau un largeç a haçot imprefait des sy cofrsac.
examples.english: He pulled surprisingly many things from his backpack.

et: Middle Borlish, compound of cofr "basket" (now archaic or dialect) < synonymous cophinus in Latin, and sac < Latin saccus "bag, sack". Originally in the latter senses, denoting a bag carried like a basket; in the "backpack" sense it is attested only from the late nineteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Jo cogleu y quesq y maðuressem dy ranscel.
examples.english: I picked the ripest damson on the branch.

examples.vernacular: Il ern l'imascry descorçant ag cogn jagerrem.
examples.english: They were peering at the sculpture in the far corner.

examples.vernacular: Surcay nos condoceu an çoir parey.
examples.english: It turns out we go to the same gym.

et: early twentieth century, clipping of forçoir

examples.vernacular: I reconnoy y segr luy collindant.
examples.english: She recognised the man next to her.

et: regular descendant of Latin collimitō "I border on", from limitō "I delimit, bound". Alternatively, a derivation in the Old Borlish period from an unattested lindar or now-dialectal lint "fence". Extension to conceptual closeness is attested from the seventeenth century.

examples.vernacular: Lon ongit no's un collujon d'Ubicqtað unanim postular.
examples.english: It is nonsensical to say there is a united Ubiquity bloc.

et: Middle Borlish, originally restricted to pejorative use and directed at one's political enemies. Borrowed from Latin collūsiō, noun derivative of collūdō "to collude, to secretly work (with someone) to the detriment of another". Nowadays used neutrally for alliance-federacies like the Drengot Collusion.
early twentieth century, literally "like babies in prams".

ge: as well as can be expected

et: Middle Borlish < Latin; a Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin combūrō "I burn up, cremate, scald".

examples.vernacular: L'agent dy Majon Roug souseyeu l'ig scard commoðer.
examples.english: The Red House agent dealt with that resistance group.

examples.vernacular: Comoscon vouð vos l'oc delit motivar?
examples.english: How are you going to justify this crime?

et: from Latin competō "I am equal to, I am capable of".

examples.vernacular: J'am alcun entr y compeðour nell'oc torne.
examples.english: I dislike all the contenders in this tourney.

et: Middle Borlish, agent derivation from the verb compeðir "compete, contend, fight". The word has been used in political contexts since the late seventeenth century, although it only became widespread a hundred years later.

examples.vernacular: Y compleis spartessem courn gajan tars.
examples.english: The better contestants won decidedly.

et: Middle Borlish, past participle of now-obsolete compleitr "to involve, to require the participation of" (compare extant se pleitr "to involve onself, participate"). This descends from Latin complector "I encircle, involve, include".

examples.vernacular: Catr çondr sur sy boucr dreçn "ðurr".
examples.english: Four charms on his bracelet spelt "burn".

et: Middle Borlish, via contemporary French from Tuscan ciondolo "pendant, charm". This is a deverbal from ciondolare "dangle, swing", which is thought to reflect a Vulgar Latin exundulō "I sway", from unda "wave". The Borlish term has broadened to cheaper and less precious ornaments than its cognates in other languages.
Middle Borlish < Latin, noun from confluïr
Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin congruus "fit, suitable, concordant".
Markish < Russian; from Markish connockry, nominal derivation from connock "ice skate" (cf. Borlish connoc), itself from Vascon connòc /kuˈɲɔk/ < Russian конёк <kon'ok> "pony, skate".

examples.vernacular: Nos se contentaum a un tatover soul porçonnar.
examples.english: We made do with sharing a single potato.

et: verbal derivation from adjective content "happy, glad, satisfied", which descends directly from Latin contentus "satisfied, lit. contained". This is the past participle of contineō "I keep, contain, fasten". The slightly extended senses relating to appeasement appear from the fifteenth century.
derivative of contar "count" with the suffix -eyar

examples.vernacular: Cay descreuçon dy contrdontaçon dy Reyaum ag Danau.
examples.english: It describes the downfall of the Danube Kingdom.

et: noun derivation from the verb contrdontar "foil, stymie, thwart".
a pleonastic extension of now-obsolete dontar "thwart, defeat", which descends from Latin domitō "I tame, I vanquish".
Latin contrāveniō "oppose", synchronically analysable as contr "against" + venir "come"
via Old Borlish from Vulgar Latin conviō "I accompany on the way".
Middle Borlish < Latin. Noun sense transferred from the adjective in the eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Com voum nos se corrir pall'oc glonscel?
examples.english: How will we get out of this mess?

et: from synonymous corrogātiō in Scholastic Latin. This comes from Medieval Latin corrogāta "corvée, collective labour provided by demand", itself probably formed by ellipsis of a Late Latin phrase opera corrogāta "invited work", from corrogō "I bring together by request, I invite".

examples.vernacular: Nos corrogau alcheðr l'oc treborth.
examples.english: We're redeveloping this seaside resort.

et: Backformation from noun corrogation "infrastructure, public works", from synonymous corrogātiō in Scholastic Latin. This comes from Medieval Latin corrogāta "corvée, collective labour provided by demand", itself probably formed by ellipsis of a Late Latin phrase opera corrogāta "invited work", from corrogō "I bring together by request, I invite".

examples.vernacular: Jo vel for un corrovað me nommar, mathem partenent.
examples.english: I'd only consider myself an amateur when it comes to maths.

et: from Middle Boral corrouað “invitee, recruit”, past participle of corrouar “to invite, to recruit”. Sense of “amateur, enthusiast” from 16C.
from Old Boral coroar “to invite”, from Latin corrogō “I bring together”.
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Italian < Latin

examples.vernacular: Jo fey pat ag cla con deit çosc.
examples.english: I fumbled the key with stubby fingers.

et: adjectival use of Old Borlish noun çosc "stump of a tree", which was a variant (likely borrowed from çoche in Old French) of native cognate çoc "stump". These descend from Vulgar Latin tsucca "stump, trunk", though to come via Gaulish from Classical German stuccas "stick, beam; stump". The word was replaced in its noun use by taisc "stump", possibly from Latin taxeus "made of yew wood".

examples.vernacular: Cain l'eç sonc a vençar for cosogr.
examples.english: These items are not to be sold separately.

et: from Middle Borlish adverb cosogr "as a pair, as a group"; prepositional use descends from the construction cosogr a X "in a set with X". This comes from Old Borlish noun cosoȝre "the other of a pair, (in the plural) a matching pair of things" and homonymous adjective "corresponding, respective, concomitant". The noun cosoȝre is a broadening of Borlish Latin cōsocer, cōsocrum "the other party to a contract", which is a local spelling and sense of Classical cōnsocer "the father of one's child's spouse"; the fathers of a marrying couple being prototypical counterparties to a contract.

examples.vernacular: Ascur alcun hom n'a costoscment mis all'yert.
examples.english: Make sure no-one's alerted the authorities.

et: nominalisation from verb costojar "defend, police, regulate", an Old Borlish derivation of noun costosc "protection, defence". This descends uncomplicatedly from Latin custōdia "safekeeping, custody"; compare Kentish costage "imprisonment, captivity".

examples.vernacular: Çot y bal yert a haut eð atten a y laç cavir.
examples.english: Fling the ball straight up and try to catch it.

et: from early 17th century çottar "beat, batter", which was borrowed via a Middlesea language (plausibly Napolitan zottà "flog") from Arabic noun سَوْط • (sawṭ) "whip". The word appears to have begun as naval slang, having acquired its modern meaning by the time it enters general use in the 18th century.

examples.vernacular: Te stove un cottegl a ty dois accatar?
examples.english: Did you need to buy a new phone case?

et: from Old Borlish coteȝl "tunic, kirtle", a pleonastic diminutive from Latin cotta "undercoat", from Germanic.

examples.vernacular: Vos saveð ou l'instroy eç stuðant çougr?
examples.english: Do you know if he has unruly students?

et: 19C, imported from slang used on the Borlish-speaked islands of the Arcabil [Caribbean] but cognate with terms used across the whole region, including northern Cappatia [South America]. These originate in Run'allo [Quechua] chucru "difficult", as used to describe animals. The unrelated bougr "boor, scoundrel" may have influenced the word's sense development.
Middle Borlish borrowing from French couite "discus, quoit, flat stone", of unknown further origin.

examples.vernacular: Jo no's un cougt droccað benoçant posc un dezein.
examples.english: I haven't used a compact disc in ten years.

et: literally "notched disc", attested from the late twentieth century as a calque of Cambrick coetan dolkiadau "disc with indentations" (partly chosen so as to preserve the abbreviation CD).
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Ancient Greek
Old Borlish < Old French < Vulgar Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Torneyeð y cout fin a y zygom sey ovart.
examples.english: Turn the crank until the valve's open.

et: via Old Borlish coud, coft "elbow, bend" from Latin cubitum "elbow, cubit". This is related to verb cubō "I lie down, I recline".
originally in eighteenth-century staddenzen Boral as a borrowing from Yengatow [Tupi] cutuc "to pierce, stab" (likely altered by analogy to toccar "to touch, make contact with").

examples.vernacular: I coutoccau y tambour agil eð exact.
examples.english: I coutoccau y tambour agil eð exact.

et: originally, along with the corresponding deverbal noun coutoc "tap, poke, prod", in eighteenth-century staddenzen Boral as a borrowing from Yengatow [Tupi] cutuc "to pierce, stab" (likely altered by analogy to toccar "to touch, make contact with").
Old Borlish < Old French < Italian < Medieval Latin
Old Borlish, past participle of covrir

examples.vernacular: Y coyol dy cligs es coup de fourraç mout cavent.
examples.english: The church's spire often gets struck by lightning.

et: via Old Borlish coȝol "hood; cone" from Latin cucūlla "hood, cowl; conical wrapper or case". Used consistently to translate Scholastic Latin cōnus "cone" in geometrical texts since the fourteenth century (possibly the unrelated con "with" discouraged directly borrowing that Latin term). In the modern language restricted to detached headgear that is at least vaguely conical.
variant Late Latin crīnia from Latin crīnis "lock of hair"

examples.vernacular: My gramma sorteu un boist plen de crochet.
examples.english: My gran brought out a full tin of biscuits.

et: Middle Borlish diminutive from croccar "to crack", a dialect form (related to synonymous modern coroccar) which is presumably of onomatopoeic origin. Extended to other similarly-shaped objects from the nineteenth century.
Old Borlish, from an Insular Latin variant crumen of Classical Latin crumēna "pouch for carrying money".
Old Borlish < Old English; presumably from Old English cnucel "knuckle" but only attested from the fourteenth century.
via Old Italian zuccharo from Arabic سُكَّر‎ (sukkar).
past participle of çucarrar “to sugar, to sweeten”

examples.vernacular: L'intermane un cug de sy caldour corpore.
examples.english: It was a decrease in her body temperature.

et: descendant of Old Borlish cauȝ, cuȝ /kaˈyɣ ~ kyɣ/ "fall, descent", which reflects Latin adjective cadūcus "falling; doomed; futile; (law) lapsed". The word is seen in metaphorical use almost at once; for physical downward slopes it may have been influenced by Norman cute "fall; chute". Poetic and legal usages are both attested from the late Middle Borlish period.

examples.vernacular: Yon erað vos cuidant cas quelt?
examples.english: Where were you thinking for dinner?

et: from Old Borlish, borrowed from Old French cuidier "to consider, presume, think", which reflects the synoymous cōgitō in Latin. Displaced always-rare coiðar "to think" from the same source.

examples.vernacular: Jo cur bogr yon nis sbolognar.
examples.english: I don't care whose fault it is.

examples.vernacular: La brouc un çut tal plen cas music.
examples.english: She has a lot of musical potential.

et: eighteenth century, borrowed from Vascon çut "waterwheel, weir; electric battery"; the latter sense was clipped from earlier çut barric "electric weir", cells being seen as analogous stores of useful work. This in turn is a rebracketed form of original açut "waterwheel, dam", which is allied with Leon açud and Portingale açude; it was borrowed from Arabic السُّدّ • as-sudd "the dam, the dike".
Old Borlish < Medieval Latin < Ancient Greek
"Old Borlish, univerbation of d'ac að ii"

examples.vernacular: Dou cat ern ðalleyant sou sol blanc.
examples.english: Two cats were basking in the sunlight.

et: from Middle Borlish ðalleyar "spread-eagle, to stretch taut", extended from its used in tannery to describe leather stretched out on tenterhooks. This reflects Old Borlish ðalȝar "to be attached to, to be fastened to", directly from synonymous adalligō in Latin.

examples.vernacular: L'a un sgart mallovicher de ðar.
examples.english: He's very naïve about farmwork.

et: Middle Borlish deverbal from ðarar "plough, till; farm; labour", originally restricted to crop production and not animal husbandry. In the last sense it is attested since the early twentieth century but is thought to be much older; cf. Tuscan arare "to plough; to have sex with".

This descends uncomplicatedly from Latin adarō "I plough, till". In the last sense it is attested since the early twentieth century but is thought to be much older; cf. Tuscan arare "to plough; to have sex with".
from a presumed Vulgar Latin dēārefō "I dry out" related to Classical ārefaciō "I dry up, wither" < āreō "I am dry" (compare Portingale alfar "to be thirsty").

examples.vernacular: L'oc darfour quesq es tan quemant.
examples.english: This purple bathrobe is so comfy.

et: agentive derivation from darfar "dry out, cause to dry, desiccate".

examples.vernacular: Nos n'eu redon aðief por semman passar n'untal davarn.
examples.english: We don't have enough money on hand to stay in a hotel like that.

et: 19C from Cambrick y davarn “the hotel”, in particular a reference to world-famous Hasinick resort town Y Davarn Heul “The Sun Hotel”. This word is an Old Welsh borrowing from Latin taberna “shop, inn”, making it a doublet of Borlish tarn “pub, café”.

examples.vernacular: I stima vos fosseð un hom troç e de sanc ðus.
examples.english: He thought you were fierce and hot-blooded.

et: idiom attested from the seventeenth century, coined approximately at the same time as de sanc freit "cold-blooded, emotionless", literally meaning "of burning blood". In the last senses the phrase is attested from the nineteenth century.
idiom attested from the seventeenth century, coined approximately at the same time as de sanc ðus "hot-blooded, emotional".

examples.vernacular: Nos se ponau voud a sy vellisqment dehiscn.
examples.english: We looked forward to his plans falling apart.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin dehīscō "I gape, yawn, split open", used primarily in botanical contexts as of blossoms or fruits. Ending in -ir modelled after other change-of-state verbs like finir, jo finisc "to finish, I finish". In figurative use it may have been facilitated by the pre-existing metaphor of the flower as a work or achievement.

examples.vernacular: Jo ðejau y pie neðan y port closisceus.
examples.english: I wedged the door open with my foot.

et: disputed. The word is often presumed to be a metathetic reflex of Old Borlish (a)ieðar [(a)dʒeˈðar] "ram, drive, push forward". This descends from Latin arietō "strike, batter", a verbal derivative from ariēs "ram; battering ram". However, this verb is last attested over two centuries before the first evidence of ðejar in the Middle Borlish period.
borrowed in legal use from Latin dēlīquī "I did something wrong".

examples.vernacular: Comoscon vouð vos l'oc delit motivar?
examples.english: How are you going to justify this crime?

et: borrowed in the tenth century from Old English dēman "judge, decide"

examples.vernacular: I reconnosc ou sy fraðr sey tan demastr?
examples.english: Does he know his brother is so judgemental?

et: derivation from demar "to opine, to express an opinion" with -astr, a pejorative suffix. First attested in the eighteenth century as the name of a character in one of Tamottan's satirical dramas.
from legal Latin dēmorātiō "adjournment" along with verb demorar "demur, delay, postpone" < dēmoror "I delay, hold up; I tarry, linger".

ge: occuring in the final stage of any process
et: The adjective denover is a contemporary derivation from denou "conclusion, ending, denouement; the final stage of any process", itself also a deverbal from denovar "untie, unravel; end". This is an Old Borlish derivation from nou "know, tangle", from the synonymous nōdus in Latin.
Old Borlish < Old French < Vulgar Latin

examples.vernacular: Nos stou la javigar des caucet.
examples.english: We must leave no stone unturned.

et: idiom attested from the late nineteenth century, literally "out of (one's) socks". Thought to have arisen in Damvath slang as a sexual metaphor (taking one's socks off prior to sleeping with someone), although in modern usage it is not considered at all obscene. The noun caucet "sock" is a diminutive of obsolete cauç "hose, stockings, tights", via Medieval Latin calcea from Classical calceus "boot".

examples.vernacular: Jan es desamoraçandessem; alor i's luy y courstravay accommettent.
examples.english: John is more likely to fall out of love, so he's the one having an affair.

et: from des- “reversal, negation” + amoraçar “to fall in love, especially suddenly”, itself from (now rare) amoraç “sudden lust, all-consuming desire”, either from Old Boral amor “love” + -aç “intensifier, pejorative”, or directly from Latin amoraceus “resembling love”.

examples.vernacular: Y baðrment trassonnau an bercellot desbiacq.
examples.english: The ensemble shifted to a swung ballad.

et: early modern borrowing via French desbiaque "slanted, lopsided" from synonymous di sbiaco in an Italian language. The noun sbiaco "slant, bias tape" comprises the prefix s- and a descendant from Vulgar Latin oblaecus, variant of oblīquus "sidelong, awry; hostile". Used in a musical context since the nineteenth century; in the last sense (lately often clipped to biacq) it is seen from approximately the same time.
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Classical German

examples.vernacular: Faç le noc gavir neðan sy sogr ðescar.
examples.english: Making her have fun will only make her sadder.

et: from Old Borlish ðescar "to feed, fatten up", inherited directly from synonymous Insular Latin adēscō (in more productive use than in Classical Latin). This is a derivative of noun ēsca "food, fodder, bait, fuel", from which we also have modern Borlish esc "bait, lure". Extension from food to fuel and then to metaphorical use is attested early, from the twelfth century.

examples.vernacular: Il ern l'imascry descorçant ag cogn jagerrem.
examples.english: They were peering at the sculpture in the far corner.

et: originally in the last sense, either a native formation in the Middle Borlish period from noun scorç "bark, peel" and prefix de- indicating reversal or movement away, or else a calque of Latin dēcorticō "I remove the bark or peel" formed in the same way. Metaphorical use is seen almost immediately and by the eighteenth century the verb has almost entirely been supplanted in its literal sense by periphrastic construction scorç delir de "to remove bark/peel from".
deverbal (from at least 8C) of desirar “to want, desire”, from Latin dēsīderō “I want, wish for”.

examples.vernacular: Sy maðr creye ig sy desir escapat sceus le coïr d'un marið trovar.
examples.english: Her mother believed her wanderlust might stop her finding a husband.

examples.vernacular: Skig sdroyet desjovar cant moustr se migrn.
examples.english: Do not unplug drives during file transfer.

et: Middle Borlish, derivative of jovar "yoke, tie together, match; (later) plug in". This is either a direct descendant of Latin iugō "I join, yoke" or more likely a re-verbing via jou < Latin iugum "yoke". The term was used metaphorically almost at once, especially in religious contexts. In both the colloquial and electrical senses the word is first attested in the nineteenth century.

Old Borlish ðestmar "work out, consider, turn one's attention to", which descends from an extension of Classical Latin æstimō "I determine the worth of, I value"; thus, ðesmar is a doublet of semi-learned stimar "consider, deem".

examples.vernacular: All'oc ostendour fey jougl y ðesmbal d'Apollon.
examples.english: This blogger unexpectedly predicted the future.

et: verb-noun compound formed in the twentieth century by analogy to earlier analogous words like caugtrbal "football", lit. "kick-ball". The word has been used metaphorically for unexpected things since the 1990s.

examples.vernacular: Me storra i vin y tabr despondr pre nos pascau.
examples.english: Me storra i vin y tabr despondr pre nos pascau.

et: descending from Old Borlish desponre "distribute, set out" or reborrowed during the Middle Borlish period from its source in Latin dispōnō "I arrange". The latter senses, likely influenced by cognates in other Romance languages, are intransitive and used with preposition de "of, from".

examples.vernacular: Jo me cou destourmað n'Avril d'an 1909.
examples.english: I was demobbed in April 1909.

et: early modern Borlish derivation from the root tourm "troop; barracks". The word has been used metaphorically of products since the mid-twentieth century, and is seen in jocular use from around the same time.

examples.vernacular: Nos stou desveyar por y tragres eluïr.
examples.english: We'll detour to avoid the parade.

et: from Old Borlish desveyar "stray, deviate, go off course", inherited from Late Latin disviō "I leave the path", a variant of synonymous deviō in Classical Latin. Alternatively, a later formation from Old Borlish vey "path, course" < Latin via "road" (compare modern veyaç "trip, journey").

university slang among the Vithor New School's students, attested there from the eighteenth century and entering the wider lexicon some decades afterwards. The noun is a borrowing from Latin deunx "eleven twelfths", related to uncia "one twelfth". The story linking its modern usage to a twelve-man jury is almost certainly false; more likely is simply the sense of being almost but not quite the whole thing.

examples.vernacular: Nos farreu noc deunx cossy alcheðr.
examples.english: We won't get so lucky again.

et: Middle Borlish < Middle French < Old French

examples.vernacular: Tal inquit no son dignant de mell'yam.
examples.english: Such words are unworthy of my uncle.

et: present participle of dignar "merit, deserve, be worthy of", itself a verbal derivation from Old Borlish diȝn "worth, merit". This reflects Latin adjective dignus "worthy, appropriate, meet". The latter senses are seen from the late Middle Borlish period.

examples.vernacular: Servið son quelt dijarbr all'ig tarn.
examples.english: They do a decent dinner at that inn.

et: adjectival derivation from dijarr "to bear, cope with, deal with, stomach". This verb descends from Middle Borlish dijarr "parse, classify, sort out; digest, stomach", a borrowing from Latin dīgerō "I disseminate, disperse, arrange" altered by analogy with now-archaic verb enjarr "to eat" < ingerō "I carry in, pile up".
18C, borrowed from French disque “disc”, from Latin discus “discus, dish”.

examples.vernacular: Tu a lorry derran disq a CMM oïð: “Soll'Autr Stel” ou?
examples.english: Have you heard their latest record “Beneath New Stars”?

examples.vernacular: Sy dithyramb s'ubicqfey cas sar.
examples.english: Her tirade's gone viral online.

et: originally in the first sense, borrowed in the early modern period via Latin from δῑθῠ́ρᾰμβος • dīthŭ́rămbos in Ancient Greek. In poetic use the word has never denoted any particular metre or form; its intentional vagueness has allowed poets to use the term for a diverse array of works. In the last senses the term is attested from the nineteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Cu vel un nom sceint issarr com dob?
examples.english: Who'd use a real name as a username?

et: originally in the first sense, a deverbal noun from dobar "confer knighthood upon, dub". In extended use the word is seen from as early as the fourteenth century; the first attestation of the last sense is from 1964.\et
Old Borlish < Old French < Old Dutch

examples.vernacular: Y ðocaç lour coy de dormir ec noit.
examples.english: The trauma keeps them up at night.

et: noun derivation from the verb ðocar "harrow, till; afflict, bedevil, torment, haunt" with the pejorative suffix -aç (from Latin -āceus "shaped like").
from Vulgar Latin adoccō "I till, harrow", an extension of the synonymous occō in Classical Latin. The verb gains its emotional senses in the sixteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Com s'augrim y stent a starn d'un dom lonc sy ray?
examples.english: What is a hemisphere's surface area in terms of its radius?

et: originally in the first sense, from Middle Borlish dom "dome; stately building, edifice" (now obsolete in the latter senses). This comes from the conflation of Italian duomo "cathedral", from Latin domus ecclēsiae​ "meeting-house, church", with French dosme "dome", which comes via Late Latin dōma "roof" from Greek δῶμᾰ "house, housetop". The merger, which had likely already occurred in Middle French before the term entered Borlish, was aided by the prominence of domes on Italian cathedrals.

examples.vernacular: Il se ponden a plaç mi ny rout, graðleur e donation rovant.
examples.english: They were standing in the street asking for money and volunteers.

et: borrowed ca. 1250 from Latin dōnātiō, dōnātiōnem “an act of giving, of presenting”, from dōnō “I give”.

examples.vernacular: Ant heu ðonc l'ovroy y valigs.
examples.english: With a wry look he opened the case.

et: via Old Borlish from Latin aduncus "hooked, bent, curved", from uncus "hook" (whence Borlish onc "hook, clasp, link, trigger"). Metaphorical extension is seen from the fifteenth century.
Old Borlish < Old French < Medieval Latin < Classical German

examples.vernacular: L'ig connart me dau ðorn!
examples.english: That bastard punched me!

et: Middle Borlish deverbal from aðornar "punch", via Old Borlish from Insular Latin addurnō "I punch". This (possibly along with an unattested noun *durnus "fist") is borrowed from Borland Kelt; compare modern Welsh dyrnod "punch".

examples.vernacular: Y victoir dell'ig sleut sta un ðorn de hanc.
examples.english: That candidate winning came out of nowhere.

et: phrase meaning "punch from (the) flank", used figuratively to describe an unexpected event since the late eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Nos desveyaum d'un ðorof a cogmaðer clamant.
examples.english: We dodged a gaggle of noisy tourists.

et: from Old Borlish ðor(o)f "assembly, herd", a borrowing influenced both by Old English þorp, þrop "village, assembly" and by drāf "the action of driving; herd, company; road". Compare the word garaf "grip" from Old Portingale grafo, garfo "hook" for the result of Vr, rV metathesis.

examples.vernacular: Jo save noc ou poðir un dos may de gouth complir.
examples.english: I didn't know if I could do another set of pushups.

et: originally in the first sense, a semi-learned borrowing from Late Latin dosis "dose", itself from Greek δόσις • dósis "gift, portion; dose". The word's extension to other measured quantities is seen in the Middle Borlish period. The latter senses originate in the military slang of the late nineteeth century, spreading into civilian use amid body-building fads during the twentieth.

examples.vernacular: Innogbr son y ci hautessem ny doujug gradual.
examples.english: The higher-ups in the hierarchy are untouchable.

et: idiom seen from the fifteenth century, literally "web of ranks". The noun doujug "cobweb; network, system" was originally a northern dialect term from the phrase doun jug /dundʒəj/ "July's down feathers", while the adjective gradual is a regular derivation from grad "rank, (noble) title, status", from Latin gradus "step, rank".

examples.vernacular: Cascif eð vos hur dað an dragoman voscon inconfeyabr?
examples.english: Why did you hire an interpreter you don't trust?

et: originally in the first senses and in particular with reference to interpreters of Arabic and Turk languages. The word was borrowed in the Middle Borlish period via Latin from Malchassian Greek δραγομάνος (dragomános) "interpreter"; this in turn came via Arabic and Syriac from Acadian 𒅴𒁄 (targumannum) "interpreter". Later semantic development was influenced by the suffix -man "-monger; seller, shop".

examples.vernacular: Jo vis y fabr all'Auspeç Impareïbr noncupað.
examples.english: I saw the dram-styled Peerless Seer's stage show.

et: of obscure origin. Putative connections with English trough or Welsh rhych "furrow" have too many issues to be workable, and nobody credits a link with draucus "strongman" in Latin; perhaps the word (which is first attested in the Old Borlish period) is simply onomatopoeia.

examples.vernacular: Cayen deg minut pre un vec alandau ny droccon.
examples.english: It was ten minutes before a bus came to the lay-by.

et: twentieth century, a noun formation from verb droccar "notch, indent" calqued from dentelon "lay-by" in Parisian French.

examples.vernacular: Nos creim y droug terraun dessur de murðon pavar.
examples.english: We think the contributions will total over ten thousand pavar.

et: attested since the Middle Borlish period, a deverbal from droughar "join in, help out; contribute, interfere". Cognate with Merch drudge "worker".

examples.vernacular: Nos deyeu vos benaular por vossy droughanç.
examples.english: We must thank you all for your contributions.

et: Middle Borlish, noun from droughar "join in, help out, contribute, interfere".

examples.vernacular: Cu 'sirn droughar de nossy taflot?
examples.english: Who wants to join our board game?

et: from Old Borlish drouȝar "to perform a service, to provide help, to carry out an errand", borrowed from Old English drēogan "to do (a duty), to endure, to bear". At first especially with religious connotations, as of providing Christian charity.
