Old Borlish < Middle Dutch < Classical German
Old Borlish < Latin adūrō "I kindle, set fire to"
participle of ðurr "burn, set on fire"

examples.vernacular: J'ig saveu mell'amig er duvant a scac.
examples.english: I realised my friend was cheating at chess.

et: direct descendant of Old Borlish duvar, dufar "to duck, dip, lower oneself; to plunge into water", which was borrowed from Old English dyfan "to dive, submerse". In its ludic sense it is attested from the seventeenth century.

examples.vernacular: Jo quïsceu ec ogl eð ençau a conteyar.
examples.english: I closed my eyes and started counting.

et: fixed idiom literally meaning "to extinguish eyes". Both this and its opposite ec ogl accendr "open one's eyes, lit. light eyes" first appear in the early Middle Borlish period, presumably via the notion of making things light and dark. In metaphorical use the phrase is seen from the fifteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Poy cossirn lorry liesc scholer la un Eden soluð.
examples.english: Few remember their time at that school fondly.

et: literally "an Eden that has been let go", an idiom first attested in Kigman's fifteenth-century poetry. The adjective soluð is the past participle of souvr "solve, let go, release, launch", which descends directly from the mostly synonymous solvō in Latin.

examples.vernacular: D'alcun sunt a effum vil toð gent vossy launt ignoscr.
examples.english: No amount of bluster will overshadow your faux pas.

et: borrowing in the 18th century from Scholastic Latin noun effūmus "emitted smoke, steam" and verb effūmō "I emit smoke, steam". These are derived from fūmus "smoke, steam" with the prefix ex- "out, away from". In metaphorical use the word is attested from the late 19th century.

examples.vernacular: Stou joun sgarant effurar dy hal sdroy vabianclosnautr.
examples.english: We need to keep kids out of the abandoned warehouse.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from contemporary legal Latin effūror "I rob, I dispossess", from fūror "I steal, I plunder", a deponent verbal derivative of noun fūr "thief".

examples.vernacular: J'yeme noc scið ig l'aye un majon de livr tal effus.
examples.english: I didn't realise her library was so extensive.

et: 16th-century borrowing from Latin effūsus "poured out, discharged", past participle of effundō "pour out, discharge" (itself borrowed at roughly the same time as effondr "spread out, disperse, scatter"). As a vaguer word simply meaning "significant" it is seen from the late 18th century.

examples.vernacular: Dou carpenter son egnam de casn coupant.
examples.english: Two carpenters are cutting oak planks.

et: Middle Borlish, rebracketing of earlier legnam "timber" reinterpreting the initial <l-> as the definite article. This is a borrowing from some Romance language's cognate of Medieval Latin lignāmen "timber"; it cannot be a direct descendant because native words reflect -āmen as -amn, cf. eramn "bronze", scamn "swarm". The word is no longer current as a personal insult except in one-off comparisons of somebody to a literal plank; in vulgar use the term is attested from the 1970s but may be much older.

examples.vernacular: Dighað: neleð me gemir / Ciel seraun yonoscon egreir.
examples.english: Tell them not to cry at all / Heaven is wherever I fall.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin ēgredior "I step out, disembark, overstep, leave", a compound of prefix ex- "out" and root gradior "I walk, march". It was modelled on the sole native descendant of a gradior compound, engreir "to begin; to sleep with" (since lost, although the participle engres "way in, starting point; sexual intercourse" remains). In euphemistic use the verb is first attested in the eighteenth century.
reflects synonymous eȝrtumne in Old Borlish, from eȝr "ill, sick" (cf. obsolete modern egr "sick") < Latin aeger "sick" and -tumne "-ness" < Vulgar Latin -tūmine (related to Classical -tūdinem).

examples.vernacular: Y sanat all'egrtumnoir tein for dou.
examples.english: There's only two doctors at the clinic.

et: Middle Borlish, location derivative of egrtumn "illness, ailment, sickness".

examples.vernacular: L'effojaçon trovau un emblemat je ados.
examples.english: The excavation found a mosaic yesterday.

et: borrowing from Napolitan emblemata "mosaic, tilework", itself from Latin emblēma "mosiac, marquetry" or directly from Greek ἔμβλημᾰ • émblēma "insertion, ornament; mosaic". Metaphorical extension is attested from the start; the last sense is a late twentieth-century innovation.
Old Borlish < Old French < Classical German

examples.vernacular: L'emendanç ottem plagra alcun hom.
examples.english: The best solution will please nobody.

et: noun derived from emendar "to fix, repair, resolve, sort out".
via Old Borlish amendar, later re-classicised, from Latin ēmendō "I improve, remedy, cure".
Old Borlish < Late Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Y soldart encromnn mansc com louf famiscent.
examples.english: The soldiers scarf food like starving wolves.

et: Middle Borlish, verbal derivation from cromn "pocket, purse, small bag". Metaphorical extension of this word is seen from the fifteenth century; in the slang sense it most recently became popular in recent decades.

examples.vernacular: Enombreu casc corrovað ac yent oc aubon.
examples.english: Let's rally the morning's new recruits.

et: The verb enombrar is a sixteenth-century borrowing from Latin ēnumerō "I count up, I reckon", based on existing noun nombr < Latin numerus "number". Military use dates from the Democratic Wars of the mid-eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: L'oc enonç es abrangent a my nom ou?
examples.english: Does this list have my name on it?

et: deverbal noun from enonçar "enumerate, list, order", orignally "make a report". This descends via Old Borlish from Latin ēnūntiō "I disclose, express, report".

examples.vernacular: Scey un ensembr a scac yonoscon ny tarn.
examples.english: There's a chess set somewhere in the pub.

et: early modern borrowing in all senses from French ensemble "together; outfit, kit, music group". This descends directly from the Latin adverb īnsimul "together, simultaneously". The term is particularly used for informal or temporary groupings, as well as games and other entertainment.

examples.vernacular: Jo vil te rannuðar an ensign extolliðessem.
examples.english: I will recommend you for a higher position.

et: Middle Borlish, a semilearned borrowing from Latin insignia "emblem, badge", a noun formation from adjective insignis "marked, distinguished". The word has been used metonymically to refer to the position conferred or represented by an insignia since the fifteenth century, and it has been used in card games from approximately the same time.
nominal derivation in the Middle Borlish period from verb ensignar "to engrave, carve".

examples.vernacular: L'entisau un traccart ny bosc entr dou casn.
examples.english: He set a trap in the woods between two oaks.

et: Old Borlish, verbal derivation from tis, tes "taut, stretched". This descends from synonymous tēnsus in Latin, past participle of tendō "I stretch; I strive". The senses pertaining to traps and weaponry, first attested in the fourteenth century, derive from the action of arming a trap or crossbow by placing a string under tension. More general mechanical senses are attested from the seventeenth century, along with the reflexive usage.

examples.vernacular: L'indrec de my sour es se trovant entr hugt e gavisc.
examples.english: My sister's charity is going from strength to strength.

et: idiom from the fifteenth century (Kigman), literally "between happiness and joy". Used primarily with negative valence (portraying the necessary choice as an imposition) until the nineteenth century, at which the latter sense begin to be attested.mn

examples.vernacular: L'entrcollocq indiglað se cou evolgað.
examples.english: The unredacted interview got leaked.

et: 19th-century coinage from entr- "between, among" and collocq "conversation", from collocquar "to converse". This reflects Latin colloquor "I discuss, speak with".

examples.vernacular: Dou alumn pagl ny preu rig s'entrjeirn.
examples.english: Two blond schoolkids at the front piped up.

et: Middle Borlish, from now-archaic jair "throw" and prefix entr- "between" or directly from Latin intericiō "I throw between" (with remodelling after the Borlish words). Nowadays the word is mostly seen in its reflexive senses.

examples.vernacular: Jo broiðau l'entrlaçour coll'outrley.
examples.english: I mixed up the scammer and the outlaw.

et: nineteenth century, borrowed (probably via intermedaries) from Sicilia ntrlazzaturi "swindler, racketeer". This is an agentive derivation from the noun ntrlazzu "scam, racket", which reflects Latin inter- "between" and laqueus "noose". Specialisation to politics probably occurred before the word entered Borlish, although there was no shortage of corruption in contempory governance on Borland to inspire the shift.

examples.vernacular: Un hour alcheðr lor porreu nos entrquïr.
examples.english: Another hour and we can take a break.

et: late Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin interquiēscō "I rest briefly", adapted to native prefix entr- "between" and verb quïr "to put out, turn off".

examples.vernacular: Y soucorsour all'entrquïscoir dy piscin teyen catr.
examples.english: Four lifeguards were in the pool's break room.

et: mid-twentieth century, place derivation (using the suffix -oir < -ōrium in Medieval Latin) from the verb entrquïr "pause, stop work".

examples.vernacular: Tag enverimmað con mandrin occeyeu ty quanga.
examples.english: Your secretary was poisoned with cyanide-laced tea.

ge: things one has a stake in

examples.vernacular: Jo n'ay scið l'eç scoclet epu plu pascr.
examples.english: I can't stop eating these mini chocolates.

et: modern borrowing from French épu "express, direct, unhindered, available, at hand", first seen in Borlish in the names of imported shopfronts such as Panier, whose Panier Épu establishments were much smaller but offered better deals than the main line.

from Old Borlish eredme "alignment, order, regularity", of uncertain origin. The word has traditionally been connected to Latin rhythmus "rhythm, cadence", ignoring the phonetic problems and the lack of cognates in other Romance languages, mostly due to a dearth of other options. Neither a hypothetical Old English *ġerǣdedōm "readiness" nor Old Norse *ǫrrǫðsemi "straight-line-ness" have been much credited.

examples.vernacular: J'ereðmfeyau l'orlosc ne traiscn a tre minut lon theu.
examples.english: I accidentally set the pocketwatch three minutes late.

et: Middle Borlish derivative of ereðm "symmetry; coincidence; happenstance" with the factitive suffix -feyar < Latin -ficō "I make _".

examples.vernacular: Jamay n'a y Caðer ne Pieðr Roug erref se caut.
examples.english: The Redstone Chair has never been recovered.

et: Middle Borlish, deverbal from errevir "rescue". In early use the term often had religious connotations, referring to the redemption of the world by Jesus Christ.

examples.vernacular: M'orruð il ain l'oc sorty erreut cos pernix.
examples.english: I think they really turned this party around.

et: from Old Borlish erevre, ereveir, from Latin ēripiō "I rescue, save, deliver, set free". Some forms show a conjugation shift from Classical ēripere to *ēripēre (compare cavir < *capēre < capere). Cognate with Barcelon erebre "to protect, guard".

examples.vernacular: Gehennant ig nos ayau porc errevour tost y dou por y fest.
examples.english: Embrassingly we'd both made pork redeemer for the feast.

ge: mix of breadcrumbs, wine, herbs and chestnuts
et: descendant of Old Borlish erevor "saviour", agentive derivation of erevre, erever "save" (which gives modern errevir "rescue"). This comes from Latin ēripiō "I set free; I remove", related to rapiō "I grab, seize". The term has been applied to Christ along with similar sauvour, reðentor "saviour" since the tenth century. In the last sense referring to a preparation of meat now often served around Christmas on Borland (although historically it, minus the chestnuts, was usually eaten on Easter Sunday).

examples.vernacular: Y trevold de Docquerl es l'ersteigon dy commouð Futurist.
examples.english: Docquerl's novel is the pinnacle of the Futurist movement.

et: originally a term of art, borrowed from Saxon ersteigon "rise, climb, ascension", a noun from steige "climb". This properly referred to the events before the climax, but by the time of borrowing the shift in meaning had become entrenched. The term was used in more general contexts in Borlish by the mid-nineteenth century.

a 17C borrowing from Vascon escapat “adventure” < “escape, breakout”, past participle of escapar “to escape”. This in turn comes from Vulgar Latin excappō “I escape”, literally “I go out of the cloak” (ex cappō).

examples.vernacular: Y clocq parey l'hour con un scard d'euxon.
examples.english: The clock keeps time with a piece of quartz.

et: compare Scholastic Latin euxō "quartz" and Malchassian Greek εὔξώνας • euxṓnas "quartz", both first attested in the tweflth century. Traditionally connected to early Ancient Greek ἐΰξοος • eúxoos "well-polished" and the verb ξύω • xúō "scrape, polish", though this theory has some diachronic and semantic issues. The adjective is attested in Epic literature but no later, and moreover the root pertains very specifically to wood (being related to ξόανον xóanon "wooden image" and ξύλα • xúla "timber").
Old Borlish < Old French < Late Latin episcopus < Ancient Greek ἐπίσκοπος

examples.vernacular: Y sar pistol ren evolganç incoïbr.
examples.english: The internet makes leaks inevitable.

et: noun derivation from verb evolgar "publicise, promulgate, leak".
borrowing from Scholastic Latin ēvulgō "I publish among the people", itself from vulgus "the common people".

examples.vernacular: I porta un min de derijon excellent.
examples.english: She had a look of undisguised scorn.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin excellēns "surpassing, eminent", the present participle of verb excellō "I rise, project, excel". The extension of the word both to general noteworthiness and to obviousness had occurred by the eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: L'exedr n'a alcun vivirc por asseïr.
examples.english: The waiting room has nowhere to sit.

et: an early modern borrowing from Latin exedra "discussion hall with seating", itself from Greek ἐξἕδρα "an exterior sitting place". In the last senses it is attested from the nineteenth century, originally in reference to such rooms in train stations.
from the sixteenth century, taken from the Latin stage direction in theatrical scripts exeunt "they leave", used as a noun "act of leaving (a stage, and metaphorically any situation)".

examples.vernacular: Il aun ig rekestað jo faç exeunt lon massant.
examples.english: They've asked me to bow out without a fuss.

examples.vernacular: Jo's cuidant cos nuvr a my dois extollir.
examples.english: I've been meaning to upgrade my phone.

et: 16C, borrowing from Latin extollō "I elevate, erect, praise". Extension to promotion in a company occurred in the nineteenth century; to technology in the twentieth.

examples.vernacular: L'oc detaxion es aphlox psolic effumant com fæx ou?
examples.english: Is this reaction producing waste carbon monoxide?

et: modern borrowing from Scholastic Latin faex "unwanted product of a chemical reaction", a specialised use of Classical faex "sediment, brine, rouge, dregs". Extension from scientific usage is attested from the eighteenth century, and its use as an insult is seen soon afterwards.
idiom first attested in the poetry of Kigman (15C), literally "to make the heart beat"
15C, royal house name Falcquad, earlier Falquald, with a claimed origin in  Old Norse folkvaldr "ruler, lit. people-wielder"
Old Borlish, from now-obsolete fam "foam", from Old English
Latin familiāris "pertaining to the household"; adjective derived from famigl "family".
Old Borlish, verbal derivation from now-obsolete adjective fangle "opportunistic, shrewd, moving forward, going ahead", from Old English fangol
borrowed in the Old Borlish period from Old English faran "go, travel; fare"

examples.vernacular: J'ignoy hayennaç assignar, ma farau.
examples.english: I forgot to set homework, no big deal.

et: early Modern Borlish, a clipping of the phrase (still occasionally seen in full) tal farau nos "such is life", literally "so we fare". The expression originally represented commiseration (a sense which it partially retains as a self-directed expletive); in its modern senses it is seen from the nineteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Jo save l'oc caum contene un fardig d'aloud.
examples.english: I knew this piece contained a lute solo.

et: seventeenth century, originally in the musical sense. Borrowed from a continental language, likely Vascon fardig(a) or Portingale fardigo/a "solo, played alone". These derive from a derivative of the Arabic root فَرْد · fard "alone, single, solitary". Extension to non-musical contexts is seen from the late nineteenth century.
Etymology: from archaic verb faughar "to mow, cut down" (overtaken in the modern language by tondr "shear, cut, mow"). This is a derivative of faug "sickle, scythe", from synonymous falx in Latin.
Old Borlish < Old French < Classical German

examples.vernacular: Y majon terraun set nell'oc feurðon.
examples.english: There'll be seven houses in this decare.

et: originally in the first sense, part of the traditional system of area measures used on Borland along with the acr "acre" (also called the jur in the east). The word reflects Old Borlish feorðon, forðin "rood", from Old English féorðing or Old Norrish [Norse] fiórðungr "quarter, fourth part". The word was redefined in the nineteenth century with the adoption of dime [metric] units, being the numerically closest measure available (compare the Turk دونوم • dönüm or the Nivoner [Japanese] タン • tan, units which were similarly adjusted to this new dime measure).
Old Borlish < Latin. reflects Latin fīgō "I fasten, fix".

examples.vernacular: Jo's eut may hellinar a tu pos figurar.
examples.english: I've been through more than you can imagine.

examples.vernacular: Nossy foyail es fis e scein lau pre yonoscon.
examples.english: We're out of petrol in the middle of nowhere.

et: past participle of figr "set down, place down, lay" used also as the past participle of figr a "finish, finish off, complete, stop" (where perhaps fis la would be more regular). In the sense of having run out of something, the word is seen from the sixteenth century; in the last senses it is seen from the seventeenth.
Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin flacceō "I am weak".
noun from flagitar, or directly from Latin flāgitātiō

examples.vernacular: Jo no poð lou affaçar pre vienn y flottisc.
examples.english: I can't confront them until reinforcements arrive.

et: from fol "mad" with the pejorative suffix -astr
derivative of follar "step" with pejorative suffix -astr

examples.vernacular: Ðe disrn empley broucar n'un foncçondry.
examples.english: They said they had jobs at an agency.

et: eighteenth century, derivation via the gestalt-forming suffix -ry from noun foncçon "purpose, use". In turn this was borrowed from Latin fūnctiō "performance, execution (of a task)". The governmental sense is original; in commercial use compare similarly-formed words like vessondry "clothier" and govondry "canteen". In espionage the word is seen from the twentieth century, originally as in-house slang.
Old Borlish < Early Medieval Latin fortia "force, violence"
nineteenth century, a derivative of forç "strength, power" < Medieval Latin fortia "force, violence" with the suffix -oir denoting location (or occasionally tools) < synonymous -tōrium in Latin.
Old Borlish < Old French < Vulgar Latin
either from Vulgar Latin formīcus, or directly from Latin formīca “ant”

examples.vernacular: Ah, j'ay formig me caut – jo seray dormið sull'oc braç!
examples.english: Ow, I've got pins and needles – I must have slept on my arm!

et: literally “to get ants (on yourself)”; the first word either from Vulgar Latin formīcus, or directly from Latin formīca “ant”. The verb from capiō “I seize, take”.
Old French < Old Dutch < Classical German
Old Borlish < Old French < Old Dutch < Classical German
via Old Borlish fouȝl from Latin folium "leaf".

examples.vernacular: Y fougl pavarrot l'evolgaurn prell'aubon.
examples.english: The tabloids got the story out overnight.

et: a particular small coin used on Borland in the early modern period and reintroduced with a different denomination in the late twentieth period. The word descends from synonymous papāver in Latin, of unknown further origin.
Old Borlish, from now-obsolete foyar "to dig up" < fodiō "I dig up"
Old Borlish extension of foy "fire" < focus "hearth" with the pejorative suffix -aç < -āceus "shaped like".

examples.vernacular: Cay tell'yoc veram un praxitel foyaçant.
examples.english: Your husband is truly a masterful sculptor.

et: present participle of foyaçar "glare, shine brightly, dazzle; show off, flaunt". The word appears in both approving and disapproving contexts from as early as it is attested.
Middle Borlish, a derivation from foyaç "glare, intense light; gaudiness, extravagance".

examples.vernacular: Comoscon fig mesnoçon foyer?
examples.english: How do misconceptions take hold?

et: Old Borlish < Latin. a direct descendant of Vulgar Latin focārium "hearth", an extension of synonymous focus in Classical Latin.
idiom from the early modern period, literally "to set (a) hearth down".

examples.vernacular: Jo groça y stoir geoscopic de my fraðr.
examples.english: I envied my brother's globe-trotting tales.

examples.vernacular: Con ðigl eu nos y dou port rent frasterrem.
examples.english: We've reinforced both doors with planks.

et: direct descendant via Old Borlish fra(i)sre "ash tree, ash wood, spear" from synonymous frāxinus in Latin. Ash wood has been used for spear shafts since pre-Classical times. As an adjective the word is seen from the fourteenth century; in its specific slang sense it is likely at most fifty years old.

examples.vernacular: J'ay hougr y fren de my rað sein inovrant.
examples.english: I'm worried my bike's brakes are broken.

et: originally in the first sense, via Old Borlish directly from Latin frēnum "bridle, harness, curb, bit". The word was extended metaphorically some centuries before it was reapplied to physical devices on other vehicles. In music the word is calqued from Willem Dutch afrem "slow down (imp.)", potentially also due to phonetic resemblance.

examples.vernacular: Teyen catorç frend ag tarn candon caye l'occijon.
examples.english: The inn had fourteen guests at the time of the murder.

et: from Old Borlish frend, fremd, borrowed from Old English fremde "strange, foreign" (for the development of the coda compare hand "sex" < OE hǣmed "sex, cohabitation").
Middle Borlish < Latin, noun derivation from frequent
Middle Borlish < Old French < Old Dutch < Classical German
past participle of frigsar "to fry, excite, arouse"
Old Borlish reflecting Late Latin frīxō "I fry", a secondary formation from Classical frīgō based on the perfect stem.

examples.vernacular: Jo soccoðoy y furtiviscour par y frigsment.
examples.english: I lost my tail in the commotion.

et: noun formed from frigsar "to fry; to excite, arouse, rile up". This reflects Late Latin frīxō "I fry", a secondary formation from Classical frīgō based on the perfect stem.

examples.vernacular: Jo's y jarry frottant tras un demy d'hour.
examples.english: I've been scrubbing dishes for half an hour.

et: from Old Borlish, borrowed from (or possibly the source of) Old French frotter "rub, polish". This is in either case of uncertain origin, but is generally thought to reflect Latin participle frictus of fricō "I rub, chafe". Musical senses are attested from the Middle Borlish period.
a borrowing from Latin frūnīscor "I enjoy", which was used non-Classically as an intransitive verb.

examples.vernacular: I port jamay allors de fustagn ou?
examples.english: Does he wear anything but jeans?

et: from Middle Borlish, borrowed from contemporary French fustagne "twilled, coarse fabric", from Medieval Latin fūstāneum or from some Romance cognate. The Latin is of uncertain origin, perhaps related to fūstis "stick, club".
Old Borlish gaz, from Borland Celtic gats- "she-dog", cognate with synonymous gast in Brythonic.

examples.vernacular: J'ay gaheç vleutað calun my vestið contenent.
examples.english: I've forgotten which locker my clothes are in.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing via Vascon gaheç "lockbox" from Arabic قَفِيز • (qafīz) "a measure of dry volume".

examples.vernacular: Jo stima noc se sceus aðief gajannar.
examples.english: I didn't think the prize was enough.

et: presumably (along with noun gajan "victory, triumph") via Old French from a Frankish descendant of Classical German vaethanō "I hunt, pursue". However, the Borlish apparently reflects a Late Latin *vadianō "I win, earn" as opposed to the form *vadaniō which must be the etymon for e.g. Tuscan guadagnare "earn" and Norman wain "win". Attested in the last sense from as early as the fourteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Postulað es l'oc roc vin d'un autr gallaið.
examples.english: There's speculation that this rock comes from another galaxy.

et: from late Old Borlish galaix, galais "the Milky Way", learned borrowing from synonymous Latin galaxiās and Ancient Greek (κύκλος) γᾰλᾰξῐ́ᾱς, literally "milky circle". Altered in the early Middle Borlish period under the influence of laið "milk", from Latin lac, lactem "milk" (or possibly from a Borland Kelt form; compare Cambrick łaeth "milk").
Old Borlish < Late Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: L'oc compostion de pont parmet coval menn gamblas apar.
examples.english: This bridge design allows horses to draw barges past it.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from contemporaneous Kentish gamblass "barge", itself extracted from Welsh łong gamblas "canal ship". It is presumed that the first component łong "ship" was treated in Kentish by folk-etymology as the adjective "long", in a reversal of its Latin origin in (navis) longa "longship".
Old Borlish < Old French < Classical German

apparently borrowed in the Middle Borlish period from Welsh gap "hole; patch, a distinct section of some larger whole". This in turn was taken from Old Norse gap "empty space, gap, chasm", deverbal from gapa "to gape, be open wide".

examples.vernacular: L'oç astuçour es gapiscent par toð y lasc.
examples.english: That mentor keeps turning up in the movie.

examples.vernacular: Cant scandr jo care garaf idone.
examples.english: As I climbed I looked for convenient handholds.

et: from Middle Borlish garaf "grip, handle", a borrowing from Portingale garafa "handle", of indeterminate origin. Either an alteration of earlier grafio, garfio "hook", from Latin graphium "stylus, pen", or else borrowed from Andalus Arabic جَارْفَا‎ (gárfá) "handful, claw".
Old Borlish < Old French < Classical German
Old Borlish < Old French < Medieval Latin < Frankish
Old Borlish, from Latin gaudeō "I make merry".
deverbal from gavir "enjoy, feel happy", which descends directly from Latin gaudeō "I rejoice, make merry".

examples.vernacular: Vos vouð uncos special accommettr por y gaviscenç ou?
examples.english: Are you going to do anything special for the festivities?

et: sixteenth century, a noun formation from the verb gavir "rejoice, have fun". Originally the word often referred specifically to the celebration of religious holidays or feast days.

from Middle French géhenne "humiliation, punishment". This reflects Old French gehine "reprisal" and gehir "to confess" (both from Frankish), respelt under the influence of unrelated Géhenne "Gehenna, Hell".

examples.vernacular: Mell'aldr son magn gehennant.
examples.english: My folks are so embarrassing.

et: borrowed along with noun gehen "embarrassment" from Middle French géhenne "humiliation, punishment". This reflects Old French gehine "reprisal" and gehir "to confess" (both from Frankish), respelt under the influence of unrelated Géhenne "Gehenna, Hell".
from Vascon gemma "gem, jewel; unit of currency", after a particular gold coin embossed with a logo in the shape of a diamond.

examples.vernacular: Nuvr soð vos melle faint con y gentagl.
examples.english: You've been mixing with riffraff recently.

et: Middle Borlish derivative of gent "people, nation" and -agl, an unproductive instrumental or collective suffix. The noun descends straightforwardly from Latin gēns "clan, tribe, people"; the affix from Latin thematic vowel -ā- and suffix -cula "tool, instrument". Attestatations of gentācula (with a first-declension variant of the suffix) "common people" in Scholastic Latin are likely modelled after the vernacular Romance forms.

examples.vernacular: Jo groça y stoir geoscopic de my fraðr.
examples.english: I envied my brother's globe-trotting tales.

dv: pertaining to the maritime explorations of the Intertwining Century following the Novomundine Landfall
et: early modern formation as if from Ancient Greek γεωσκοπῐκός "world-beholding", originally in the last sense. Metaphorical extension of the term is seen from the nineteenth century.

a borrowing via synomous guèvre in Parisian from Welsh guivr "wire". In turn this appears to have been borrowed from Old English wīr "metal thread", likely influenced in form by guevr "amber" due to its electrical properties.

examples.vernacular: Din noc divertið par gevrment.
examples.english: Don't be distracted by minutiae.

et: derivation with the gestalt suffix -ment < Latin -mentum from the noun gevr "electrical wire". In metaphorical use the term is seen from the mid-twentieth century.
Old Borlish < Late Latin < Ancient Greek < Prakrit < Dravidian

examples.vernacular: Com voum nos se corrir pall'oc glonscel?
examples.english: How will we get out of this mess?

et: originally in the first sense only, from Old Borlish glomscel "yarn, tangle". This descends from Vulgar Latin glomiscellus "ball of thread", a popular diminutive of Classical glomus.

examples.vernacular: Jo parmanoy a hoissar, y glouç seponent.
examples.english: I kept playing, ignoring the giggles.

et: Middle Borlish deverbal from now-obsolete gloçar "cluck; chuckle" (now usually glouç fair "to do giggles"). This reflects Vulgar Latin glōciāre "to cluck", a regularised conjugation class variant of synonymous glōcīre in Classical Latin. As an interjection the word is attested from the eighteenth century and is now somewhat old-fashioned or facetious.
Old Borlish < Old French < Classical German
via Welsh from one of the Bamackon languages of West Africa (cf. Wolof guru "kola nut").

examples.vernacular: Jo fon got ag mar cay dou meis.
examples.english: I've got nothing done for two months.

et: idiom attested in various forms since the sixteenth century, and in the modern form since the eighteenth, literally "to spill a drop of the sea". Likely at first a reference to events in a burger play of the period. Extension to the last sense is attested only from 1968 but may be much older.

examples.vernacular: T'orruð ou le day gouth cosogr mey?
examples.english: Do you think I'm a rebound for him?

et: late nineteenth century, during an early instance of the many physical exercise fads of the modern period. The term was borrowed from Welsh gwth "push, thrust, shove". The metaphorical uses (principally in gouth dar "to make a comeback, to attempt to get over someone by dating; lit. to give pushups") are seen from the 1970s.

examples.vernacular: Nossy dottr es melle faint entr y govey galant.
examples.english: Our daughter's hobnobbing with the smart set.

et: Middle Borlish, borrowed from contemporary Kentish or Norman covey, govee "brood". This is a substantivisation of the past participle of cover "to brood (an egg)", the regular descendant of Latin cubō "I lie down; I incubate" (from whose present tense Borlish cair "to fall" takes its suppletive past tense forms). Extension from venery to other groups of animals is seen from the seventeenth century, and to groups of people from the nineteenth.

examples.vernacular: Te stou moutessem y govon oglar.
examples.english: You need to oil the hinges more.

et: originally in the first sense, the descendant of Old Borlish govon "hinge, tenon, pin". This reflects Vulgar Latin gōfō "nail, peg, dowel", a variant of synonymous gomphus in Classical Latin. The extension to a generic point of rotation (and from there to all other senses) had occurred by the Revitalist period.

examples.vernacular: J'acatau dou quignou de nossy govondry.
examples.english: I bought two pastries from our canteen.

et: Middle Borlish govonry "inn, eatery", place derivation from now-obsolete govon "innkeeper, barkeeper". This appears to descend directly from Latin caupō "tradesman, innkeeper". It specialisation to small eateries and counters within organisations takes place first in a military context during the eighteenth century.
a borrowing via another Romance language from Latin grabātus "cot, pallet, camp bed", from Greek.

examples.vernacular: J'addoceu my sour d'ig j'er grabattour parsiscent.
examples.english: I told my sister I was training to be a paramedic.

et: 20C, agentive derivation from grabat "stretcher, gurney; emergency medical transport". Transfer from the military context to peacetime healthcare is attested from the 1950s.

examples.vernacular: Il se ponden a plaç mi ny rout, graðleur e donaçon rovant.
examples.english: They were standing in the street asking for money and volunteers.

et: from Old Borlish (a) grad liure “freely, voluntarily”, literally “with free will”, from Latin grātus “will” and līber “free, unrestricted”.
from Latin crassitūdō. Synchronically analysable as gras "thick" and -tum "-ness".
Old Borlish < Old English / Old Norse

examples.vernacular: Y cociner le tirau des un croun de greim.
examples.english: The cook took it out of an apron pocket.

et: direct descendant via Old Borlish from Latin gremium "lap; bosom; embrace". The term has been used in tailoring from the thirteenth century. The metaphorical sense may continue the similar usage in Latin, but is more likely to be an independent innovation of the early modern period.

examples.vernacular: Alcheðr my paðr ençau a grindr n'Avril.
examples.english: My dad's been dating again since April.

et: from Old Borlish grindre, greindr "sift, separate, allocate, rank", which reflects a Vulgar Latin form *grēniō, grēnere "I sift, sieve, distinguish between". Despite the formal differences, by the semantics we can deduce that this is an altered form of Classical Latin cernō "I sift (etc.)" modelled on the perfect stem (cf. crēvī "I sifted", crētus "sifted, separated"). The initial voicing is sporadic, but shared with related noun grivr < cribrum "sieve".

examples.vernacular: My trelamn a blad gringlau tout a coup.
examples.english: My house of cards collapsed all at once.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from French gringueler "to tumble, roll down", itself from Dutch cring "circle, ring".
Old Borlish < Old French < Frankish < Classical German

examples.vernacular: I rob y parol bogr grivlað.
examples.english: She doesn't mince words.

et: verbal derivation in the Old Borlish period from grivle "sieve" (modern grivr). This noun descends from Vulgar Latin criblum, a dissimilated form of cribrum "sieve".
borrowing via synonymous French grivouiller from Willem criblen "scratch".

examples.vernacular: Quippe porra tu noc my grivougl leir.
examples.english: Of course you can't read my scrawl.

et: deverbal noun from grivoglar "scrawl, scribble, write illegibly". The second sense is attested from the early twentieth century.

examples.vernacular: Y bourgmer ag Groin groin posc y decret.
examples.english: A Coruña's mayor grumbles about the act.

et: from Old Borlish groȝnar, groȝndir "grunt", reflecting Vulgar variants of Classical Latin grunniō "I grunt". To describe sounds made by people the word is attested as early as the Old Borlish period. The expected modern spelling grognar was once sporadically used but may have been avoided on aesthetic grounds (compare genoil "knee" < genoȝl in Old Borlish).

examples.vernacular: Jo passau un ðorof de groun jos l'odysse.
examples.english: I passed a gaggle of teens by the cinema.

et: Old borrowed with the first sense in the mid-twentieth century from Willem Dutch gróng "adolescence; unruly young person", cognate with growing in English. Applied to all youths of a similar age since the 1970s, the word quickly also became a mild insult describing stereotypical teen behaviours. In the final senses it is only attested in the last twenty years.

examples.vernacular: Intermane pegntur d'un joun doncel eð un guy.
examples.english: It was a painting of a young girl and a guinea pig.

et: clipping of fuller laprot guy (/laˈprɔt ˈgaj/ [lɐˈpʀɔt ˈgaj]), literally "guy-rabbit". In its derogatory senses it is attested from the late eighteenth century; as a general term for young men, from the mid-twentieth.
Old Borlish < Old French < Old Dutch

examples.vernacular: Nos s'usareu l'ignifex posc y kenonaut arra dou gyr may complið.
examples.english: We will run out of oxygen when the ship has completed two more orbits.

et: 16C, from Latin gȳrus “circle, circuit”, probably via French gyre; from Greek γῦρος (gûros) “circle, ring”. Predominantly in technical contexts and in translations of astronomical texts until the success of Elsebeth Sneider's Durgh'nen Shorzen Shouer (Through a Glass, Darkly) in 1795, and the ensuing decades-long fashion for voidtales.

examples.vernacular: Cosogr il taussan men an haçot a maus.
examples.english: The set cost less than a bunch of bananas.

et: Middle Borlish diminutive of haç "bundle", borrowed in nautical use from synonymous haç in Vascon. This reflects Latin fascis "packet, package; burden, load".
compound of hades 'the underworld' and clað
Old Borlish < Old English haguþorn or Old Norse hagþorn

examples.vernacular: Nell'oc molin jo ploug jonc vars haidy.
examples.english: In this factory I process cane into rum.

examples.vernacular: Jo fey rongelon sur my hamac fin a quelt.
examples.english: I dozed in my bunk until dinner.

et: originally in the second sense, borrowed via Morrove Arabic همك · hamaca and French hamac from Tainow [Taino] hamaca "hammock". Extended in two directions, to various cramped sleeping arrangements aboard ships as well as to other swinging objects. The word's use in physics is attested from the nineteenth century.
borrowing from Old French hamelot < hamel < ham, cognate with "home"
from hamblot "hamlet, village" with the pejorative suffix -aç.
from Vulgar Latin hanca "hip", from a German source related to ankle in English.

examples.vernacular: J'eye sauf a aïr y hapr yent.
examples.english: I'd nearly got all the groceries.

et: direct descendant of Old Borlish happle "fruit, collectively; yield of a fruit harvest" (since displaced by native frugt < Latin frūctus), borrowed from Old English æppel "apple, fruit; sphere". The appearance of the initial h- is unexplained, but may be a hypercorrection; at this point /h/ was absent in native Borlish vocabulary and was being reintroduced via Germanic loanwords. Its modern sense is influenced by the compound haprman "greengrocer; (later) wholesaler".

examples.vernacular: Un bougr insuet vien de laurar cas y haprman.
examples.english: A new guy's just started at the grocer's.

examples.vernacular: Jo parceveu my cigl er se portant cos harif.
examples.english: I noticed my beau was acting weird.

et: borrowed in the late Middle Borlish period from Vascon harif (cf. Leon or Portingale harivo) "misshapen, grotesque; weird, uncanny". This in turn comes from Arabic خَرِب • kharib "ruined, destroyed". The term gained its conventionalised usage in speculative fiction in the late nineteenth century, popularised by the works of Nan.
via Drengot French from Old Norrish hernest, a compound of herr "army" and nest "provisions". The word was restricted to military contexts until the sixteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Nos harneisaum graivet e gant.
examples.english: We put shinpads and gloves on.

et: Middle Borlish verbal derivation from harneis "equipment, gear, tackle".

examples.vernacular: Me soupren ig ja n'ay jo l'ec harvougl pars.
examples.english: I'm surprised I haven't lost my earbuds yet.

et: originally in the first sense, from Old Borlish horvoȝl, erveȝl "earwig". Thought to be partially from Vulgar Latin forficula "small scissors", diminutive of forfex "scissors", and partially from Old English ēarwicgel "earwig". The development of the initial consonant is unexplained, but compare Vascon horveix "earwig". Folklore connecting the insect to ear-burrowing influenced the modern senses, first attested in the twentieth century.

examples.vernacular: "Hau a toð gent," dis y giðour quaucant.
examples.english: "Hi, everyone," said the hurried guide.

et: in the first senses, a continuation of Middle Borlish hauð! "hello, good day", literally "health". The word hauð "health", now archaic, was borrowed in the Old Borlish period from synonymous hǣlþ in contemporary English. The form and informality of the greeting have been influenced by the last sense, which is probably of onomatopeic origin.

examples.vernacular: Lorry haubrojoranç er speut bannið.
examples.english: Their advertisement was swiftly banned.

dv: communication whose purpose is to inform or influence customers about products or services; an instance of advertising something
et: seventeenth-century coinage from verb haubrjorar "to announce, to herald, to make public", itself a derivation from noun haubrjour "herald, town crier, one whose job is to announce things publicly". This had shifted from the sense "scout, sentry, lookout; omen, advance warning", in which form it was borrowed from Old French herbergeor "one sent ahead (of a military camp)".
Shifted from the Old Borlish sense "scout, sentry, lookout; omen, advance warning", in which form it was borrowed from Old French herbergeor "one sent ahead (of a military camp)".
Old Borlish, borrowed from Old Norse hǫfn "harbour".

examples.vernacular: Jo montau ag tabr e clignau my bos yert a haut.
examples.english: I got up on the table and fired my gun into the air.

examples.vernacular: L'a acavað a casc batman haval allaçar.
examples.english: She's managed to get every action figure.

et: from Middle Borlish haval "doll, puppet" originally in southern dialects around Pentrose, a borrowing from contemporary Cambrick haval "likeness, image; doll, effigy". In adjectival use potentially attested from as early as the sixteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Y joun ern haval fayent ny gardin.
examples.english: The children were playing pretend in the garden.

et: idiom from the sixteenth century, literally "do dolls". The noun haval "doll, puppet" was originally a southern dialect term out of Pentrose, borrowed in the Middle Borlish period from Welsh haval "likeness, image; doll, effigy". Extension out of the realm of childhood play is seen from the nineteenth century.
Middle Borlish, borrowed from synonymous haiena in Vascon. This reflects Latin facienda "that which is to be done".

examples.vernacular: Alcun hom nil nis mettr ag hayennaç çaf.
examples.english: No-one will bother doing the extra homework.

et: pejorative derivation from hayen "task, duty, piece of work".

examples.vernacular: Jo's eut may hellinar a tu pos figurar.
examples.english: I've been through more than you can imagine.

et: verbal derivation from hellin "cork; plug, bung", itself borrowed from Vascon or Leon hellino "cork (substance); bottle stopper". This is a sufficiently-early loan from Arabic فَلِّين <fallīn> "cork" that it exhibits the f > h sound shift characteristic of northern Spanish languages.
Old Borlish borrowing from synonymous hēlā in Old English, of onomatopoeic origin.
pejorative derivative of hellovar "to call out in greeting"
agentive from hellovaçar "to make a loud noise to attract attention"
clipped from agr heredian "heredian acid" from Latin heres "heir".
a Scholastic Latin derivation of heres "heir, heiress".
from Germanic, cf. Old English hearma "ermine".

examples.vernacular: Il aun heu equal cos stoniscent, ða meðes jammel.
examples.english: They look astonishingly similar, even for twins.

et: from Old Borlish hiu "form, appearance", borrowed from Old English hiew "shape, appearance, colour". Specialisation to the appearance and comportment of people occurred in the Middle Borlish period.
Old Borlish < Old English, Medieval Latin

examples.vernacular: Nos entisaum gas, l'aye min hieratic eð intradugbr.
examples.english: We locked eyes, his face set and unreadable.

et: borrowed directly via Scholastic Latin from Greek ἱερατικός • hieratikós "priestly", from the root ῐ̔ερός • hĭerós "sacred". In extended use from the seventeenth century, in parallel with other languages like Vascon, presumably in reference to the stereotypical manner and bearing of priests.
Middle Borlish derivation from historic "historical" or histoir "history".

examples.vernacular: Jo le stim uncos entr y vajot de star un hivocin.
examples.english: I find it's one of the perks of being a wallflower.

et: from Vascon hivocin or Scholastic Latin hivocīnus, each having come via Morrove Arabic from a Mayattan language, plausibly Gish 'ibach "armadillo". In the metaphorical sense the word is attested from the early twentieth century, after the nickname of a character in popular children's book Figl a Fojon "Children of the Quarry".
thought to be of onomatopoeic origin.

examples.vernacular: Y bourg deleu l'oc hoðic ne souc d'un courstray.
examples.english: The town fired this councillor due to an affair.

et: descendant of Old Borlish houðic, hoðinc "village leader; esp. leader of a Norse settlement in the north of Borland". This is a borrowing from Old Norse hǫfðingi "chief, lord", which is a derivation of hǫfuð "head". The term was first used for elected positions in town or city councils in the fifteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Hour alcot es tu y toriot hoissant?
examples.english: How long have you been playing the torriot?

et: from Middle Borlish hoisçar "whistle, flout", probably of onomatopoeic origin. Otherwise, perhaps a borrowing from Old English hwistlian "to whistle". Its subsequent semantic development is unclear but mirrored in e.g. Dutch fluiten "to play the flute, to scorn, to scoff".

examples.vernacular: L'a heu allagherrem an ivan ayent hopr receut.
examples.english: He looked happier than a kid with new toys.

et: from Middle Borlish hopr "tool, instrument; equipment, gear", from synonymous hople in Old Borlish. This is a borrowing via Old French from Medieval Latin hopla "gear, equipment; tackle", from Greek ὅπλᾰ • (hópla) "tackle; weaponry". Used for children's toys from the sixteenth century, for laughable people since the eighteenth, and in the last senses from the twentieth.
Middle Borlish < Dutch < Polish < Russian < Comain

examples.vernacular: Jo luy hortaminau acceir all'empley.
examples.english: I urged him to accept the job.

et: from Scholastic Latin hortāminō "I exhort, urge", a non-classical verbal derivation of hortāmen "incitement, encouragement". This comes from deponent verb hortor "I encourage". Originally in legal use, but seen in general contexts since the seventeenth century.
borrowing from Norman French houille "stone coal", probably from Frankish hucila "pile mound".

examples.vernacular: Hour alcot es tu y toriot hoissant?
examples.english: How long have you been playing the torriot?

examples.vernacular: Y barvier hox sy cloðour sur y taisson.
examples.english: The shepherd sets his terrier on the badger.

et: early Modern Borlish, allied (along with interjection hox "attack!") with Saxon hoxen, Bavarn huchsen and Carnish huschken, all meaning roughly the same thing. Possibly just a onomatopoetic formation, but the formal similarity of Crovatian huškati "provoke" is also suggestive.
from Old Borlish huȝt, a borrowing from Old English hyht "hope".

examples.vernacular: J'enveyau sy cigl risc aye un hundy a catr roum.
examples.english: I envied his rich boyfriend's four-room set.

et: nineteenth century, borrowed from Welsh hundy "bedchamber; (by extension) hotel room". This is a compound of hun "sleep" and ty "house". Initially confined to upmarket use, the word was extended to the university setting around the turn of the twentieth century. Compare roughly contemporaneous randy "apartment" < Welsh rhandy "wing (of a building); apartment".
Middle Borlish, onomatopoeia, Old English; from the thirteenth century in diverse forms, likely onomatopoeic but influenced in some way by Old English hrūxlian "to make noise".

examples.vernacular: Y madarc yeme lucr de huyaç.
examples.english: The lawman was taking bribes.

et: nineteenth-century coinage originating in Pentrose slang, a derivative of local dialect term huy "gang, mob, syndicate" with the pejorative suffix -aç < Latin -āceus "resembling". The noun huy goes back to the fifteenth century, and is a borrowing from Kernish chui "crowd, rabble" (cf. Cambrick why "movement").
Middle Borlish < Old Borlish < Latin < Ancient Greek
conflation of Latin īdūs "ides" and Arabic 'īd "holiday"

examples.vernacular: My sour ignoy vondrous alcot sta y pegl meyon luy teissuð.
examples.english: My sister kindly overlooked how ugly the hat I knitted her was.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin ignōscō "forgive, pardon", perhaps influenced in some uses by similar-looking ignorar "not know, fail to perceive". Its conjugation is modelled on connoscr "to know of, to be familiar with".

examples.vernacular: Il ern l'imascry descorçant ag cogn jagerrem.
examples.english: They were peering at the sculpture in the far corner.

et: derivation from verb machiar "mar, blemish", a borrowing via Italian from Latin macula "stain".
derivation from verb machiar "mar, blemish", a borrowing via Italian from Latin macula "stain".

examples.vernacular: My paðr es collocquant con y gournour imminent.
examples.english: My father is interviewing the governor-elect.

et: Middle Boral borrowing from Latin imminēns, present participle of immineō "I overhang; I am intent upon, I am near at hand". The verb imminir was briefly current but had obsolesced by the end of the seventeenth century. Its original use in Borlish was in the phrase heriter imminent "heir apparent", as opposed to heriter provisoir "heir presumptive".

examples.vernacular: Sy benjamin a cedr sta imminuð sad.
examples.english: He'd overdone the cedarwood perfume.

examples.vernacular: Impar my fraðr j'am l'ig pascman a manoscart.
examples.english: Unlike my brother I like that fusion restaurant.

et: Middle Borlish legalese borrowing from Latin adjective impār "unequal", and used as a preposition almost as quickly by analogy with par "by, through, (archaic) according to" < Latin per "through".

examples.vernacular: Jo vis y fabr all'Auspeç Impareïbr noncupað.
examples.english: I saw the self-styled Peerless Seer's stage show.

et: Originally in legal use for "official reprimand for immorality", from synonymous improbātiō in Latin.

examples.vernacular: Y maðr improbau sell'heir posc l'ig fo reuluð.
examples.english: The mother scolded her son when he got back.

et: Middle Borlish < Latin, from the some root as incendiar

examples.vernacular: T'incombisce te leyar tostessem.
examples.english: You should have got up earlier.

et: originally in the first senses, a Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin incumbō "I lie upon, I recline". The physical senses are attested later and may be based on the Latin (or may show influence from related descombr "go to bed, lie down to sleep).

examples.vernacular: Sell'ec gest volen rebondir cos incommorant.
examples.english: His acts would have immediate consequences.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from Scholastic Latin incommorāns "not lingering; not delaying", a derivative of the root moror "I linger, loiter"
from Scholatic Latin incox "digestion", from verb incoquō "I boil down".

orphaned negative of (by then obsolete) creil "gullible, trusting". This descends from Latin crēdulus, whence also creu "an oath of frustration or (ironically) appreciation, lately particularly in sexual contexts", which is a 20C borrowing from Portingale créu via the meaning "idiot, git, jerk".

examples.vernacular: Y taflot nos souvolau un nievr d'increiltað atorn.
examples.english: The game sowed seeds of mistrust among us.

et: Middle Borlish noun derivation of increil "disbelieving, mistrustful".
sixteenth-century borrowing from Latin indāgō "I track, trace; I investigate".

examples.vernacular: Nos ayau l'indagour scos ne sell'azig.
examples.english: We'd hidden the tracker in his shoe.

et: agentive derivation from verb indagar "track, investigate, scan, analyse". The word was used only for people until the late nineteenth century, when the word was extended to various devices able to autonomously track or analyse things.

examples.vernacular: Y stuðant infruniscent assisten y leiçoir.
examples.english: The bored students were at the lecture.

et: negated participle of the verb frunir "to have fun, enjoy oneself". In the latter senses it is attested from the eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Com soð vos tout dijarnt a mesur dell'ec asc inoïð?
examples.english: How are you faring in these unprecedented times?

et: negated past participle of oïr "to hear", seen in usage extended from the literal "unheard" from the twelfth century. The verb descends directly from Latin audiō "I hear". In the specific sense "unprecedented" it is seen from the seventeenth century.

examples.vernacular: Deu mien, il s'ayen por inquillin!
examples.english: Oh my God, they were roommates!

et: from Latin inquilīnus "sojourner, lodger; inmate", related to incolō "I inhabit". Influenced in sense by the unrelated noun quil "bed" and verb inquillir "embed". The euphemistic sexual sense has a possible citation in the seventeenth century, but is only securely attested in the nineteenth.
learned borrowing from Latin inquit "he/she said", a personal form of the highly defective verb inquam "I say".

examples.vernacular: Jo dis noc l'ig meyon inquittað con!
examples.english: I didn't say what I've been quoted as saying!

et: seventeenth-century verbal derivative of inquit "quote, citation, excerpt, attestation". The noun inquit is a learned borrowing from Latin inquit "he/she said", a personal form of the highly defective verb inquam "I say".

examples.vernacular: Y lat de dou ascreir quocent produg irruniscabiltað.
examples.english: Supposing √2 is rational leads to a contradiction.

et: noun from irruniscabr "contradictory", itself formed from runir "reunite; reconcile" with the potential suffix -abr and negative suffix ir-, from -ābilis and ir- in Latin. In concrete use describing a particular contradictory thing, the word is attested from the early twentieth century.

examples.vernacular: Vos eð y jacas nuvr oïð ou?
examples.english: Have you heard the new gossip?

et: deverbal from jacassar "chatter; gossip", possibly reinforced by the Merch jackass "male donkey".
borrowing from synonymous jacasser in French. This verb comes from jacasse "magpie; busybody", a derivative of the name Jacques.
Old Borlish < Latin iaceō “I lie down”.

examples.vernacular: Fort alcot i quotta y jacquot me souprene.
examples.english: I was surprised how well the coat suited him.

et: Middle Borlish < Middle French < Old French < Arabic

examples.vernacular: Cay sdroy cas sar de jout jagat.
examples.english: It's an online collection of narrative tropes.

et: nineteenth century borrowing via Vascon from Gurjat જગત <jagat> "world, universe", used as a term of art for "setting" in literary criticism. This is a learned reflex of synonymous Sanscrit जगत् <jagat>, from a root cognate with English "come". Its poetic usage recalls the original sense but is not used in ordinary speech or writing.

examples.vernacular: Y lasc es jagatteyað nell'Anarchy Portingal.
examples.english: The film is set during the Portingale Anarchy.

et: early 20th century, verbal derivation from jagat "setting, world, continuity". In the last sense the word enters general use only around the turn of the millennium.

examples.vernacular: Il ern l'imascry descorçant ag cogn jagerrem.
examples.english: They were peering at the sculpture in the far corner.

et: of uncertain origin. Likely a diminutive of a form *jac, jag, which must be related somehow to the synonymous jag in Markish—the direction of borrowing is however unclear since the Markish is only attested from the fifteenth century. Attempts have been made to connect the words to Borland English çagge "shrub" but the semantics are doubtful.
past participle of jagottar "to notch, serrate".
from noun jagot "notch, snag, sharp projection"

examples.vernacular: Ty jahesment es angostessem sur y mien.
examples.english: Your TV set is thinner than mine.

et: borrowed from Vascon jahesment "contraption", a derivative of jahès "harness, rig". This in turn was borrowed from Arabic جَهَاز • jahāz "gear, utensil", from a root meaning "to prepare". Specialisation to devices such as telephone or radio sets was first applied to steeplepost equipment around the turn of the 19th century.
literally "hated throw", originally used in gambling games to describe losing positions with only a slim chance of turning around.
Old Borlish < Latin iaciō "I throw, fling".

examples.vernacular: Te val casc joccon presument jannestar.
examples.english: You should ignore all the smug jokesters.

et: verbal derivation of jannest "broom, cleaning brush", from Old Borlish janeste, geneste "broom, broom shrub" (the former originally from northern dialect), from Latin genesta "broom shrub". The noun jannest has been supplanted in its botanical sense by originally-Kelt banag "broom shrub" (see also Norman balay, Cambrick banadyl). In the last sense, attested since 1941.
a modern coinage from Greek ἰάνθῐνος <iánthinos> "violet-coloured"

examples.vernacular: Jo vent for pisment y reloðessem, ne jast e n'eramn.
examples.english: I sell only the finest clockwork, made of zinc or bronze.

et: 17C, from Scholastic Latin iastum “zinc”, either from Middle Italian jasto or Vallack jastu “zinc”, from Persian جاست (jast) “zinc”, from Gurjatick जस्ता (jastā) “zinc”. Discovered as an independent metal in 14C India, then traded west along Arab routes. Nonetheless, jast alloys such as brass were known in Europe from antiquity, as well as igniac jast (that is, calamine), but the structure of these materials was not fully understood.

examples.vernacular: Panel jattove parlocan y cambr.Atchey
examples.english: Teak panels lined the bedroom.

et: from Portingale xaviga "trawlnet" in the thirteenth century; the initial voicing is unexplained and has been attributed to dialect variation. The Portingale word is a borrowing from Arabic شَبَكَة (shabaca) "fishing net", likely via Mostara Spanish.

examples.vernacular: Nos javigaum toð y majon livr por detaxion cas aur.
examples.english: We searched the whole library for syntheses involving gold.

et: originally in the first sense, borrowed along with the noun javig "trawlnet; later, (a) methodical search" from synonymous Portingale xaviga in the thirteenth century; the initial voicing is unexplained and has been attributed to dialect variation. The Portingale word is a borrowing from Arabic شَبَكَة (shabaca) "fishing net", likely via Mostara Spanish.

examples.vernacular: Nos som jeunant y jorn, ma colluïsc mey a masquet pos occas vars un gran quelt.
examples.english: We're fasting during the day, but come with me to mosque after sunset for a big dinner.

et: from Old Boral ieunar, from Latin ieiūnō “I fast”. Synchronically analysable as jeun “fast” + verbal -ar. With prefix des- < Latin dis-, we have desjeun “breakfast”, desjeunar “to have breakfast”.
19C in the jargon of competitive archery; possibly related to the letter <x> /ɛks/ as a symbol marking a target. The phrase jay X "an X-throw(?)" has been suggested as the origin but is unattested.

examples.vernacular: Nos targoim y fenestr de joivr ne spaiðant.
examples.english: We scraped frost off the window.

et: descendant of Old Borlish givre, guivre "frost", borrowed from Old French and thought to originate in a Frankish form like gibara cognate with Willem gever "saliva".

examples.vernacular: Lamp a jom e smaraut accenen y pladisc.
examples.english: Deep blue and emerald lights lit the bar.

et: sixteenth century from Scholastic Latin iomus or Tuscan jomo, originally referring to a sort of blue pigment containing cobalt often used to dye glass. These are trade-words borrowed from the east, via (Bagliemman) Arabic from Turk or Persian جام • jām "glass". The term was repurposed for the metal once it was isolated in the late seventeenth century.
Old Borlish < Old French < Latin < Classical German

ge: cow which has not yet calved
et: rom Vulgar Latin iunicia, an alteration of Classical iūnīx, iūnīcem of the same meaning (see also Burgund jenice, Valacan juninca).

from Old Boral ȝenhovar and similar forms, from Old Welsh gwenhwyfar “white spirit”, possibly via an Old English form *ġenovare, though this is disputed. Equivalent to English names Guinevere, Jennifer.

examples.vernacular: Scan noc y jonnovar zucarrað ancour – nos despardreu eç fam.
examples.english: Don't bring out the candied butterflies yet – we'll ruin our appetites.

et: type of sweet, shaped pastry spiced with cinnamon or nutmeg, traditionally in the form of butterflies. From early Borlish symbols of rebirth, associated originally with the winter solstice but now linked strongly to Christmas Day.

ge: between a rock and a hard place

examples.vernacular: Y preç ag davarn vole nossy jougl.
examples.english: The hotel's price would be the clincher.

et: from Middle Borlish jougl "death blow, killing strike", deverbal from joglar "to slay, to decisively kill, esp. to slit the throat of". This descends via synonymous Old Borlish ioȝlar from Latin iugulō, verb derivative from iugulum "collarbone, throat; fig. a murder". Less-fatal use appears first in the context of prize-fighting.
Old French jouel < Latin iocale < iocus

examples.vernacular: Ag port penoy sign scaunt 'Abseïr Jug'.
examples.english: The sign on the door read 'Keep Out'.

et: from Old Borlish iui /dʒyj/ "always, forever, without stopping", which descends directly from Late Latin iūge "constantly, all the time". Replaced in the "always" sense by tojorn < toð jorn "all day" by the Middle Borlish period. The expected modern spelling juy was over time altered to jug under the influence of the Latin form. In modern spoken usage the word is confined mostly to imperative constructions.
Old Borlish < Old French < Medieval Latin

examples.vernacular: Nos ayau paut ny refectoir jusser.
examples.english: We'd eaten at the downstairs cafe.

et: redundant adjectival derivative of Old Borlish juss "below, further down", from late Insular Latin iūrsum, iūssum, a nonstandard form of Classical deorsum "downwards". In the latter sense extended by analogy to tauger "upstairs; more general".

examples.vernacular: Neleð y gran key roug appoyar.
examples.english: Please don't press the big red button.

et: from Old Borlish key, keȝ, caiȝ "toggle, dowel, pin for securing rope or fabric", a dialect form of stanard caiȝle /ke(j)ʎə/ (soon lost). This reflects Vulgar Latin cavicla (cf. French cheville, Venisian caúcia), from Classical Latin clavicula "bolt, bar, small key".
from synonymous kirte in Old Borlish, and is probably onomatopoeic in origin.

examples.vernacular: Cay rix un kirt ag madou por defas machinaçonnal.
examples.english: War is a catalyst of technological development.

et: idiom attested from the 18C, literally "spark to the kindling".
from Old Borlish cyfew, kiue and other forms, loaned from Borland English cīfeoh "herd of cattle"—compare Old English cȳ "cows", feoh "cattle, property".

examples.vernacular: Jo cof un grivougl de kiveury ag quarvol.
examples.english: I got a herdtale potboiler at the airport.

et: 19th-century derivative of kiveu "cattle, herd" with the suffix -ry "a collection of things, a shop, a gestalt quality", coined as a calque of Hasinic Welsh jadełath "herd-dom". The noun kiveu descends from Old Borlish kifew "cattle", a borrowing a Borland Old English cyfeoh "cattle-herd". To describe an ideology the term is seen from the early twentieth century, usually in critical contexts.

examples.vernacular: Cay l'hour set.
examples.english: It's seven o'clock

et: 19C, originally a brand name, from lacq "lac" and Latin veronix "varnish".
"unclear—probably Germanic given Old English langan 'yearn', but possibly influenced by Latin langueo"

examples.vernacular: Y barvier portan lan des lorrell'ovegl meðes.
examples.english: The shepherds wore their own sheep's wool.

et: uncomplicated descendant of Latin lāna "wool". For human hair the word is attested sporadically from early Middle Borlish, with a resurgence in the twentieth century. The generic senses appear to descend from an obsolete slang use of the word to mean "cash, coins", which was briefly current in the early modern period.

examples.vernacular: Candon y nuverrem es ig Istr Boral vencoy ny torney a lançbal?
examples.english: When did Borland last win the lineball tournament?

et: eighteenth-century compound from lançar "to throw" and bal "ball". The verb descends from Late Latin lanceō "I launch, shoot, pierce", a derivative of Classical lancea "javelin, spear". Compare caugtrbal "kickball, football", which dates from roughly the same time as a word but whose rules were standardised several decaded later than lineball. In the last sense the word is attested from the 1950s.
Old Borlish < Old French < Old Aquitain < Vulgar Latin
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Portingale—further origin unclear

a seventeenth-century calque of Vascon conill guy (/gi/; the earlier /gwi/ was altered by analogy to the unrelated name "Guy"), which comes via Morrove [Maghrebi] Arabic from Run'allo [Quechua] quwi "(female) guinea pig".

examples.vernacular: Y lasc 'Blanc Gahað' a font n'un livr d'an 1890.
examples.english: The film "Jet White" is based on a book from 1890.

et: borrowed in the Middle Borlish period originally in the first sense, either via Roun French lage "film" or directly from synonymous lágye in Dorstad Dutch. This is a diminutive of lágh "layer", cognate with English "low". Extension to photography took place in the nineteenth century; the word was applied first to the light-sensitive coating and then to the film as a whole.

examples.vernacular: Caye gimmolt lasdr a y smoutour ðescar.
examples.english: It was a pathetic attempt to egg on the riots.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from contemporary French lasdre "n. leper, wretch; adj. leprous, wretched". This descends from Late Latin Lazarus, in reference to a beggar in the New Testamement who was traditionally understood to have been a leper.
either a secondary development in the Old Borlish period from adjective las "tired, faint, spent, or else a direction descendent from Latin lasitudo.

examples.vernacular: Il ayen heu lastumnesc, com ig il n'ayen for pog dormið.
examples.english: They looked haggard, as though they hadn't had much sleep.

et: fifteenth century, from lastumn. For things other than people, from the 18th century.

examples.vernacular: Y lat vorpal de cinq cent e doç val ogt.
examples.english: The cube root of five hundred and twelve is eight.

et: Middle Borlish, a borrowing from Latin latus "side, flank". Originally used in geometry, and extended to the arithmetic usage by analogy to the example of a square's area and side-length. Senses referring to metaphorical sudden boundaries are attested from the eighteenth century.
via Old Borlish from Insular Latin lauga "league" (cf. leuga, legua), originally a Gaulish unit. Adopted along with the pie "foot" as a base length unit of the modern "dime" system of measurement.

examples.vernacular: Nos feim un baugl lau pre yonoscon.
examples.english: We camped in the middle of nowhere.

et: early nineteenth century idiom literally meaning "league before wherever". In metaphorical use from the early twentieth century.

examples.vernacular: Y dou tarnaç laundaurn ne sortir.
examples.english: The two regulars stumbled as they left.

et: from Old Borlish laundar "slip, err", either from an unattested synonymous Latin verb *lābundō or a contemporary verbal derivation of laund "slippery, unsteady" (the modern launt "slip, misstep, faux pas" is likely a later deverbal from the Middle Borlish period). In either case the word originates with Latin lābundus "slippery", participial form of deponent verb lābor "I slip, sink, vanish, err".
idiom meaning "donkey's work", attested from the eighteenth century.
learned borrowing from Latin laurea "laurel tree; crown of laurels; triumph, victory".
Middle Borlish; partly from some phrases containing l'au "had it", but the origin of the coda -sc is unclear.

examples.vernacular: Tu a scaumel lavaç meyon benoçabr ou?
examples.english: Do you have a spare pen I can borrow?

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from early Roun French lavace "wasteful, spare", originally "abundant, copious". This comes from a homonymous noun meaning "abundance" (originally "torrential rain"), a derivation from verb laver "to wash", from Latin lavō "I wash, bathe".

examples.vernacular: Con tersur psolic poð l'yeustanç de vin lejar.
examples.english: Sulfites can arrest the fermentation of wine.

et: Middle Borlish < Medieval Latin < Mostara < Arabic < Ancient Greek
borrowing from synonymous léncorve /ˈleːn.kɔrv/ in Willem Dutch, from lenen "to lend" and corve "basket; fund".

examples.vernacular: Tu desir un beller epu a scoclet lessy ou?
examples.english: Do you want a mini white chocolate sweet?

et: originally in the first sense from Old Borlish leissi "bleached, whitened; (n.) lye soap". This descends from Vulgar Latin lixīvia "lye", via lixīvus "made of lye" from lixa "lye, alkaline water".

examples.vernacular: Y haprman libau sy bier e reuloy a racont fair.
examples.english: The grocer quaffed his lager and kept talking.

et: borrowed from Latin lībō "I taste, sip; I offer a libation". Extension to metaphorical drinking is attested from the eighteenth century. In the last sense, a backformation or reborrowing from Latin which is much less common than the synonymous phrase libaçon fair "to offer a libation".

originally in the second sense, an Old Borlish deverbal noun from verb lejar "stop moving, crash, come to a halt". This descends from Insular Latin laedicō, a regularisation of Classical laedō "I strike, collide, hurt".

examples.vernacular: Com veleð vos farar ða vos cay un liesc bouclant?
examples.english: What would you do if you were in a time loop?

et: idiom from the late 19th century, literally "looping duration". The phrase was first used in the translation of 1880 work Cludor ncar Vantel "A Postman in Wrexham", which features such a time loop.
Old Borlish < Italian < Vulgar Latin < Ancient Greek
from Vulgar Latin līctō "I forsake", from past participle līctus of verb linquō "I leave, quit, depart"

examples.vernacular: Y segr possey linaç aðief por vous dou.
examples.english: The man has enough parentage for you both.

et: from Old Boral linaç "lineage, parentage", probably borrowed from Old French but in any case related to lign "line; line of descent". In the sense "house, dynasty", attested from the twelfth century.

examples.vernacular: Sco livað den!
examples.english: I'm fed up of it!

et: past participle of livar "tan, darken, make leather from rawhide", itself a verbal derivation from noun lif "tan, oak bark or similar compound using in tanning leather". This reflects either an unattested Latinate derivative of līveō "I am bruised" or a Kelt form cognate with Cambrick łiw "dye, paint".

examples.vernacular: Augrimeð y locomoçon entr y dou termin dy camin.
examples.english: Find the displacement between the path's endpoints.

et: sixteenth century, borrowed from Scholastic Latin locomōtiō "movement from place to place", from Classical Latin noun locus "place" and verb moveō "I move". The word is sometimes in technical contexts contrasted with moçon "motion of parts of a body relative to other parts". Its mathematical sense is attested from the eighteenth century as the vector counterpart of scalar lonctumn "length, distance".
Scholastic Latin, from the same root as locomoçon "movement"

examples.vernacular: Lodrignaðer l'ig no's meðes un pescot.
examples.english: Technically that's not even a fish.

et: first attested in the eighteenth century, adjectival derivation from somewhat older noun lodrignað "medical intervention, operation; technique, procedure, protocol". This is borrowed from Welsh łodrinnaeth "surgery, medical intervention" (cf. also the calqued Markish handiwork "surgery"), whose root is in trinna "to handle, treat".

examples.vernacular: Vail un bon trenc, lour dar un jorn cogmað lon cost.
examples.english: It would be nice to give them a day off for free.

et: “without cost”. The first word is from Old Boral loin “away from”, from Latin longē “from far off”; the second a deverbal derivation of the verb costar “to cost, to be worth” (first attested 12C), from Latin constō “I consist of, I cost”. Both the verb and the deverbal are unattested outside of this construction after 1500.

dv: an interjection expressing (often ironically) that something echoes how one is (or would like to be) perceived
et: taken from a parody of stock phrases used in late 20C crime reporting, the phrase literally meaning "how one's friends/colleagues describe one"
Latin longitūdō or formed in Old Borlish

examples.vernacular: Jo me cou battuð d'un hom raðant ag los.
examples.english: I got hit by someone cycling on the pavement.

et: originally in the first sense and descending from Old Borlish los "flag, slab", reflected by synonymous lausa in Medieval Latin (and later Vascon llosa "slate", among others). This is thought to be from a Kelt form *lausā related to known līvus, whence for example Irish lie "stone, pillar".

examples.vernacular: Nos acataum trenc a lox dy stal ant un canougf a fais blau.
examples.english: We bought pizza from the stall with a blue-striped awning.

et: borrowed into Borlish in the twentieth century via for instance Saxon lox, Napolitan losse, Awrish [Hungarian] locs /lokʃ/ and Greek λώξη • lṓxē "pizza, etc." from a metathetic variant of Armeniac լաւշկի • lōški "lavash, pitta, small flatbread". The word is applied widely, although without modification it refers prototypically to slices of thin bread with a sauce, cheese and vegetables.

examples.vernacular: Veleð y luam covauclir pre exeunt fair.
examples.english: Please put the toilet lid down before leaving.

et: late eighteenth century, originally in university slang and then in euphemistic use, borrowed from the Latin verb form luam "I will wash, cleanse". Semantic transfer from the room to the fixture had occurred by the mid-nineteenth century. Puns involving the homophony of luam "toilet" and l'yam "the uncle" < Old English ēam "maternal uncle" are attested from 1910.

examples.vernacular: Jo n'ay acconnosc aut d'un segr luïcherrem.
examples.english: I've never met a more ridiculous man.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin lūdicer "sportive, playful" with the stem remodelled on related verb luïr "to play".
Middle Borlish < Old French < Vulgar Latin
Latin lūsor, related to luïr "to play".

examples.vernacular: Banc redirigent machinal receveurn magn aversion.
examples.english: Automated redirection banks were met with significant opposition.

examples.vernacular: Il le macquaurn vars surcair un tarç dagr.
examples.english: They raised her to be neither fish nor fowl.

et: from Old Borlish ma(c)quar "to raise (a child)", from synonymous Insular Latin maquō, maccō, likely of Kelt origin. If so, cognate with Irish mac "son" and Welsh magωr "cowherd" (formerly "breeder of animals").

a borrowing from Middle French (a)madou "lure, bait; kindling, touchwood", a deverbal of amadouer "coax, lure; kindle". This verb is thought to descend via Old Norse mata "lure, feed" from Classical German *matō "I feed".

examples.vernacular: Jo cogleu y quesq y maðuressem dy ranscel.
examples.english: I picked the ripest damson on the branch.

examples.vernacular: Banc redirigent machinal receveurn magn aversion.
examples.english: Automated redirection banks were met with significant opposition.

ge: ten to the minus eighth power

examples.vernacular: Jo m'asseyeu ny caðer magrastr cos coðelous.
examples.english: I sat gingerly on the rickety chair.

et: early Modern formation using the pejorative suffix -astr < Latin -aster "incomplete resemblance to" from adjective magr "limited, scarce, meagre". This descends directly via Old Borlish maȝre /ˈmaɣ.rə/ from Latin macer "lean, skinny". The word is attested in metaphorical use from the nineteenth century.

examples.vernacular: L'agent dy Majon Roug souseyeu l'ig scard commoðer.
examples.english: The Red House agent dealt with that resistance group.

examples.vernacular: No sceye l'hour por commorar ne malestr.
examples.english: There wasn't time to linger in discomfort.

et: descendant of Old Borlish malestre "discomfort". This was a compound of mal "bad", which descends from synonymous malus in latin, and estre "being, state" (a former infinitive of "be" since replaced by star), which descends from Latin essere "to be". The word has extended to cover various bad or unpleasant emotions, competing for space with hougr "fear, annoyance, discontent" < Latin augurium "omen, warning, foreboding".

a borrowing from synonymous Merch mallowick or directly from the character Mall-Lowick /ˈmal ˈlu.ɪk/ and her eponymous novel, in which she is a young girl subjected to various travails but never losing her hopeful demeanour. Her name is a compound of Mall, a hypocoristic form of Mary, and Lowick, which comes via Old French Loïc from Frankish Hloðwig (cf. Vascon Luixa and Napolitan Ludgia [and IRL Louise]). The name was applied almost immediately in a mocking way to a person seen as similar to Mall-Lowick.

examples.vernacular: J'osc sy cigl novel; i's mallovicher sad demay.
examples.english: I hate her new girlfriend; she's far too chipper.

et: 19C, adjectival derivation from mallovic "someone who is naïve and cheerful to a ridiculous or irritating extent".

examples.vernacular: Cascif aun y mancel dou colour destegnt?
examples.english: Why are the sleeves two different colours?

et: via Old Borlish mancel "sleeve" from Vulgar Latin manicella "little sleeve", diminutive of synonymous manica in Classical Latin.
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Greek ἀμυγδάλη

examples.vernacular: Tag enverimmað con mandrin occeyeu ty quanga.
examples.english: Your secretary was poisoned with cyanide-laced tea.

et: adjectival derivation from mandr "almond" (from the presence of cyanide in almonds) first used in expressions like mandrin a lix "potassium cyanide" in the eighteenth century.
Middle Borlish < Latin, adjective from març "wares".

examples.vernacular: Jo cof alcun marrenquon n'oc hour apres.
examples.english: I didn't have any nightmares for a while.

et: pleonastic compound of Old Borlish marr and enquon, both meaning "nightmare". The former is a loan either from Old French or from a German language, while the latter descends from Latin incubō "nightmare". The extension of this word to other malevolent demonic figures is seen from the sixteenth century.
