Old Borlish from Late Latin martellus "hammer", a variant diminutive of synoymous marculus in Classical Latin.
noun derivation from martellar "hammer, pound; emphasise, accentuate". This term developed its metaphorical senses in tandem with the verb, during the late Middle Borlish period.

examples.vernacular: I me dau ðorn tranq ag massour.
examples.english: She punched me right in the jaw.

et: Middle Borlish masçour "jaw(bone)" respelt in the 1870 reform, agentive derivation from masçar "chew, bite down on". This straightforwardly reflects post-classical Latin masticō "I chew", from Greek. In non-anatomical use the word is attested from the sixteenth century.
Middle Borlish < Scholastic Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Nos stau livað d'ableganç vars y maugr.
examples.english: We're fed up of being on the sidelines.

et: via Old Borlish marȝr, mauȝr "margin, edge" from Latin margō "border, margin, edge". In the geographical sense originaly referring specifically to the rural areas near to the city of Damvath. The term is seen in the last metaphorical sense from the eighteenth century onward.
Middle Borlish < Medieval Latin < Italian < Arabic

examples.vernacular: I da empley a xiphar mejoncr naðusc.
examples.english: She employs rather mid mercenaries.

et: alteration of Middle Borlish mejocr "middling" under the influence of unrelated words like coroncr "impostor" and pujoncr "dagger" (whose endings descend from the diminutive suffix -(un)culus in Latin). This was borrowed directly from Latin mediocris "mediocre", a possible compound of medius "middle" and ocris "rugged mountain" (as to suggest "halfway up").
Italian melodrama, from melo- and drama "play"
Noun derivative based on Old Borlish mendre "less, fewer" (cf. modern mendrem)

from Old Borlish mensc "praiseworthiness, repute, fame". This was borrowed from Old Norrish mennska "humanity", a descendant of Classical German manniscas "human". The semantic shift via honourable actions to general good behaviour was complete by the seventeenth century.
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin *mentō < Latin mentum

examples.vernacular: Smars sta un cont mesaventoresq e stendiscent.
examples.english: What emerged was an overlong, farcical tale.

et: nineteenth century, a blend the two preexisting words mesaventur and aventoresq.
the prefix mes- "badly" (from Germanic) and the obsolete noun aventur "event, chance" < Vulgar Latin adventūra

examples.vernacular: Sy sour luïsc tojorn sona de mesmerist.
examples.english: Her sister always tells it like it is.

et: 18th century borrowing from Scholastic Latin mesmerista "truth-teller" and mesmerizō "I reveal the truth"; this verb comes from synonymous μεσμερίζω • mesmerizō in Malchassian Greek, a derivative of μεσμέρι • mesméri "midday; (fig.) clarity, understanding".

examples.vernacular: L'eç dougl nos mestein cascun.
examples.english: These losses sadden us all.

et: via Old Borlish from Vulgar Latin mesticō "I sadden", from Latin maestus "sad, gloomy".
Old Borlish < Latin, conflation of maestus and miser
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Italian < Latin
Middle Borlish < Middle Dutch, Old Norse
from Vulgar Latin *molliō "I soak, drench", related to mollis "soft, tender".

examples.vernacular: Nossy can am noc eir tras port candon cay moglastr.
examples.english: Our dog doesn't like going outside when it's damp.

et: derivative of moglar "to wet, dampen, moisten" with the pejorative suffix -astr < Latin -aster "resembling, quasi-".

examples.vernacular: Jo cogleu l'aujon des y tabr mogn.
examples.english: I picked the mag up off the low table.

et: direct descendant of Old Borlish mogne /moɲə/ "low down", of disputed further origin. Probably not related to Old French moins "less", despite use of the word in parallel comparative constructions in dialectal modern Borlish. The most secure lead is Kernish [Breton] monn "oaf", connected with Old French moing "someone mutilated" to a proposed Gaulish munniō "blunt", although the semantics are somewhat tenuous.
Old Borlish < Latin. In the computing sense, partly from Arabic مَجْهُول • majhūl "unknown".
Old Borlish < Medieval Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Nos eyau monnocquar tras seg acr por ac yembr.
examples.english: We had to trudge through six fields to get here.

et: first attested in the 18th century; further origin obscure. Attempts to connect the word "monk"—perhaps moigne or monhe from regional French and Portingale dialects respectively—stumble on phonetic grounds (and the proposed semantic connection of a monk's plodding gait is tenuous).

examples.vernacular: Jo montau ag tabr e clignau my bos yert a haut.
examples.english: I got up on the table and fired my gun into the air.

examples.vernacular: Y çarf bondisceu tras un reu mormonnant.
examples.english: The stag leapt over a babbling brook.

et: late Middle Borlish, an onomatopoetic formation (along with contemporaneous mormonment "(a) mumble") allied with Latin murmurō "I murmur" and Parisian marmotter "to mutter". The word had extended to similar non-speech sounds by the end of the eighteenth century.
Old Borlish < Insular Latin, noun from mordr "bite"
literally "bite at a carrot", coined by the poet Bautrmeu as the title of her 1654 compendium of works.
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Italian < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: I vendra tart dec caut flaccið ne mot routoir.
examples.english: He'll be late since he's stuck in a traffic jam.

et: from Old Borlish mot "lump, mound" and thought to be of Germanic origin; possibly via Old French mote "hillock" from Frankish motta "mud, peat, turf". The term is first used in the "blockage" sense in the fifteenth century, and soon thereafter it sees metaphorical use.

examples.vernacular: Comoscon vouð vos l'oc delit motivar?
examples.english: How are you going to justify this crime?

et: Middle Borlish, verbal derivation from motif "plan, project, grounds, reason, excuse". This descends from Late Latin mōtīvum "motive, cause", neuter of adjective mōtīvus "moved, stirred".
Old Borlish from Latin mōlēs "crowd, heap; weight, effort".

examples.vernacular: Tras sougl azia segr moulous un bos svingant.
examples.english: At the door was a bulky man holding a gun.

et: eighteenth-century derivative of moul "lump; mass, heft, size", which descends directly from Latin mōlēs "crowd, heap; weight, effort".

examples.vernacular: Sy figl reloy sur y hayennaç con un movaç.
examples.english: His kid continued the homework with a pout.

et: eighteenth century, pejorative noun formation from movar "pout, sulk".
from earlier moar, a borrowing from Old French verb moer and noun moe "grimace", each from a Frankish form reflecting Classical German mauvō "sleeve; protruding lip".
augmentative of obsolet mud, via Dutch mus and Old French muid from Latin modius "unit of dry measure"
Old Borlish, related to Classical German munis "mind, memory"
Middle Borlish < Late Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Jug sein y domn egrtumnesc n'eç cahut.
examples.english: Keep the sick women quarantined.

et: idiom attested from the eighteenth century, literally meaning "in cabins". It appears roughly contemporaneously with cognate idioms in other languages, such as Merch's in cahutes "independently".

examples.vernacular: Vos s'arreð n'impisantour tras catr minut.
examples.english: You will feel weightless for four minutes.

et: 1812, coined along with the noun impisantour "weightlessness" during the voidtale craze of popular fiction set out among the stars. The noun is from the much older pisantour "weightiness". In extended use the word is attested from the late nineteenth century, with the slightly disparaging connotation established shortly thereafter.

examples.vernacular: J'asseye n'oc hour fin a tandem alandau my convey.
examples.english: I sat for a bit until my train came at last.

et: sixteenth-century idiom, literally "in this time". The preposition and demonstrative n'oc < Latin in hōc "in this" co-occur also in other contemporary idioms like n'oc ort "upwards, with an upwards motion". In the last sense the phrase is still sometimes proscribed, despite attestations going back over two hundred years.
Old Borlish < Latin; from Latin navis, perhaps with some Old French influence.
borrowed from Germanic (cf. Saxon narr "wildcard; maverick").

examples.vernacular: Mell'amig lou narreyau vars agir temerer.
examples.english: My friend goaded them into acting rashly.

et: via Old Borlish nariȝar "to taunt, goad" from Vulgar Latin nāricō "I snort", related to nārēs "nose". Respelt in the Modern Borlish period by conflation with narr "fool, jester, joker"
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin, doublet of nascr

examples.vernacular: Y nastr a my sac son flois demay.
examples.english: My bag's straps are too loose.

et: via Old Borlish nasle "strap, thong" and an identical Old French word from a Classical German noun derivative of nastanam "bind, tie, braid, plait". Extended to the tool used in animal husbandry and as a weapon in the Middle Borlish period.

examples.vernacular: Jo feg nouf laur mathem ne ðougl ig crevoscr.
examples.english: I knocked out nine maths problems last night.

et: literally "in a flurry, in a gust of wind", idiom first attested in the fourteenth century. The noun ðougl "flurry, gust" reflects Old Borlish ðouȝl, deverbal noun from ðoȝlar "waft, gust, float on the wind"; this verb descends from Latin adoleō "I emit an odour, I smell".

examples.vernacular: Jo luy dau un croun neðan i surcous ne fousc arð.
examples.english: I gave him some cash so he wouldn't be flat broke.

et: nineteenth-century idiom literally meaning "in (a) pit". The noun fousc "pit, hole in the ground; trap, snare, pitfall" descends with meaning pracatically unchanged via Old Borlish fouz /futʃ/ from fovea in Latin. The coventionalised intensifier for this idiom is arð "steep", which has been analogised to other expressions for poverty; cf. povr arð "very poor".

examples.vernacular: Nos orruð stou le fornir con ne minemini.
examples.english: She seems worth the benefit of the doubt.

et: fourteenth century in legal Latin as nē minēminī "do not threaten, do not accuse", from the prohibitive particle nē and the second-person plural subjunctive of deponent verb minor "I threaten, accuse". Its original denotation was closer to a admonition against obtaining confessions by duress or threats, only attaining its modern meaning in the seventeenth century. Shortly thereafter the phrase appears in nursery rhymes, presumably more for phonetic reasons than any semantic connection. Nonetheless, some have dubiously linked these rhymes to the act of picking a scapegoat for a crime.

examples.vernacular: Son il nervous d'issaur ny cors?
examples.english: Are they sure they'll win the contest?

et: from Middle Boral nervous "sinewy; vigorous", borrowed from synonymous Latin nervōsus along with noun nerf < Latin nervus "nerve, sinew; vigour". The extension in meaning from "vigorous" to "bold" and then to "confident" had taken place by the start of the nineteenth century.
neyar “to snow” plus the gerundive -anç, from Late Latin nivat “it snows” (a regularisation of Classical Latin ningit) and the nominalising suffix -antia, respectively.

examples.vernacular: Y preu osc borallesc dy Grant Morenç a 1519 fis loy ne Damvað a mesur dy neyanç vert.
examples.english: The first Borlish victim of the 1519 Great Dying was in Damvað during the green snowfall.

et: regular adjectival derivation of niaç "nest", which is itself an extension of earlier ni < Latin nīdus "nest".
regular reflection of synonymous nex in Latin.
from dialectical Portingale nimbrete "keepsake", diminutive formation related to standard nembrar "to remember". This is a dissimilated form from Latin memorō "I bring to mind".

examples.vernacular: Jo cur bogr yon nis sbolognar.
examples.english: I don't care whose fault it is.

et: from Old Borlish nis, neȝs, niȝs et al. "effort, vigour", which descends uncomplicatedly from Latin nīxus, nīsus "strain, forward momentum". This is the participle of deponent verb nītor "I lean on, advance, strive, contend", which does not survive in any descendant.

examples.vernacular: Cu tendra nis ac?
examples.english: Whose fault is it?

et: idiom from the seventeenth century, originally seen in legal contexts, literally "to hold effort".

examples.vernacular: Certan dy niveu catr son y scaunç de melodram parsiscent.
examples.english: Some in the fourth set are learning musical scriptwriting.

et: late 19th century, borrowed from Roun French nivew "level, tier" during educational reforms in the Drengot Collusion (of which Borland was a part). This was itself borrowed from Parisian, descending after dissimilation and a gender change from Latin lībella "level (builder's tool)". Extension out of the school setting is seen from the mid-20th century.
contracted form of i no se poð "it isn't possible" popular in the late eighteenth century, with a revival in the early twentieth.

examples.vernacular: Stou y Duc coy l'eç nohas parmy sull'administration d'autortað may accarr.
examples.english: The Duke must stop the right-wing in his regime gaining more influence.

et: 1751, from Arabic نحاس (nuḥās) with the same sense, and originally “copper”. Inspired by the Copper faction in the court of Malik Hisham Al-Rashid (reigned 1601-1610) of Libya, who petitioned against the poor reforms he oversaw. The Copper, and their opposition, the Tin, took their names from the two principal colours of the Libyan banner at the time, which was quartered into two black, one white, and one orange field. These two terms – nohas and casdir – were borrowed into various European languages through the success of the Vascon writer David Bensaíd's treatise on statecraft The Three Cities, which was translated into over twenty languages. Compare for example French nouase, kasdir.

examples.vernacular: L'oc enonç es abrangent a my nom ou?
examples.english: Does this list have my name on it?

examples.vernacular: Jo vis y fabr all'Auspeç Impareïbr noncupað.
examples.english: I saw the self-styled Peerless Seer's stage show.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from contemporary legal Latin nuncupātus "nominal, by name", a variant of Classical nuncupātivus "so-called, nominal". These are derivatives from verb nuncupō "I name, I announce publicly".

dv: pride or bias towards one's own people, home or other particular group
et: 19C, from Ancient Greek νόστος • (nóstos) "the act of returning home" and ῠ̔́βρις • (húbris) "pride, insolence".

examples.vernacular: Nos yemoim toð pront scið y Jorala sta nothe.
examples.english: We immediately realised the Jorala was forged.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from Scholastic Latin notheus "illegitimate, bastard", a pleonastic extension of synonymous nothus in Classical Latin. Originally restricted to legal contexts (where it replaced terms like bort and cif which were considered vulgar), it is now in general use. The term coexists as a higher-register term with French-derived bastart, which is somewhat crass.

examples.vernacular: L'oç mersc verdeya de nougl spinous.
examples.english: That bog was full of spiky bulrushes.

et: from late Old Borlish noȝl "distaff". This is though to conflate two earlier forms: (1) conoȝl "distaff" < synonymous conucula in Late Latin, derivative of Classical colus "distaff"; (2) rocle "distaff" < synonymous rokkill in Old Norse. Dialects differ greatly on which particular plants may be referred to by this term; its meaning is not clarified by its indiscriminate use in poetry.

examples.vernacular: Frastr intermane y nuivr dy hax.
examples.english: The axe handle was made of ash.

et: aphaeretic form of earlier manuivre "hilt" attested from the fifteenth century, a direct descendant of synonymous manubrium in Latin. In metaphorical use it is most often seen in idioms like vars y nuivr "to the bitter end, unreservedly". In the vulgar sense it was current in the nineteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Lor sceye un nuton a tapeçment e pieðr nuaç.
examples.english: Then there was a fad for hangings and stonework.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from various French forms such as luiton, nuitin, lutin, neton, all meaning "sea monster; mischievous spirit; will-o'-the-wisp". These appear to have been influenced by luire "shine" and nuit "night"; the oldest form is netun "sea monster", which descends from Latin Neptunus "the sea god Neptune".

examples.vernacular: Nos pretenm ig casc nou muncef ain nux.
examples.english: We plan to have a hub in each new town.

et: eighteenth century, borrowed from Scholastic Latin nux "nut; cell nucleus". Extended to atomic nuclei upon their discovery in 1902.
a Middle Borlish borrowing from synonymous occāsiō in Latin.

examples.vernacular: Caye un homily magn occajonal sur cartað.
examples.english: It was a very seasonal sermon on charity.

et: adjectival derivation from occajon "opportunity, the right moment". The word's semantic extension is in line with similar shifts in cognates across the Romance languages.

examples.vernacular: Tag enverimmað con mandrin occeyeu ty quanga.
examples.english: Your secretary was poisoned with cyanide-laced tea.

examples.vernacular: L'oc defey sera dur oðig inacavabr.
examples.english: This challenge will be hard or even impossible.

et: descendant of Old Borlish oðiȝ "truly, certainly", which reflects Latin adverb utique "in any case, at least, in particular". The term in its adverbial use is now restricted to very formal writing, and the clarifying sense is also more of the written than spoken register.
taken from the first letter of œculux /ˌe.kiˈlɪks/ "electromagnetic radiation", from Greek οἰκουμένη "the world" and Latin lux "light".

examples.vernacular: Vos val joddy offiçar ag costosc dy bauglment.
examples.english: You should set watchmen to guard the camp.

et: late Middle Borlish, a derivation either vernacularly or within Scholastic Latin from noun offiç "office, position; duty, responsibility, task". The term was originally most common in military and ceremonial contexts, and has broadened significantly to many technical settings.
deverbal from offirr "to hit back, react".
from Insular Latin obferiō "I strike out at", a derivative of feriō "I strike". Perhaps influenced in meaning by Borland English ofwerien "to drive off, parry, push away".

examples.vernacular: Noc saif no's oistr eld ogtoç.
examples.english: Marriage at eighteen is unwise.

et: borrowed in the early modern period from old northern dialect term oistre "wife", which descends directly from synonymous uxor in Latin (compare Old French uissor "wife"). The shift in meaning appears to be due to the poet Bautrmeu, who introduced the term to standard Borlish in her work Mornç a Morn "A Piece of the Action". It is presumed that she misinterpreted the (even then archaic) northern idiom prendr n'oistr "to wed, lit. to take as wife" as "to take in wedlock".

examples.vernacular: Bosc d'ollem sarf a bog fair.
examples.english: Elm wood is used to make bows.

et: via Old Borlish olem "elm", apparently reflecting an unattested Insular Latin ulēmus as a variant of ulmus "elm" influenced by Kelt *lēm "elm". We also see forms such as olmair in the Old Borlish period with the addition of suffix -air to denote a type of tree.

examples.vernacular: Val l'oc ollom se figr n'un reliquat.

et: a descendant of Old Borlish onlom "vessel; (religion) relic", borrowed from Borland Old English ondlōma "utensil, vessel". By the thirteenth century the word had become restricted to religious usage (viewing a relic as a vessel for holy power), from which the other senses have sprung.

From Middle Borlish ombisc 'surrender, capitulation, giving up; resignation, act of leaving a post', deverbal from now-obsolete ombijar 'surrender, capitulate, give up; resign, leave a post'. This descends with a change of valency (possibly via a reflexive form although this is not well attested) from Old Borlish onbi
deverbal from ondolar "ripple". Alternatively, directly from Late Latin undula (but the Borlish is not attested until after the verb).

examples.vernacular: Nos aulaum tras lau de collin ondolant.
examples.english: We walked for miles over rolling hills.

et: directly from Late Latin undulō "I rise in waves, undulate", a derivation from the noun unda "wave, billow". In metaphorical use it is attested form the Middle Borlish period; the emotional extension from the seventeenth century.
from Old Borlish or "now", either straight from Latin (hāc) hōrā "in (this) hour" or via synonymous (a)ore in Old French.

examples.vernacular: Or bon, tenau a le javigar.
examples.english: Alright, let's keep searching.

et: phrase comprising or "well, however" and bon "good, correct".
Middle Borlish < Vascon < Portingale < Arabic < Persian < Sanscrit < Damilid

from the particularly-variable Old Borlish orðençar, orthanscar, aðincquar "to invent, make up", which appears to be the confused chimera of Old English noun orþanc "creativity, skill, invention" and related verb āþenċan "to conceive of, think up".

examples.vernacular: Jo kigla reuvr a mell'orin pre oc annað.
examples.english: I hadn't been back home until this year.

et: via Old Borlish orin, oriȝn "breeding, heritage" from Latin orīgō, orīginem "commencement, origination, (particularly) birth", from which also comes the later reborrowing origin "source, origin, beginning". Used metonymically to refer to the place of one's birth since the fourteenth century.
via Latin from Greek ὁρῐ́ζων • horízōn "horizon". Displaced in the sense "horizon" by lovacq, from Arabic.
verb from orisont "horizon; range, limit, ambit"

examples.vernacular: Cain minut alcot prell'orisontment Jovial?
examples.english: How many minutes is it until Jupiter sets?

et: Middle Borlish, originally a term of art for the first sense, noun derivation from orisontar "set, pass below the horizon". In mathematics the term is seen from the eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: L'ormal dy baðrment fey commet par vrolliscour.
examples.english: The orchestra started the set with a crowdpleaser.

et: an Old Borlish borrowing from Old Norse ǫrmalr "quiver". This is a compound of ǫr "arrow" and malr "case"; the former is from Classical German arhuō "arrow", while the latter is likely allied with malhō "leather bag" (although the change of declension is unexplained). The vulgar sense was current in the Middle Borlish period and enjoyed a brief resurgence in the 19th century due to conscious use in historical novels. The musical senses are attested from the 1920s, originally in reference to recorded music played over the radio.

examples.vernacular: L'ivan asseye sur y ranscel dell'orn.
examples.english: The child was sat on the rowan's branch.

et: Direct descendant of Latin ornus "mountain ash, rowan" via the synonymous orne in Old Borlish. In the last meaning, a conscious revival of an Old Borlish usage which had vanished for centuries.

examples.vernacular: Nos luïsceu primer nell'orn.
examples.english: We're first on in the programme.

et: either from a native Old Borlish orne, ordne, "ordering, arrangement" or borrowed from contemporaneous Old French orne, ordre, both reflecting (as a direct descendant or an early semi-learned loan) Latin ōrdō, ōrdinem "arrangement, rank, group, troop, rite". Extended senses almost definitely adapted directly from the Latin reflex in the Middle Borlish period (cf. short-lived later borrowing ordin).

examples.vernacular: Orruðe hour laundaus lavaç sad.
examples.english: It seemed an awful waste of time.

et: from Old Borlish oruðar, ouruðar "to take up space, take the form of; to amount to", from Late Latin obrūtō "I overwhelm, conceal, cover, take up space". This is a regularisation (with unexplained lengthening of the root vowel) of synonymous obruō in Classical Latin, based on the past participle. In impersonal use it appears to be syntactically modelled on Germanic constructions like English methinks "it seems to me".

examples.vernacular: Je mell'osceyan jolleyaum nos ag scen.
examples.english: For my birthday we went to the theatre.

et: from Middle Borlish oscey-an "birthday celebration", literally "marks the year". The verb osceyar "to mark, commemorate" (now often specifically "to celebrate a birthday" by backformation) is a derivative of now-obsolete osc "notch, mark, tally". This noun is of obscure origin and presumably unrelated to osc "victim" < Latin hostia, although osceyar has on occasion been deliberately misinterpreted as meaning "victimise, prank, haze" for comic effect.

derivative of now-obsolete osc "notch, mark, tally". This noun is of obscure origin and presumably unrelated to osc "victim" < Latin hostia, although osceyar has on occasion been deliberately misinterpreted as meaning "victimise, prank, haze" for comic effect.
Old Borlish <  Old French < Medieval Latin

examples.vernacular: Ðe n'aun nien ostendað tras dou meis.
examples.english: They've posted nothing in two months.

et: early Modern Borlish, a borrowing (probably via a French or Italian language) from Latin ostendō "I expose to view, reveal". In journalism the term originally connoted commercial writing as opposed to actual news. In the context of the mesh there are attestations from the earliest meshfora in the late 1960s.

examples.vernacular: Se poð ou scadom ben ugnlac accatar.
examples.english: You can buy either tomatoes or onions.

et: Old Borlish o ou, "or; question particle", a direct descendant of Latin aut "or". In the last sense, the term was originally used for all the options in a list, but in the modern language the latter options are introduced by ben "or" < Latin bene "well". In the second sense it alternates with ig "that" < Latin ibi "there", which introduced realis clauses; the prototype examples are jo saif ig X "I know that X", jo saif noc ou X "I don't know whether X".

examples.vernacular: Cay ouç ny majon livr.
examples.english: The library is silent.

et: from Old Borlish oç, ouç "leisure, ease, idleness", which reflects Latin ōtium "time free from activity, time avoiding activity". The shift to meanings directly involving the lack of noise had occurred by the sixteenth century.

examples.vernacular: L'es un ouger sobottal cay set annað.
examples.english: He's been a radio host for seven years.

et: from Middle Borlish ouger "landlord/lady", altered from louger via rebracketing of the definite article. This is an agent derivative of now-obsolete lousc "shelter; inn", borrowed from Old French loge "shelter; covered walkway, hut, small room", via synoymous laubia in Medieval Latin from the Classical German root laubam "leaf, foliage". The word has been applied also to other host roles since the seventeenth century.

examples.vernacular: M'orruð un hom ay my bos oundrað.
examples.english: I think someone's broken my gun.

et: from Old Borlish (v)ounrar, oundar "wound, injure", a conflation of the descendant of Latin vulnerō "I wound" and the borrowing of Old Norse unda "to wound" (which are unrelated). The loss of the initial consonant would be unexpected if the Latin etymon was the only one; however, this was a regular feature of Old Norse.

examples.vernacular: Y segr m'oustau des caucet.
examples.english: The man utterly charmed me.

et: descendant via Old Borlish oustar "kill, slay; thwart, stop, defeat" from Latin obstō "oppose, block, hinder". Its more violent senses survive mostly through their use in early translations of the Bible into Borlish; the latter senses are more common in the modern language.

examples.vernacular: Descon luy noc y fraðr vel morir all'outrcaum dy stoir.
examples.english: Don't tell her the brother dies at the climax of the story.

et: seventeenth century coinage in the musical sense, from outr- "beyond, last" < Latin ultra "beyond" and caum "piece of music" < Latin carmen "poem, incantation". The compound has been calqued into other languages, including Merch outsong /ˈəut.sɔŋg/ "coda". In extended use the word is attested from the middle of the nineteenth century.
from Old Borlish outre ley "beyond law"
folk-etymological reformation of Middle Borlish ounieðr "storm", influenced by outr- "beyond" and ney "snow"; ultimately from synonymous unweder in Old English.
Middle Borlish < Latin, Medieval Latin < Persian

examples.vernacular: L'oç bougr s'outrval cos outr.
examples.english: That chap's an utter braggart.

et: early Modern Borlish, derivation of valir "be worth" < Latin valeō "I am strong" with the prefix outr- < Latin ultrā "beyond" (compare independent Borlish words outr "complete, utter" and doutr "beyond"). In reflexive use the word is attested from the Long Peace period at the turn of the nineteenth century.
unknown, compare Old French ui, English wye

examples.vernacular: J'ay my pan sciftað a çamoc demay.
examples.english: I've spread too much jam on my bread.

examples.vernacular: Panel jattove parlocan y cambr.
examples.english: Teak panels lined the bedroom.

et: from Old Borlish panel "swatch of fabric, rectangle of wood", descending via a Vulgar Latin diminutive from Latin pannus "cloth, rag".
directly from synonymous pāvō in Latin

examples.vernacular: Jo horre sona luïr de paon ne Paçongr.
examples.english: I was worried that I didn't fit in at all.

et: idiom from the nineteenth century, literally meaning "a peacock on Paçongr (Place)". The placename Roðon Paçongr, a major intersection in Borland's capital city Damvath, is a borrowing from the Italian name Pazzongolo; this is presumed to reflect in part the uncommon diminutive -unculus in Latin, but the root is of unknown origin.
Middle Borlish < Medieval Latin, from pap
literally "by (the width of) a scalpel blade"
a borrowing from Old French, a univerbation of par amont "by upward", from Latin per "through" and ad montem "to a mountain; upwards".

examples.vernacular: Il affirmn y paramontað de rigteç sur ley.
examples.english: They assert the primacy of ethics over law.

et: nominal derivation from paramont "supreme, primary". This is a borrowing from Old French, a univerbation of par amont "by upward", from Latin per "through" and ad montem "to a mountain; upwards". The word was originally used in the thirteenth century to describe the relation of the Drengot Emperor over the kings in his demesne.

examples.vernacular: Nos erau y fabr parcorrent set hour.
examples.english: We'd been rehearsing for seven hours.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin percurrō "I run through; I look over", modelling on inherited par- "through" and corrir "to run". In the last sense it is attested from the eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Panel jattove parlocan y cambr.
examples.english: Teak panels lined the bedroom.

examples.vernacular: Enceð a y novel parsemnar ig jo sail oc jorn.
examples.english: Start spreading the news that I'm leaving today.

et: Middle Borlish, either a native derivation of semnar "sow, plant" or directly from a Scholastic Latin perseminō "I sow throughout" (compare cognate pessembrar in Vascon). Almost immediately extended from its agricultural roots, and used of news since the seventeenth century.
from Napolitan persolone "cash prize", augmentative derivation from persolvè "to pay".

examples.vernacular: Scey vigt vecin sart all'oc pascman.
examples.english: This restaurant serves local food.

et: from Middle Borlish (re)pascman "eatery", derivative of repasc "meal" with the vendor suffix -man < Old Borlish manc/ç "shop, vendor". The noun repasc reflects a Late Latin repāscō "I make food, cater", from Classical pāscō "I graze, feast".

examples.vernacular: L'agathin a pat fait sad ag tourf.
examples.english: The minister mishandled the riot.

et: idiomatic phrase attested from the fifteenth century, literally "to do paws" in reference to the unsuitability of many animal's paws for holding things. In metaphorical use the phrase is seen from the seventeenth century.
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin; regularly derived from Vulgar Latin palpetra, variant of Latin palpebra "eyelid, eyebrow".

a particular small coin used on Borland in the early modern period and reintroduced with a different denomination in the late twentieth period. The word descends from synonymous papāver in Latin, of unknown further origin.
a diminutive of pavar "poppy", here referring to a particular small coin used on Borland in the early modern period and reintroduced with a different denomination in the late twentieth period.
originally dialect—either from povr 'poor person' or Paul Alternatively cognate to Portingale chapa < *plapa

examples.vernacular: Il passaurn y ralley par jacas pegr.
examples.english: They spent the afternoon chatting idly.

et: via Old Borlish peir "unintelligent; idle; lazy" from Latin piger "dull, lazy, sluggish; loth, averse". Use of physical appearance is attested from the sixteenth century; in the latter more general senses the word is seen from the early nineteenth century.
Onomatopoeia or from Old French or Vulgar Latin pīssiāre (although this would give piscar).

examples.vernacular: Ag port penoy sign scaunt 'Abseïr Jug'.
examples.english: The sign on the door read 'Keep Out'.

examples.vernacular: Jamay so jo tal vencuð a pengovin.
examples.english: I've never lost like that at pinochle.

et: borrowed into European languages (compare Merch penguin /pɪŋˈgjəwɪn/) in the seventeenth century from Bāsan [Malay] penguwing "pangolin", literally meaning "one who rolls". In the second sense, the word is a calque from Bengal bonoro "pangolin; bezique", apparently named for a deck which featured art of a pangolin on some of the cards.

examples.vernacular: Y gardinner apportau un pal des y pentis.
examples.english: The gardener got a shovel out of the shed.

et: Middle Borlish, borrowed from contemporary French apentis "appendage, attached building". This reflects appendicium, a Medieval Latin variant of Classical appendix "supplement, addition". In the last sense it was originally restricted to military encampments.

examples.vernacular: L'ec voç de nossy felau echovan tras y pereð.
examples.english: Our mates' voices carried through the partition.

et: via Old Borlish pereð, paired "bulkhead" from Latin pariēs "wall". This was outcompeted outside nautical contexts by the descendant of Latin mūrus "wall (orig. of a town or city)". The word's anatomical sense is first attested from the seventeenth century in translation from Scholastic Latin.

examples.vernacular: L'eye doutr y verroil ant deit pernix.
examples.english: She picked the lock with nimble fingers.

et: learned borrowing in the Middle Borlish period from Latin pernix "nimble, agile, swift", thought to be connected with perna "ham, haunch, gammon" (cf. inherited Borlish parn "bacon"), although the expected Latin form would be *pernāx. Its latter sense develops in the eighteenth century under the malign influence of unrelated perniçous "harmful, pernicious, deleterious", from synonymous Latin perniciōsus, a derivative of pernecō "I kill, slay, annihilate".

examples.vernacular: Jo no's deja satisfait dy pestriçon nell'exedr.
examples.english: I'm not yet happy with the anteroom's layout.

et: early Modern Borlish, a noun derivation from verb pestrir "knead; mould, form, shape". Initially referring to the act of kneading dough or moulding clay, the word took on more general senses almost at once.
inherited from Vulgar Latin pistriō "I knead", from Classical pistor "baker".
Old Borlish < Latin, poss paviō "I tread on".
learned borrowing directly from Ancient Greek φάσμα • (phásma) "apparition, phantom, image".

examples.vernacular: Alcun hom nole l'oç od phthongar a caum.
examples.english: Nobody was going to set that ode to music.

et: originally in the first sense and specifically in religious contexts, as of writing choral music whose lyrics were taken from a particular hymn or homily. The term is a borrowing from Scholastic Latin phthongō "I set (to music)", itself from synonymous φθογγῶ • (phthongṓ) in Malchassian Greek. Broadening of the word's senses to other forms of art and writing is seen from the eigteenth century.
Middle Borlish < Vascon pildra < Latin pilula

examples.vernacular: Jo socquau ne my caðer pille cos ajoutað.
examples.english: I sank gratefully into my padded chair.

et: Middle Borlish learned borrowing from Latin pilleus "made of felt; felt cap"; compare inherited pegl "cap, woollen hat". Seen in metaphorical use from the sixteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Y lan a filar se coun pisað cos inequal.
examples.english: The wool to spin was unfairly distributed.

et: from Old Borlish pisar, pesar "to weigh, consider", the combination of the native descendant of Latin pēnsō "I ponder, purchase" (which also gives Modern Borlish pesar "think") along with a secondary verbal derivation from noun pis "weight, measure", from Latin pēnsum "allotment, quota".

examples.vernacular: L'Agathin a Ðar derra nis prestar ag stoccad cas piver.
examples.english: The Farms Minister must consider the livestock lobby.

et: via Old Borlish peȝvair "livestock" from Latin pecuārius "pertaining to sheep or cattle", from pecū "domestic animals". In the last sense attested from the early modern period, especially in constructions like y piver de X "the practical skills required to do X".
Middle Borlish—compound of plat 'flat' and obsolete couf 'covering'
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Sceye un ouç plentivous cant alcun hom parolau.
examples.english: There was a tense silence before anyone spoke.

et: late Middle Borlish, borrowed from French plentiveus "flush, rich". This is a derivation from plentif "abundant" and plenté "abundance", via Latin plēnitās "fullness" from plēnus "full". The emotional senses, attested from the seventeenth century, appear to evoke the danger of an overfull vessel. In scientific use the word is modelled on prior plentað "fullness; (physic) electric charge" (compare the analogous plentiful "charged" in Merch).

examples.vernacular: Nell'oc molin jo ploug jonc vars haidy.
examples.english: In this factory I process cane into rum.

et: from Old Borlish ploȝar "to till, plough" and now-obsolete noun plouȝ "plough", both originally in western dialects and borrowed from Old English plōg "land for ploughing, (later) plough". In its latter senses it is a metaphorical extension from the agricultural use, seen from the fifteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Jo sceu y moment veir de ty plouç souvr.
examples.english: I caught the moment you dropped the act.

et: originally restricted to the first sense, a direct descendant (or via Old French, but the cognate plouce "shutter" is unattested before the twelfth century, and may instead be from Borlish) of Latin pluteus "railing; screen; bookcase". Metaphorical extension to other forms of concealment is attested from the Middle Borlish poetry of Kigman in the fifteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Schol aun lorrell'alumn amenað all'oc plouçastr.
examples.english: Schools have brought classes to this pantomime.

et: nineteenth century, pejorative derivation from plouç "screen, disguise; façade, persona". In the last senses it dates to the 1940s in political criticism.

examples.vernacular: Jo le stim magn pluottað cos nuvr.
examples.english: I think he's really matured recently.

et: originally only in the first sense, a verbal derivative from Old Borlish pluot, pluvot "down feathers, (later) beard stubble". This is a diminutive (possibly via a Kelt form) of plum "feather", from the synonymous plūma in Latin.
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Late Latin
Old Borlish < Latin pōtiō "drink, draught, potion", from pōtō "to drink (liquor)".
Middle Borlish, participle of poçonnar "poison, kill chemically, sterilise, disinfect"
Old Borlish, from poçon "poison, toxin, bane".
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Latin < Ancient Greek
Middle Borlish < Late Latin < Ancient Greek
Old Boral porton, porcon “part, share” < Latin portiō, portiōnem “share, portion”.

examples.vernacular: Ayent dou cougl W e X, un porçonment dy som W + X nommau nos un mission m ant font W e bers X ða casc porçon toc X cos unic.
examples.english: Given two sets W and X, a partition of the sum W + X is called a function m with source W and target X if each part intersects W exactly once.

et: nominalisation of porçonnar, attested from 1650. In mathematics from 1830, originally in translation from Dutch Austeilung “distributing”.

examples.vernacular: Y graðleur porçonaurn y mansc seyon coglt pall'eç joun orphan.
examples.english: The volunteers shared the food they had collected with the orphans here.

et: verb derivation from porçon, ca. 1400. Displaced former partir in this sense.

examples.vernacular: Carra je Naðal oc porrujonnant.
examples.english: Christmas is just round the corner.

et: Middle Borlish verbal derivation of porrujon "balcony, mezzanine" (at the time meaning "overhang, bulge, thrust"). In metaphorical use, seen from the seventeenth century.

examples.vernacular: Ag port penoy sign scaunt 'Abseïr Jug'.
examples.english: The sign on the door read 'Keep Out'.

et: Old Borlish por tan "for so much"

examples.vernacular: Fig a pounçar e faç mey garaf poll'oc gat!
examples.english: Stop flirting and help me with this barrier!

et: originally in the first sense, a verbal derivation from pounç "pumice stone", itself via Norman from synonymous pūmex in Latin. In its archaic sense its usage mirrors others slang terms relating rubbing motions to sexual activity. By the mid-nineteenth century the term had weakened to describe flirtatious behaviour.

examples.vernacular: Nos visau y costroinç de randy præmiar.
examples.english: We aim to incentivise building apartments.

et: borrowed from Scholastic Latin præmiō "I reward, honour", a verbal derivative from præmium "profit, prize, bribe". Though the verb was once poetically used with the person rewarded as the direct object, now only the honourable act itself may take that position.
via Latin prāxis "demonstration" from Greek prâxis "act, deed"

examples.vernacular: Il se courn mariðað pre un cocoro.
examples.english: They got married unexpectedly.

et: idiom attested from the 16th century, literally "before a cockcrow". The noun cocoro "cockcrow", here used figuratively to denote "first light, daybreak, dawn", is assuredly onomatopoeic in origin (as, ultimately, one assumes coq "cock, rooster" was).
Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin praestigium "delusion, magic trick"

examples.vernacular: Caye trencaç yon jo venoy primer n'Ausbagn.
examples.english: It was freezing when I first came to Axbane.

examples.vernacular: Hasiny progentau magn orðenjanç sobottal.
examples.english: Hasiny originated many radio innovations.

et: the verb is an early modern backformation of older progentour "creator". In metaphorical use for causing actions or feelings the word is seen from the early nineteenth century.
Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin prōgenitor "ancestor". This is an agent noun derivation from verb prōgignō "I beget, produce".

examples.vernacular: Capitan, cay uncos inovrant cas y motour prophthan.
examples.english: Captain, something's gone wrong with the warp drive.

et: coined in 1949 by Napolitan author Ludgia Pitceri as awareness of the normal speed entered popular culture and parachthon (fantasy/sci-fi) writers reached for various justifications for speedy interstellar travel. The word is a borrowing from Scholastic Greek προφθάνων • prophthánōn "preceding, overtaking", from φθάνω • phthánō "I precede, overtake". In its imprecise use the word is attested from the 1970s.
Latin prōsa "straightforward" from the term prōsa ōrātiō ("a straightforward speech–i.e. without the ornaments of verse")

examples.vernacular: Y deixist sceu tandem un inquit prose vecinar.
examples.english: Y deixist sceu tandem un inquit prose vecinar.

et: either from Scholastic Latin prōseus "direct" or prōsē "directly", both derivatives of prō(r)sus "direct". This in turn appears to be from the prefix prō- "forward" and Old Latin vorsus "turned". In the last senses the term is attested from the 1920s.
Old Borlish < Late Latin prōpositus, variant of Latin praepositus (“one placed in command”)

examples.vernacular: Con tersur psolic poð l'yeustanç de vin lejar.
examples.english: Sulphites can arrest the fermentation of wine.

et: originally in the latter sense to denote combustion products such as carbon monoxide (in-universe, psolick aphlox), coined by Kievan alchemist Sogut Ranhalov in 1765 and derived from Ancient Greek ψόλος (psólos) "soot, smoke".
via Old Borlish, from Latin pūgiunculus "small dagger, poniard"
borrowed from Old French puie "balustrade, balcony" (whence also English pew), from Latin podium "balcony in an amphitheatre".
Old Borlish < Old Portingale < Late Latin

examples.vernacular: Attenað y zachet vel quaglar oç noit.
examples.english: Wait for the glue to set overnight.

et: direct descendant of Latin coāgulō "I curdle, coagulate", reinforced in the Middle Borlish period by contemporary Portingale or Leon quallo "curds, cottage cheese". The last sense is attested only from the mid-twentieth century and is already rather old-fashioned.

examples.vernacular: Y quallour egreye des y convey posc catr lau.
examples.english: The passenger left the train after eight miles.

et: agentive formation from dialect verb quallar "to ride, travel by horse", which along with qual "horse" are nonstandard variants of covallar and coval in standard Borlish. These all descend from Vulgar Latin caballus "horse", from Gaulish. In latter usages clipped from compounds desc quallour "passenger meal" and plant quallour "passenger plant".

examples.vernacular: Tag enverimmað con mandrin occeyeu ty quanga.
examples.english: Your secretary was poisoned with cyanide-laced tea.

et: borrowed in the Old Borlish period from Old English hwearf "embankment, wharf".
Old Borlish < Old French < Vulgar Latin

examples.vernacular: Cay l'oc convey visað ag quarvol?
examples.english: Is this the train to the airport?

et: early twentieth century, portmanteau of quarvet "(bus, taxi, ferry) station, a stopping place for transportation" and vol "flight".
the exact origin is unclear but most scholars point to Portingale's queimagen "cream cheese" as the earliest-attested variation of the word.

examples.vernacular: Cossy asseïr sull'ig caðer no sera scur quemant.
examples.english: Surely sitting on the chair like that is uncomfortable.

et: present participle of obsolete verb quemar “to be comfortable, to be suitable”, borrowed into Old Boral ca. 9C from Old English cƿēman “to please, to satisfy”.

examples.vernacular: Jo cogleu y quesq y maðuressem dy ranscel.
examples.english: I picked the ripest damson on the branch.

et: from Middle Borlish (prun) quesq "damson (plum)", borrowed from Dutch dialectal queske, queshken "damson". This is a variant of synonymous standard Saxon tweshge and Bavarn zweschen, both borrowed from Vulgar Latin davascena "damascene plum" (cf. Classical damascēnum). In metaphorical use a clipping of phrase quesq a tort "damson in the pie", attested from the seventeenth century.
Old Borlish < Old English / Old Norse

examples.vernacular: Caye l'oç flaðr derran uncos quiðeyant.
examples.english: That last climb was gruelling.

et: the descendant of Old Borlish quiðeȝar "sicken, nauseate; unsettle, rattle, unnerve", derived from dialectal quið "belly, stomach, intestines". This is a borrowing from Old English cwiþ "womb; stomach". The shift in meaning from disgust or emotional disturbance towards hard work is complete by the eighteenth century (although related forms in rural dialects retain some earlier senses).

examples.vernacular: Jo dout ouð y quil çaveyour vel lou incombir.
examples.english: I doubt life on easy street would suit them.

et: directly via Old Borlish quil, coil "bed, cot" from Latin cubīle "bed, couch; lair, kennel"

phrase attested from the early modern period, literally "cushioner bed". This is an early example of a compound-forming construction, much more prevalent in the modern language, which uses agent nouns as modifiers. Use as a mascot for easy living is seen from the nineteenth century, and has persisted likely due to its use in some evergreen folk songs.
Old Borlish < Old French < Medieval Latin < Arabic < Latin
Italian—clipping of loquista 'speaker' from Latin loquor

examples.vernacular: La passau y quoncein par y Novomond aðendrar.
examples.english: She spent her twenties travelling the Americas.

et: twentieth-century calque of Willem quonzerád "young adulthood", an abstract derivation from southern dialect quonze "twenty" (standard twinte); the second element was replaced with the Borlish suffix -ein denoting a number of years (as in dezein "decade", carantein "a period of forty years"), which descends from Latin -ennium "years". Metaphorical extension of the word usually refers either to inexperience and naïveté or to a pinnacle of performance and flourishing.

examples.vernacular: Nos som quondant ag loub cant i se caf tos.
examples.english: We're loitering at the shops while he has a haircut.

et: from Old Borlish quondar, covondar, acquondar et al. "lie in wait, prepare to ambush", appearing to reflect an unattested Vulgar Latin verb *accupābundō from *accupābundus "lurking, hiding, watching animals". This is a confused form influenced by the verbs aucupor "I catch birds or bees" and occupō "I occupy, seize, anticipate" (compare Cambrick achup "save, rescue").

examples.vernacular: Fort alcot i quotta y jacquot me souprene.
examples.english: I was surprised at how well the coat suited him.

et: originally in the third sense, borrowed in the Middle Borlish period from Italian quottare "to be accounted for (in a budget); of a transaction, to succeed" presumably via some financial or trade connection. The Italian is a derivative of Latin quot "how much"—compare the synonymous descendant alcot in Borlish. Generalisation to the first sense occurs from the seventeenth century (and partially displaces existing entrar "go in"); in mathematics it is seen in 1834; the slang sense seems to date back only to the 1980s.

examples.vernacular: Jo me cou battuð d'un hom raðant ag los.
examples.english: I got hit by someone cycling on the pavement.

et: locative derivation from rajogndr "have a meeting"

examples.vernacular: Mell'acquetta er çarvinot ramenant starc.
examples.english: My liqueur tasted strongly of raspberries.

et: borrowed from Old French rang, ranc "position", itself from a descendant either of Classical German rhingas "ring, circle" or of rancas "straight, upright".

examples.vernacular: I trovau launt cant i rancheya y fougl.
examples.english: He found typos while he set the pages.

et: Middle Borlish, verbal derivative of ranc "row, ordered line; rank, caste". Extension from the verb to senses involving arrangements other than into literal rows is seen in the early modern period; in the printing sense it appears in the sixteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Jo cogleu y quesq y maðuressem dy ranscel.
examples.english: I picked the ripest damson on the branch.

et: from Vulgar Latin *rāmuscellum "little branch". This is a double diminutive of Classical rāmus "branch, bough, limb".

examples.vernacular: Dou rout ranscellau n'un bosc gauvn.
examples.english: Two roads diverged in a yellow wood.

et: verbal derivative of ranscel "branch, Y-shape, divergence"

examples.vernacular: Sceye un rasamar de conement pront la y varous cof yert.
examples.english: There was a rush of customers as soon as the shop opened.

et: Middle Borlish, a univerbation of the earlier phrase ras a mar "onrush of sea". The now-obsolete word ras "rush, stampede, running" was borrowed either from Old English or Norse. In metaphorical use the word rasamar is attested from as early as the fifteenth century.

examples.vernacular: J'yemoy scið aïr kes raspað demay sad.
examples.english: I realised I'd grated far too much cheese.

et: twelfth-century borrowing from Old French rasper "scratch, grate", itself from synonymous hraspōn in Frankish. The extension to string playing, as well as the noun raspour "string player", is seen from the late sixteenth century.
Latin rastellum “rake, hoe”, diminutive of rastrum “rake”.

examples.vernacular: Rien va par un bricot nuçal lour rovant, com i fay rastel!
examples.english: There's no point asking him for a wedding present, he's so miserly!

et: “to rake”, via the sense “to waste nothing”, seen from 13C. In the sense “be spendthrift”, it was originally a positive judgement, but by 18C was exclusively used to insult, in the sense “be miserly”.

Unknown. If of Latin origin all of reus "guilty", rabidus "furious" and an unattested *rōdus "slander" (from rōdō "I slander") have been suggested; if German then perhaps some cognate of Markish rough "unkind, rude". Attempts to connect the word to Welsh rhew "frost, disdain" are semantically tempting but otherwise unsubstantiable.

examples.vernacular: Jo sta raussið d'y vec vabian closnautr montar.
examples.english: I was loth to board the rickety bus.

et: past participle of raussir "reverse, invert, flip". In extended use the word is attested from the eighteenth century.
motion verb derivation of now-obsolete raus "backwards", which descends via Old Borlish reaus, rears from Latin reversus "returned".

examples.vernacular: Banc redirigent machinal receveurn magn aversion.
examples.english: Automated redirection banks were met with significant opposition.

examples.vernacular: Jo recuida jamay noiteyar n'un davarn.
examples.english: I realised I'd never stayed in a resort.

et: Middle Borlish coinage derived from cuidar "think, suppose, intend". This descends directly from Latin cōgitō "I think, reflect, have in mind". The extension in Borlish to deduction is attested from the 18th century.

examples.vernacular: Banc redirigent machinal receveurn magn aversion.
examples.english: Automated redirection banks were met with significant opposition.

examples.vernacular: Jo stim y lasc rediveu cos outr.
examples.english: I find the film totally unoriginal.

et: borrowing from Latin redivīvus "resurrected, second-hand" modelled on vīvus > Middle Borlish veu "living" (now obsolete). Metaphorical extension is seen from the late eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: I pegntau toð y lettranç ag reðrpuy meðes.
examples.english: She even painted all the backtound text.

et: originally in the last sense, from reðr "behind" and puy "aisle, walkway, gangway". In extended use the word is attested from the eighteenth century.
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Vulgar Latin

examples.vernacular: Y reloðeç ag tarner sta aplattiscent.
examples.english: The host's gentility was irritating.

et: noun derivative of reloð "fine, fancy, refined", which descends uncomplicatedly via Old Borlish from Vulgar Latin relautus "elegant, splendid, fashionable". This is a variant of synonymous lautus, which is an adjectival derivative of lavō "I wash, clean".
Middle Borlish < Old French < Classical German
Middle Borlish < Italian < Vulgar Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Jo vil molir an requïçon idoneyessem de my caf d'an posc.
examples.english: I'll ask my boss for a more convenenient weekend next year.

et: originally restricted to religious use, borrowed from Latin requiētiō "rest, repose" and modelled on verb requïr "to rest, be comforted". In the modern era the three weekends Fri-Sat, Sat-Sun and Sun-Mon are recognised by law in Borland (in line with the rest of the former Drengot Collusion and many other polities).
Middle Borlish from Latin requiēscō "I rest", modelled in quïr "to extinguish".

examples.vernacular: Y kenonaut vil casc meis volar retrasiscent entr y Tar eð y Lun.
examples.english: The spaceship will fly back and forth between the Earth and the Moon each month.

et: present participle of retrasir “to cross back over”

examples.vernacular: Se poð jo nolois cavir validað ag reu.
examples.english: I might lack the prereqs for the course.

et: from Old Borlish riu "stream, small river", from the synonymous rīvus in Latin. First attested in the scholastic sense from eighteenth-century student slang at the Vithor New School, and in the last senses first applied to tachygraph casting in the twentieth.
20C, from reu "stream, channel, feed" < Latin rīvus "small river" and a derivative of boðar "signal, transmit, communicate" < Old English bodian "announce, foretell".

examples.vernacular: L'oc baðrment a hoissar es my reu de við.
examples.english: This wind ensemble is my calling.

et: idiom attested in Borlish since the fifteenth century, adapted from slightly earlier Latin rīvus vitae "stream of life". Originally in the earlier senses; extended to general predictable behaviours via law enforcement in the nineteenth century.
idiom attested from the eighteenth century, literally "flip of the card" and taken from gambling jargon.

examples.vernacular: Y jonglour fey l'ig bal yemois reunt.
examples.english: The magician made the ball reappear.

et: present participle of reuvr "come back, return, turn over, flip, do again, repeat".
via Old Borlish reouvre from Latin revolvō "I unroll, repeat", from volvō "I roll, tumble".
Scholastic Latin revectō "I bring upon myself".
alteration of earlier raivot, diminutive of now-obsolete raif "rage", which descends from Late Latin rabia "rage"

examples.vernacular: J'oye un revottaç allors nell'oc varosset.
examples.english: I heard a tantrum elsewhere in the shop.

et: pejorative derivation from revot "annoyance, irritation". The word is considered impolite as a description of an adult's behaviour.
Middle Borlish < Late Latin < Ancient Greek
idiosyncratic (perhaps onomatopoetic) diminutive formation from Old Borlish verb rir "laugh" (now obsolete), from Late Latin rīdō "I laugh" (cf. synonymous rīdeō in Classical Latin).

examples.vernacular: Stou ty sour convoccar dec i's tan ricottabr.
examples.english: You should invite your sister; she's so funny.

et: derivative via the -abr "-able" suffix of verb ricottar "laugh".

examples.vernacular: Nos erau flannant lonc y rif, ig carnt yon beller acatar.
examples.english: We were walking down the strand, looking to buy sweets.

et: uncomplicated descendant via Old Borlish rif from Latin rīpa "riverbank, seashore". By the Middle Borlish period we see a clear semantic separation between sandy play "beach, bay" and stony rif, although some place names like Volandry (from dialect volan "gull" and rif "beach") fail to fit this dichotomy.

examples.vernacular: I save cojan alcot volen y cançon accis par y roç.
examples.english: He knew how boring the cabbie's music would be.

et: early 20C from Napolitan rozzo "cabbie", further origin disputed. Formally identical with earlier rozzo "boor, lout", from Latin adjective rudis "rough, unskilled, rude", but this term seems to have been obsolete by the mid-19th century. Occasionally identified with dialect ruzza "wheel", from Latin rotula "small wheel, scroll".

examples.vernacular: J'er nuvr sortið cant cou roçon.
examples.english: I'd just left when it started drizzling.

et: hybrid form attested from the thirteenth century, combining rosað < Vulgar Latin rōsāta "dew" with rorçon < Latin rōrātiō "dewfall", both from rōs "dew".
from Old Borlish romnç "shard, piece broken off something", a derivation of rompre "to break".

examples.vernacular: Cay un ronç cadarað d'ougl tascban.
examples.english: It's an extract of vanilla flavouring.

et: phrase meaning "distilled portion", first attested in the sixteenth century. The noun ronç "portion, part, component; fraction, ratio" descends from Old Borlish romnç "shard, piece broken off something", a derivation of rompre "to break". The adjective cadarað is the past participle of cadarar "to distil", a late medieval borrowing from Spanish related to Arabic قطرات <qaṭarāt> “droplets”, in reference to the process of distillation.
Middle Borlish; from the fifteenth century as rom-caf "breaks the head".

examples.vernacular: Y rostr a my creðon es coroccað.
examples.english: The tip of my pencil has snapped.

et: an uncomplicated descendant from Latin rōstrum "bill, beak, snout, muzzle; prow". The latter meanings are thought to derive from the anatomical senses of the Latin word. Extension from boats to other vehicles and then into metaphorical usage occured during the Middle Borlish period.

examples.vernacular: L'agent dy Majon Roug souseyeu l'ig scard commoðer.
examples.english: The Red House agent dealt with that resistance group.

et: from Latin rōbur via Insular form rōbolem formed by dissimilation

Middle Borlish routur, which originally referred to a small quantity of land as might be granted to or owned by a common farming household. This descends from Latin ruptūra "fracture, rupture, breach; (later) a division of land".

examples.vernacular: Lorrell'heir desir un routuron mariðar.
examples.english: Their son wants to wed a commoner.

et: Middle Borlish derivative of routur "vulgarity, working-class quality" (compare late Medieval Latin ruptūrō "freeman"). Outside of historical texts, the term is usually metaphorical or jocular.
Middle Borlish < Middle Dutch < Classical German
a 19C backformation (based on analogy to the adjectival -ic ending) from rubicon "sports, athletic activity".

an 18C folk-etymological form (evoking the idiom y Rubicon trasir "to pass the point of no return; to start a fight"), possibly via a French or English language, from Willem Dutch robicong "competition, sport, athletics". This is a compound of rob "fight, contest, brawl" and iken "to be compared, compete".

examples.vernacular: Jo ney a l'oc run final yembr ny scarrad yarcer.
examples.english: I can't get the last letter in this crossword.

et: originally in the last sense, descending from Old Borlish run /ryn/ "rune". This was borrowed either from Old Norse rún "secret, rune" or Old English rūn "mystery, rune". In the Middle Borlish period this word retained senses like "magic spell" and "talisman", but these became obsolete in the sixteenth century (although derivatives like runam "secretly" and runastr "sorcerer" survive to the modern day).

examples.vernacular: Nos erau runam alleyant con lou commet a fin.
examples.english: We were secretly on their side the whole time.

et: from Middle Borlish runam "by magic, using sorcery; in secret, hidden from view" (the semantic shift mirroring that of "occult"). This is a derivative of contemporary run "symbol, spell, talisman" using the now-unproductive adverbial suffix -am, descending from Latin anima "soul" (compare kireðam "wholeheartedly", coram "in person").

examples.vernacular: Ja ou vos ignorað comoscon y runastr l'acavau?
examples.english: Do you still not know how the magician did it?

et: Middle Borlish, derivative of run "magic spell, talisman" with the pejorative suffix -astr < Latin -aster "resembling, quasi-" (compare contemporaneous but now obsolete runart "sorcerer"). Originally restricted to those doing evil or harm with magic, the word had become a generic word for a magic user by the late eighteenth century. In the last senses it is seen in slang from the early twentieth century.

from Old Borlish rupp "tear in fabric, run, fraying", deverbal of ruppar "(of fabric) to tear, fray, run" (now obsolete). This is presumably cognate with Merch rippen "to tear, rip", although no Old English form is attested.

examples.vernacular: Me storra Janvier passar con gent rustr.
examples.english: I'll have to spend January among rustics.

et: from Old Borlish rustre "rural", either directly from Latin rūsticus "rural" or via synonymous rustre in Old French. The insulting senses date as far back as Classical times, and may have been reintroduced during the Middle Borlish period.

examples.vernacular: Saðour sialler seraun sacr sy seucq saufgardant.
examples.english: Rye farmers will be vital to securing his legacy.

et: originally in the first senses, a Middle Borlish reborrowing from Latin sacer "sacred, holy". With these meanings the words is mostly confined to idioms, collocations (y Bibr Sacr "the Holy Bible") and poetry, supplanted by words like sacrað and sagntað "holy". In the last senses the word was briefly popular in the mid-twentieth century and it is occasionally still used (alongside the comparative sacherrem which saw similar use somewhat later) to evoke the period.
from Latin sacro "I make sacred", related to sacr "holy".

examples.vernacular: Sy benjamin a cedr sta imminuð sad.
examples.english: He'd overdone the cedarwood perfume.

examples.vernacular: Nos vaun saget forgar n'adamantin ou?
examples.english: Are titanium arrowheads worth it?

et: Old Borlish saget "arrow", a semi-learned form reflecting Latin sagitta "arrow, shaft, bolt". The term was displaced in referring to the whole arrow by Germanic loan flesc "arrow". Metaphorical extensions are seen first in heraldic descriptions; the computing sense dates to the late twentieth century.
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Italian < Classical German

examples.vernacular: J'abhoir cont de heros saluberrem.
examples.english: I despise tales of virtuous heroes.

et: Middle Borlish, borrowed directly from Latin salūber "healthy, beneficial". The terms has been applied to moral goodness almost from the moment of its first attestation in Borlish. In the monetary sense the word has been used since the eighteenth century.
directly from Latin sanguis "blood" (albeit from a Vulgar oblique form like sanguem rather than Classical sanguinem).

examples.vernacular: Y cociner ença voug cas hojol ne sarzin.
examples.english: The cook was terrible at buckwheat pancakes.

et: in its only surviving modern sense, a clipping of the earlier bla sarzin "Saracen wheat" which is first attested in the fifteenth century, in reference to its eastern origin (the plant having been brought to Europe via the Turkish Riyalid Sultanate or possibly via Russian Cazany).

examples.vernacular: Theorist prevein un collijon par sax d'an 2026.
examples.english: Scientists predict an asteroid impact in 2026.

et: 1813, a borrowing from Latin saxum "stone, rock", used as a calque from synonymous tsa'ra in Mashick Arabic. The term was originally used to describe the various apparently-pointlike bodies in the cisjovial ring, which at that time were being discovered by telescope. The first celestial body this word was applied to, Ixion [Ceres], is now known to be spherical under gravity and so is no longer considered to be a sax. In modern usage saxes include comets, although knowledge of comets dates back to antiquity.
Old Borlish < Medieval Latin < Frankish < Classical German

examples.vernacular: Jo cur bogr yon nis sbolognar.
examples.english: I don't care whose fault it is.

examples.vernacular: Stou a casc lusour y pachet fort sborreyar.
examples.english: Each player should shuffle the deck well.

et: early modern Borlish, borrowed from northern dialect. The word is a verbal derivative of rural term borr "tuft, burr, clump", which descends from Latin burra "ragged garment, coarse fragment". The prefix s- < Latin ex- is somewhat pejorative; the verbal ending comes from -idiō in Vulgar Latin.
from Moorish Arabic (arab moresc) شطم <sheit·om> “tomato”, itself from the Classical Nahuatl (nawat normal) for “tomato”, scitomatl.

examples.vernacular: A Portingal fo un method novel, ant carn aromað ne saus de scadom pisað.
examples.english: In Portingale there was a new recipe, with spiced meat in a tomato sauce.

examples.vernacular: Me stou for savir ig nos seim scaðr den.
examples.english: I want to know we're on the same page.

et: from Old Borlish iscaðre, iscarre, carre "square", from Vulgar Latin (ex)quadra "square", variant form of post-Classical quadrus "square". Adjectival usage attested from as early as the eleventh century.

examples.vernacular: Oc voscon accommis va contr y scagl a natur.
examples.english: What you've done is against the natural order of things.

et: literally "nature's staircase", derived in the Middle Borlish period from the Scholastic Latin scāla nātūrae "the Great Chain of Being" (literally, the ladder of nature). This is the theological concept of the hierarchy of all matter and life, thought by medieval Christianity to have been decreed by God, and adapted from similar ideas in Platonic and Aristotelian philosophy.
Old Borlish from Latin scandō "I climb"

examples.vernacular: Ty dois tach novel es un scanjon ou?
examples.english: Is your new smartphone an upgrade?

et: noun from scandr "rise, climb" or directly from Latin scansiō "a climbing". The word is attested in metaphorical uses from the sixteenth century, and in its specifically economic sense it is seen from the nineteenth century.

examples.vernacular: L'agent dy Majon Roug souseyeu l'ig scard commoðer.
examples.english: The Red House agent dealt with that resistance group.

et: Middle Borlish < Old French < Medieval Latin < Arabic
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Classical German
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Vulgar Latin

examples.vernacular: Orruð ig scerra alcheðr un parolment scaug.
examples.english: It seems there'll be another hung parliament.

et: a borrowing from early Middle English shawe, scaȝe "thicket", from synonymous sceaga in Old English. Extended metaphorically to any tangle by the fifteenth century, and in adjectival use since the seventeenth. In its legal and political senses it is attested from the Global Workshop period.
Middle Borlish < Old French < Late Latin

examples.vernacular: Ag port penoy sign scaunt 'Abseïr Jug'.
examples.english: The sign on the door read 'Keep Out'.

examples.vernacular: L'oç segr es dignt tojorn i vil scaur ag mur ne Pompeï.
examples.english: That guy's always saying he'll make a name for himself.

ge: write one's name in the history books
rearrange deck chairs on the Titanic
et: literally "to write on the walls of Pompeii", first attested as an idiom in Napolitan some years after the unearthing of the ruins of Pompeii and the uncovering of its trove of graffiti. The last sense, attested in Borlish since the 1920s, refers directly to the volcanic eruption of 79N which buried the city.

examples.vernacular: Y lasc es l'administraçon dy dezein 70 scavlant.
examples.english: The film's satirising the government of the 70s.

et: Middle Borlish, verbal derivation from scavre, scavle "reflection, mirror image" (exemplifying the confusion regarding final -re/-le which affected contemporary Borlish).

from Old Borlish scaure "mirror, mirror image; actor, performer", borrowed from Old English sċēawere "observer, watchman; mirror; jester, buffoon" (compare Saxon shower /ˈʃɔ.wɐ/ "mirror"). This is an agentive derivative of sċēawian "watch, look at".

examples.vernacular: J'admet ig no scey l'augrim a nacleu ne sce de mey.
examples.english: I admit differential calculus isn't in my wheelhouse.

et: originally (and now only historically) in the first senses, descending via Old Borlish sce, sie "see, (arch)diocese" from Latin sedes "seat; residence; (Late Latin) episcopal see". Broadening to more general locations occurred in tandem with the import of cathedral to replace most of the religious senses.
formerly sometimes re-classicised as scæn, borrowed from Latin scæna "stage, scenery" from Ancient Greek σκηνή "tent, stage". In metaphorical use seen from the eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Y tissour aun un exeunt scenað.
examples.english: The weavers have staged a walkout.

et: Middle Borlish verbal derivation from scen "(theatre) stage; platform, soapbox" (formerly sometimes re-classicised as scæn)

examples.vernacular: L'actour fey exeunt voud dy scenoir.
examples.english: The actor stormed out of the studio.

et: twentieth century, derivative of scenar "stage (a play), film (a movie)" with the place-forming suffix -oir < -ōrium in Latin. In metaphorical use the term is seen (first in media criticism) from the 1960s.
Old Borlish < Old English < Classical German
attested from 10C as skolar, scholair “pertaining to academia”.  Derived from schol “school, academia” + the adjectival -er suffix, itself from Latin -ārius with the same meaning.

examples.vernacular: Cain entrquïsc n'hour scið par y liesc quic.
examples.english: Breaks are at set times during the workday.

et: from Old Borlish scið "known, determined", a direct descendant from Latin scītus "learnt, known, appointed". This was the perfect participle of both sciō "I know" and scīscō "I learn". The last senses reflect the word's Borlish use as the suppletive past participle of poðir "to be able to", whose past tense, imperfect subjunctive and past participle were replaced with forms from sciō in the Old Borlish period. In early use the "fixed" sense was used principally to refer to certain Christian feast days and canonical hours.

examples.vernacular: J'ay my pan sciftað a çamoc demay.
examples.english: I've spread too much jam on my bread.

et: from Old Borlish sciftar "to arrange, tidy", borrowed from Old English sciftan "divide, apportion, arrange". Specialisation to senses to do with layering is seen from the sixteenth century, likely by analogy with making the bed.

examples.vernacular: Nos s'yettaum por scap fair dell'eç scobr.
examples.english: We sprinted away from the explosions.

et: from Old Borlish scoble, scople "explosion", from a Vulgar Latin form scoplus which shows metathesis from scloppo "slap"; compare Tuscan schioppo "gun", Barcelon esclop "woodblock".

examples.vernacular: Jo poðe noc me quottar ag scop dy trevold parachthon.
examples.english: I couldn't get on board with the sci-fi novel's conceit.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from Tuscan scopo "purpose, point", which descends from Latin scopus "target". This was borrowed from σκοπός • skopós "watcher; target" in Ancient Greek. The second sense is attested from the seventeenth century; the last only in literary criticism of the twentieth.

examples.vernacular: Torn all'An ne Deganny interman un cainç scroçabr.
examples.english: New Year's in Deganny is a harrowing experience.

et: derivative of scroçar "to agonise, torment, vex". The last senses are disliked by some but is attested from the early nineteenth century.
direct descendant via Old Borlish from synonymous excruciō "I torture" (related to cruciō "I crucify"). The last senses are disliked by some but is attested from the early nineteenth century.
Medieval Latin scrutiniosus "inquiring, investigatory" < scrutinium "inquiry" < Latin scrutor "I search thoroughly"

examples.vernacular: Rey Ambrosc commandau casc vascel portn frugt sandrin, ma stoveurn moneð demay.
examples.english: King Ambrose required each ship to carry citrus fruits, but the cost was too high.

et: Old Boral skurvuȝ et al., presumably from Old Norse skyrbjúgr “sour-milk tumour”. Discovered in the late 15C to be caused by diet, following the famed voyage to Mendeva of Princess Alexandra of Vascony (the first time a European royal set foot in the Novomund), after whom sandrine is indirectly named.

examples.vernacular: A sy lasc novel scey un tombr a sdegn.
examples.english: Her new film's garnered lots of criticism.

et: deverbal noun from sdegnar "scorn, malign". The word nowadays often connotes that the criticism is undeserved (compare the phrase sdegn accarr "to be wrongly criticised").
derivative of archaic degnar "deign, condescend, begrudge", which comes from Latin dignō "I deem worthy".

examples.vernacular: Salað y vec ag hal sdroy.
examples.english: Get off the bus at the depot.

et: first attested in the late medieval period as isdroȝ "freight, goods in transport over water; (especially) goods in the maritime trade mesh of the Stadbund [a group of cities in northern Germany and the surrounding regions]", borrowed from synoymous zdruog in contemporary Saxon. This is likely from Polish zdroi "(water) spring, small stream; origin, source, place to find something", though this word's sense development appears to be due to Saxon influence.

examples.vernacular: L'a echo vardið ny sdroyet por reðrtien.
examples.english: She's got backup copies on the drive.

et: diminutive of noun sdroy "depot, warehouse, stockpile", first attested in Middle Borlish isdroȝ "freight, goods transported by water". This was borrowed via synoymous zdruog in contemporary Saxon, likely from Polish zdroi "spring, small stream; origin, source". The historical and modern senses are presumed to be independent derivations; the latter first appears over a century after the former became practically obsolete.
deverbal from sdruçollar "slip, slide; glide, skate"
borrowing from synonymous sdrucciolare in Italian. This apparently reflects a Vulgar Latin *exderoteolāre, from rota "wheel".

examples.vernacular: Posc resoum nos y fastig, nos arreu se corruð contrell'yarn.
examples.english: Once we fix the roof, we'll be set for winter.

et: past participle of se corrir "make it, survive, get through, succeed", the reflexive of corrir "run". Idiomatic use of this phrase is seen from the fifteenth century poetry of Manuel Kigman. The phrase appears to have originally referred to simply being well-off or comfortable; semantic association with the verb has more recently given the idiom connotations of past struggle and present battle-readiness.

examples.vernacular: Nos se ponau voud a sy vellisqment dehiscn.
examples.english: We looked forward to his plans falling apart.

et: via Middle Borlish from Latin sēcrētus

examples.vernacular: Nos som travodant posc je semman ados!
examples.english: We've been in negotations since last week!

examples.vernacular: Il parmettoirn nos entraum semprað.
examples.english: They cheerfully let us come in.

et: past participle of semprar “to be cheerful, to celebrate” (now only in certain dialects), from some variant of the salutation sempr! “always!”, traditionally said at feasts and other get-togethers.
Old Borlish, from Vulgar Latin singluttus "sob, hiccup", a alteration of synoynmous singultus in Classical Latin under the influence of gluttiō "I swallow, gulp".

examples.vernacular: L'er resoluð a casc senglottaç ignorar.
examples.english: He was bent on ignoring any criticism.

et: nineteenth century derivative from senglot or the related verb senglottar "sob, sigh, lament". Metaphorical use is attested from the early twentieth century.
twelfth century, verbal derivation from senglot "sob".
Old Borlish < Insular Latin < Borland Kelt

examples.vernacular: Nuvr so jo my seucq historic molinant.
examples.english: Lately I have been contemplating my legacy.

et: collocation first seen in legal use in the eighteenth century, originally referring to certain inherited effects. The adjective historic "historical" is a direct borrowing from Latin historicus, while the noun seucq "footpath, trail, tracks; legacy, progeny" is murkier. It descends from Borland Latin silqua, sēlqua "track (of an animal)", though to be olf Kelt origin.

examples.vernacular: J'er un pom sgranfeyant cos pegr.
examples.english: I was idly munching on an apple.

et: seventeenth century, derived from the root gran "grain, seed" with the somewhat-pejorative prefix s- < Latin ex- "out" and the factitive suffix -feyar < Latin -ficō "I make". The word was first used to refer to eating a century after its first attestation.
Old Borlish < Old French < Vulgar Latin < Latin

examples.vernacular: Ag port penoy sign scaunt 'Abseïr Jug'.
examples.english: The sign on the door read 'Keep Out'.

et: Old Borlish < Old French < Vulgar Latin

examples.vernacular: Val y signal ou "Abseïr Jug" ben "Skig Acceir"?
examples.english: Should the sign say "Keep Out" or "No Entry"?

et: Old Borlish iskiȝar "to flee, escape"; compare synonymous eschiver in Old French and sċīen "fear, recoil, startle" in Old English, all descending from Classical German sciuhas "frightened, timid, shy".
