The last senses are now by far the most common, originally a colloquial alternative for prohibitive constructions but now ubiquitous.

examples.vernacular: Y pescot e skillet n'Ausçagm son ragostant.
examples.english: The fish and chips in Ausçagm is delicious.

et: early modern Borlish, apparently from Kernish askleut or Devoner skylot "chips, shavings, splinters". These both descend from Classical British asclod "splinter", a borrowing from Late Latin ascla which itself is a variant of Classical assula "splinter". The word was first applied to foods in the seventeenth century and had specialised to starches like potatoes by the nineteenth.
Old Borlish islargir, from larc "broad" < largus

examples.vernacular: L'er mell'yam sleghant avant my rau!
examples.english: He was shamelessly slandering my uncle!

et: via Old Borlish isler "elect" from Vulgar Latin exligō (Classical ēligō "I pick, choose, elect").

examples.vernacular: Nos slengettaum pegnt gauvn sull'ec stig de hey.
examples.english: We slathered yellow paint onto the fenceposts.

et: originally in the first senses, attested along with the related noun slenget "snog, make-out session" in the late eighteenth century. It applies the somewhat pejorative verbal derivation s- -ar and the diminutive suffix -et to the root lenc "tongue" < Latin lingua "tongue". The first metaphorical extensions are each attested from the early twentieth century; in the sense of "meddle" it is an innovation of the last couple of decades.
past participle of verb sleir "to elect, to vote for". The noun was used almost immediately as a somewhat derogatory term for anyone perceived to act in the manner of a politician.
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Ancient Greek

derivation from the verb snuvlar, which had become obsolete by the seventeenth century. This descends from Old Borlish isnuvlar, a borrowing from Old English snyflan "to have a runny nose". In the latter sense the phrase is attested from the eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: No stou bogr snuvr fair dell'oç cæros.
examples.english: The opportunity's nothing to sniff at.

examples.vernacular: Par y sobot coum nos addoit dy cainç.
examples.english: We heard the news on the radio.

et: 1910, backformation from the somewhat-earlier adjective (1904 boðour sobottal "radio transmitter", 1907 œculux sobottal "radio waves").

Attested in Borlish from 1904. The technology having been invented in Hasiny, the word was borrowed indirectly (probably via Vascon) from Hasinick Welsh sobotał "signal, message". This in turn comes from Jaughta çobota "smoke; message", after the practice of sending signals via smoke.

examples.vernacular: Jo soccos my jacquot avant y foyer ne spien i sechisceus un poy.
examples.english: I shook my coat in front of the fire so that it might dry out a bit.

et: Old Borlish < Latin succutiō “I shake, I fling” with usual collapse of the -iō verb class. Compare French secouer “to shake”.

examples.vernacular: Nos eum enfugr pront la nos fom soccos destr.
examples.english: We had to run as soon as we were rumbled.

et: past participle of soccoðr des "to shake out of; to unmask". The verb soccoðr "shake, mix up" descends directly from Latin succutiō "toss up, fling into the air". The adverb destr "out of there" reflects Latin dē "from" and exter "on the outside".
Old Borlish, borrowing from Latin somnifer "sending one to sleep", from somnus "sleep".
from thespian slang in the early modern period, a clipping of Latin persōna "mask; character, part, role".
Middle Borlish < Old French < Old English

examples.vernacular: Y costoscment aun l'hom sont vecinað.
examples.english: The police have found the guilty party.

et: borrowed from Latin sōns "guilty, criminal" in the early Middle Borlish period for legal use. Unrelated to sont "seventh" [1], with which it may be distinguished by word order (this latter always appears before the noun).

examples.vernacular: Desmettað noc y sontiçtað de nossell'entrpris!
examples.english: Don't fire the backbone of our company!

et: borrowed from Scholastic Latin sonticitās "urgency, exigency" or a derivation within Middle Borlish from sontic "urgent, critical". The word has been used to refer to a necessary thing or person since the eighteenth century.
idiom attested from the eighteenth century, literally "under covered darkness"; probably formed by analogy to preexisting sou ciel ovart "in plain view", literally "under open sky".
from Latin succurrō "I help, aid, succour", adapted synchronically to the etymological sou- "under" prefix and corrir "run" root.

examples.vernacular: Vos souspectað y soucorsour ou cas y vol?
examples.english: Do you suspect the lifeguard of the theft?

et: iddle Borlish, an agentive derivation from verb soucorrir "rescue, go and help, come to the aid of". The historical sense had been out of use for approximately two centuries before the modern senses appear, and so the latter are presumably an independent rederivation.
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Portingale < Arabic
Old Borlish, a deverbal of soumonir "prompt, remind"

examples.vernacular: Nos veleu soumoin jair a nossy conemour.
examples.english: We'd like to shout out our patrons.

et: idiom meaning "to throw reference" attested from the seventeenth century.
Old Borlish < Latin summoneō "I privately advise, give a hint".

examples.vernacular: Y sounç d'abat interromoy eç accommission corrogaçonnal.
examples.english: War breaking out interrupted those infrastructure projects.

et: nominal derivative from verb souvr "solve, let go, release, launch", from solvō "I loosen, untie"; or, directly from a Latin noun solventia "a loosening, an untying". In the last sense attested from as early as the eighteenth century in erotic literature; the term continues to be dispreferred in formal or technical contexts.

examples.vernacular: Nos som plait de l'ambit agathiner vos soupleyar.
examples.english: We are proud to grant you the ministerial post.

et: via Old Borlish sopleir "fill up, furnish, supply, provide" (later conflated with sopleȝar "require, take, consider necessary") from synonymous suppleō in Latin. Used for gifts originally in the context of granting land and titles to people.
Old Borlish souple < Old French < Latin supplex "supplicant"

examples.vernacular: Fort alcot i quotta y jacquot me souprene.
examples.english: I was surprised how well the coat suited him.

examples.vernacular: Toð y volcan sur Istr Boral souquondn tras millenner.
examples.english: Toð y volcan sur Istr Boral souquondn tras millenner.

et: Middle Borlish, derivation with the prefix sou "under, below" from the root aquondar, covondar et al. "lie in wait, ambush". The botanical sense is attested from the seventeenth century, and the medical sense from the nineteenth. The last senses appear to have arisen in journalistic circles within the past few decades.

examples.vernacular: L'agent dy Majon Roug souseyeu l'ig scard commoðer.
examples.english: The Red House agent dealt with that resistance group.

et: from Middle Borlish, a borrowing from Latin subsīdō "I crouch, subside" modelled on other verbs in -seïr like asseïr "dwell" and posseïr "own". First attested in the latter two senses in the seventeenth century, in early use seen particularly in the context of diplomatic disputes.

examples.vernacular: Jo poðe noc discernir cal seyon sousonnað.
examples.english: I couldn't tell what she was implying.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin subsonō "I express secretly".
borrowed from Scholastic Latin substantia "substance", a derivative of substō "I exist; (literally) I stand under".

examples.vernacular: Jo's stuðant vars theorist soustançal denir.
examples.english: I'm studying to be a materials scientist.

dv: pertaining to matter or to properties of matter
et: borrowed from Scholastic Latin substantiālis "of or pertaining to substance", a derivative of substō "I exist; (literally) I stand under". Used to refer to a particular branch of science at the intersection of physics and chemistry since the nineteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Y rimband ag fruyour souvolaurn apar.
examples.english: The dancer's ribbons swept through the air.

et: borrowing from Latin subvolō "I fly upwards from below", adapted to existing sou- "under" and volar "fly". In metaphorical use the word is attested from the eighteenth century; in a theatrical context it is seen from 1888, originally in use by a specific school of acting in Axbane.

examples.vernacular: Scey un spaiðoir scos ne sy tablaur.
examples.english: Her desk has a secret drawer.

et: sixteenth-century derivative of verb spaiðar "slide, scrape" with the locative suffix -oir, which comes from -tōrium in Latin. The verb is an Old Borlish derivative of paið "floor, smooth surface", which directly reflects Latin pavītum "beaten, trodden upon" from paviō "I beat, ram, tread down". In figurative use the word is seen from the late eighteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Nos survism y spanjon dy quaðeglad.
examples.english: We oversaw the campus extension.

et: noun derivation from spandr "expand, spread, broaden, explain" or directly from Latin expansio "an instance of spreading out". The metaphorical senses of expansion are partially modelled after use of the term in Scholastic Latin.
Old Borlish < Latin, poss influenced by medieval past tense disperuit
pejorative noun derivation from spoiðar "use up, deplete", from poið "well, source".
19C, backformation from a squid "on the take", from contemporary Welsh á sguyd "with a (hand)shake", a derivative of verb sguyd "shake, toss, tremble".
a direct borrowing from Saxon staddenzen, respelt to align with existing Borlish denzan "local, denizen, citizen".
from Old French estanc, from a verb deriving from Vulgar Latin *stānticāre < *stānticus < stāns "standing"

examples.vernacular: Mell'acquetta er çarvinot ramenant starc.
examples.english: My liqueur tasted strongly of raspberries.

examples.vernacular: Sy morrig es steðig sad cas theu.
examples.english: Her aunt's very set in her ways.

et: descendant of late Old Borlish steðiȝ "stable, constant", borrowed from an early Middle English or Middle Dutch derivative of a cognate of stead "place, position". Initially describing strong convictions, the word has been extended to describe people with such convictions since the seventeenth century.
deverbal of stivar “to load, to stuff, to crowd”, from Latin stīpō “I crowd, I compress”.

examples.vernacular: Jo dorme prell'hour un ; nos ayau tout stif jacent dy Fest Reveglon.
examples.english: I was asleep before one; we were all sleepily stuffed from the Christmas meal.

et: Refers to the sleepy state one enters when one has eaten perhaps too much food.

examples.vernacular: Con un stig de remors jo ðureu y pistol.
examples.english: With a pang of regret I burned the letter.

et: from Old Borlish stii, stiȝ "stitch, stabbing pain", a borrowing from synonymous stiġe in Borland Old English. This is a variant of stiċe "stitch", which descends from Classical German sticis "prick, poke, a sticking". For more general pains the word is attested since the sixteenth century, and for emotions it is seen soon afterward.
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Old French < Old Dutch < Classical German
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Old French < Old Dutch < Classical German
from Portingale estivador "stevedore", from estivar < Italitan stivare "to load" (cf. Borlish stivar "to stuff, cram")

examples.vernacular: L'indrec son stoccadant vars parroc demosin.
examples.english: The charity is lobbying for public parks.

et: verbal derivative from stoccad "a lunge, thrust" either in Middle Borlish or in the synonymous French estoccade, estoccader before their adoption into Borlish. In either case the noun comes from Italian stoccato "thrust", past participle of stoccar "to thrust (with a sword)", itself from now-obsolete stocco "rapier, shortsword". This noun, which is a borrowing from Dutch stooken "to poke, stab", is reflected in Borlish stoc "truncheon, club".

examples.vernacular: Jo groça y stoir geoscopic de my fraðr.
examples.english: I envied my brother's globe-trotting tales.

examples.vernacular: Me stou fort y lasc laçar cant i's n'odysse.
examples.english: I really want to see the film while it's on.

et: from Old Borlish istover "be necessary", a verbal derivation of istof "obligaton, necessity, need". This is a univerbation of Latin phrase est opus "there is need". The shift to less urgent wants is relatively recent, occuring over the course of the nineteenth century. Stovir still connotes stronger desire than the alternative construction desirar "to want" (colloquially 'sirar), which sees more use for polite requests.

examples.vernacular: Sceyen tor doç stuðant ny reu.
examples.english: There were about twelve students on the course.

et: Old Borlish stuðant "student", present participle of stuðar "excel, shine, be skilled; learn, practice, improve, train" influenced by Latin studēns "dedicating oneself to, studying".

a derivative of stuð "clever, intelligent, skilled; interested, engaged, paying attention" (now obsolete outside of fixed expressions), from Latin ā̆stūtus "crafty, cunning, tricksy", and was quickly conflated with shortlived semi-learnèd studiar "to study (in the Church)", from post-Classical Latin studiō "I study" (compare earlier synonymous studeō).

examples.vernacular: Jo sucq de ty connardaç!
examples.english: I'm fed up of your bullshit!

et: from Old Borlish sucquar "to sink, sag, slump", from synonymous søcqua in Old Norse. Seen in the last use especially in the phrase jo sucq den "I've had enough" from the sixteenth century. The latter meanings may have been influenced by Dane sʉg "ill, weary, fed up" or a similar cognate.

examples.vernacular: Y mur ne Damvað Veðerrem son pegntað con suicr.
examples.english: The walls of Old Damvath are coated with soot.

et: via Old Borlish sui, suicle "soot" from synonymous sūdia, sūdicula in Insular Latin (compare French suie, Welsh huðygl, both meaning "soot"). In the more general uses the word is attested from the fifteenth century; the botanical senses date in writing to the seventeenth.

examples.vernacular: Jo trovau nien benoçabr entr y supellex dy collocquour.
examples.english: I found nothing useful in the journalist's paraphernalia.

et: 17C borrowing from Latin supellēx "furniture, utensils, kit", likely related to legō "I collect, gather". Extension to behaviours is seen from the late nineteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Y concegl surmettraun jamay ty messarf periglous d'œculux bressem.
examples.english: The committee will never condone your dangerous misuse of ionising radiation.

et: Old Boral surmetre, suvr mettre “to send/throw over”, from Latin super- “over, above” (with sporadic lengthening of the first vowel, cf. French sur) and mittō “I send, release”.

examples.vernacular: Nossy bevey surplom y rif par un porrujon annexað.
examples.english: The balcony in our suite overlooks the beachfront.

et: Middle Borlish coinage from sur- "over" (< Latin super-) and plomb "lead, weight, sound", conjuring the image of a weight suspended above something. In the third and fourth senses, from the inherent danger of the suspended object falling on one (attested from the sixteenth century); in the last sense originally in guild jargon and perhaps then jocular (attested from the early twentieth century).

examples.vernacular: Y Grec identfeyan Suthocq e Typhon.
examples.english: The Greeks conflated Set and Typhon.

et: 18th century, originally in translation from Arabic سُتُخ • Sutuch "Set". This in turn comes from the very new (and still somewhat inaccurate) decipherment of hieroglyphs, leading to a surge in interest in Egyptian mythology, reflecting the name now usually transcribed as /suː.tiç/ (whence Coptic ⲥⲏⲧ /seːt/).
Old Borlish diminutive of sut, siu "tallow" from Latin sēbum "grease", perh influenced by synonymous obsolete tolc from Old Norse tolg "tallow".
via Old Borlish from Old English swamm "fungus, sponge".

examples.vernacular: Nos stou y ðanc sveldr prell'eicon zar.
examples.english: We need to thin out the crowd before the real competition.

et: from Old Borlish isveldre "to pluck, remove parts of", a pleonastic derivative of a presumed *veldre descending directly from Latin vellō "I pluck, depilate, demolish". Extension to woodworking is attested by the thirteenth century, in abstract use it is seen from the fifteenth, and the colloquial sense first arose in the late eighteenth before a revival (or re-coining) in the twentieth.

examples.vernacular: Seyað clar con ig voscon desirað svellar.
examples.english: Be clear in what you want to express.

et: originally in the last senses and later weakened substantially, from Old Borlish isvelar "to unveil, reveal", derivative of velar "to veil, shroud" < Latin vēlō with the prefix is- "out, away, un-" < Latin ex- "out, throughout".
cf. French éventiller "hover in place", from vent "wind" or Latin ēventilō "I expose to air".

examples.vernacular: Toll'aucoum ediculat ern tijon svingant.
examples.english: The whole ediculate set were up in arms.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from some Germanic language, most likely Saxon swingen "to swing, wave, brandish", but Markish and Horther have also been suggested.

lx: sy mensc e y mansc tenir
ge: have one's cake and eat it too
et: The modern phrase literally means "to keep one's manners and one's food", in reference to being a good host while not actually offering anything to eat. It is first attested in a book of proverbs by an anonymous author of the late eighteenth century
from the city of Tabris and the Persian mass the mann

examples.vernacular: Jo montau ag tabr e clignau my bos yert a haut.
examples.english: I got up on the table and fired my gun into the air.

et: Old Borlish, diminutive of tafl < Old Norse

examples.vernacular: Tag enverimmað con mandrin occeyeu ty quanga.
examples.english: Your secretary was poisoned with cyanide-laced tea.

et: 19C, Scholastic Latin taglīnus, originally applied to minerals containing surfeited tagline [F⁻] < Napolitan taglino (1643) "fondant [flux], substance for lowering the melting point of metals" < Arabic تليين • talyīn "softening; fondant".
unknown, possibly Latin taxeus "made of yew".
borrowing from synonymous tan in Old French, ultimately from Gaulish tannos "green oak".

examples.vernacular: Tandem il pardoirn nis e fegrn repaðr.
examples.english: Eventually they gave up and went home.

et: Middle Borlish borrowing from Latin tandem "at last", related to tam "so, so much". Apparently once pronounced with initial stress, but the stress had shifted to the final syllable by the seventeenth century at the latest.

examples.vernacular: Gent tanniscen gles par mejan d'yedic.
examples.english: People used to set dyes using vinegar.

et: Middle Borlish, verbal derviation from the noun tan "oak bark" (from which tannic acid is obtained). Extension to various other procedure for making materials harder or more durable is seen through the early modern period and into the twentieth century.

examples.vernacular: Y reloðeç ag tarner sta aplattiscent.
examples.english: The host's gentility was irritating.

examples.vernacular: Jo sceu noc grap aïr all'outraç tars dell'ig bougr.
examples.english: I couldn't believe the cad's sheer effrontery.

et: past participle of targr "to clean, wipe, scrub", descendant of Latin tergō (variant of tergeō "I wipe, polish"). In the last sense first seen in certain collocations like victoir tars "a runaway victory".
Middle Borlish < Old French < Classical German

examples.vernacular: Apar cogleu nos y tas de v ne V yon v.m=x.
examples.english: Thus we get the set of w in W with m(w)=x.

et: the conflation in early Modern Borlish of two words with unrelated etyma. Partially a borrowing from Dutch tas, tasch "bag, pouch", which descends straightforwardly from Classical German tascon "purse, pocket". Partially via French from Mostara tasa "bowl, vessel", a borrowing from Arabic طَاس • ṭās "cup". In the mathematical sense from 1831, in translation from Dümmeyer's 1827 work Sammel und Sendungen "Sets and Functions".
altered from early Middle Borlish tor to be closer to Latin taurus "bull, steer".

examples.vernacular: Nos orruðe casc y gent ausn taur a ençar destr.
examples.english: It looked like everyone was eager to get going.

et: literally "to have bull", idiom attested (in the slightly different sense of impulsiveness) from the sixteenth century. The last sense is attested sporadically from the late nineteenth century and reached its peak popularity in the mid-twentieth.
transparent diminutive of taur "bull" seen as early as the thirteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Taus gran alcot es y molin rouð faint la?
examples.english: At what rate does the factory make wheels?

et: from Old Borlish taus "tax, price", deverbal of taussar "to impose a tax on" borrowed from Old French and reflecting Latin taxō "I handle, charge, appraise, reckon" (compare modern French taux "level, amount, quantity" with an etymological respelling).
verbal derivative of taus "cost, price, rate"

examples.vernacular: Jo duvau y bosaç con y tegmn d'un hey.
examples.english: I used a fence as cover from the gunfire.

et: originally in the first senses, a direct descendant from Latin tegimen "cover, protection". This noun comes from verb tegō "I cover, conceal", which became Old Borlish ter "span, cover (an amount of land)" and thence modern teir "amount to, number". Extended to safety in more abstract contexts by the early modern period.

examples.vernacular: Cal mocry son il teissent oy?
examples.english: What nonsense are they spouting now?

et: originally in the first senses, from Old Borlish teissir, tistre, teȝsre (among many other forms) "to weave, work with thread". These all derive from either Latin texere "to weave" or a Late Latin texēre exhibiting a change of conjugation. Use in the narrative sense is attested as far back as the Classical period; much of the metaphorical usage is likely extended from this first idiom.
an uncomplicated descendant from Latin tenebrae "darkness"

examples.vernacular: Tenguð lousc jaint penoirn dy ci ranscel.
examples.english: Glittering baubles hung from the branches.

et: 18C Borlish, clipped from Sant Enguð "Saint Angith", a canonised medieval abbess from Sothbar on Borland. In the late medieval period her pilgrimage site was associated with freely-offered figurines and pieces of embroidered fabric.

examples.vernacular: Con tersur psolic poð l'yeustanç de vin lejar.
examples.english: Sulfites can arrest the fermentation of wine.

examples.vernacular: L'oc aer es teun neðan nos respireu.
examples.english: This air's too thin for both of us to breathe.

et: via Old Borlish tiun, tieun "thin" from Latin tenuis "slight, weak". Thus, this word is one of the only pieces of evidence as to the development of post-stress /-w-/ (following a non-velar consonant) from Latin into Borlish. The semantic shift to senses relating to insufficiency is evidenced from the early Middle Borlish period.

examples.vernacular: Folastr ne vrugheç a mell'accostur teurfiað.
examples.english: A moorland frolic has got my clothes dirty.

et: Middle Borlish derivation from noun teur "tar" with the suffix -feyar (< Latin -ficō) which forms verbs meaning "to make/render _". The noun teur is an Old Borlish borrowing from Old English teoru "tar, resin, earwax", which is related to "tree". Almost immediately we see use of the verb, particularly in contemporary legal cases.
Middle Borlish < Medieval Latin < Ancient Greek
Middle Borlish < Medieval Latin < Ancient Greek
Middle Borlish < Medieval Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Rumorar no's y theu de mey.
examples.english: I don't usually spread gossip.

et: direct descendant of Old Borlish theu, thau "wont; behaviour", borrowed from synonymous þēaw in Old English. In the last senses the word usually has positive affect, unlike otherwise comparable words like obstinaç "obstinacy". Puns on this word with the name Theo are attested from the eighteenth century, possibly as soon as the words became homophonous in many Borlish dialects.

examples.vernacular: Me stove y vajot eð y time grindr.
examples.english: I had to weigh the pros and cons.

et: derived from earlier adjective time "doubtful; shy, timid", a borrowing from Scholastic Latin timeus "frightened, cowrdly". This comes from the root verb timeō "I fear, I am afraid". The word is seen as a noun from the seventeenth century, and as a disadvantageous quality of something (as opposed to something felt by a person) since the mid-nineteenth century.
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin tunna < Celtic

examples.vernacular: Hour alcot es tu y toriot hoissant?
examples.english: How long have you been playing the torriot?

et: Middle Borlish < Old French tornei < torneier "turn around"
early modern borrowing from Latin turpiloquus "speaking in an unseemly way, fromturpis* "ugly" and loquor "I say".
Middle Borlish < Italian < Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Nos eu l'oc annað dou tort dell'ivan apportað; stoven torrir ag casc aldr!
examples.english: We've brought two Christmas pies this year - both my parents wanted to bake!

et: Old Boral torte del ifan “child's pie” (first attested 10C), from Latin torta panis “twisted bread” and īnfāns, īnfāntem “child, infant”.

examples.vernacular: Veleð aular a to-rutto lonc y forcul.
examples.english: Cross the mountain pass in single file.

et: attested in various forms since the late Middle Borlish period, an ideophonic idiom used to refer to single-file sorts of arrangement or motion. The phrase is hypothesised to originate in farmers' livestock-counting numerals, which may be reflected by the modern appearance of to-rutto in counting-style nursery rhymes. These rural tally-like systems (e.g. an, to, ry, bo, bum, ...), which are present across Borland, derive from Germanic or Celtic numbers.

examples.vernacular: Jo tossottau eð y camis me moglau con saf.
examples.english: I spluttered and got juice on my shirt.

et: verbal derivative of tossot "splutter", from tossir "to cough". This descends from Latin tussiō "I cough". Attested in the more metaphorical sense since the nineteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Jo fo sveilað je aubon posc par y tourf.
examples.english: I was woken in the morning by the riot.

et: early modern borrowing from Welsh twrf "disturbance; crowd, mob", itself originally a borrowing from Latin turba "disorder; throng". The word gained currency during the Democratic Wars of the mid-eighteenth century, form which it obtained its political undertones.

examples.vernacular: Storra un tourm ottem all'oc kevlar.
examples.english: This heist will need a better crew.

et: Middle Borlish, via the conflation of contemporary French tourme "troop" and Dutch torem "tower, fort". The former is a borrowing from an Italian descendant of Latin turma "troop, team", while the latter is probably a borrowing from a Romance decendant of Latin turris "tower". As a collective noun it is attested from the sixteenth century for ants and somewhat later for some other animals.
Old Borlish toaȝl "towel, washcloth" < Latin < Frankish
Middle Borlish < Old French < Old Vascon
Old Borlish < Old French < Old Dutch

examples.vernacular: Casc phasmet tienn ne traiscn coll'oc emblemat.
examples.english: Every video keeps buffering at this resolution.

et: a deverbal from traiscnar "trail, drag behind, lag", which reflects a Vulgar Latin verb traxinō "I drag, pull, tug" which extends the verb trahō in Classical Latin.

originally horological jargon used by clockmakers, attested from the seventeenth century, literally "in lag". The word has been extended from clocks to public transportation and then to computing in the modern era.

examples.vernacular: Jo passau y trasson nell'exedr a quarvol.
examples.english: I spent the layover in the airport lounge.

et: formerly trasçon, either a Middle Borlish noun derivation from trasir "to cross, traverse", or a direct borrowing from Latin trānsitiō "transit, transition". In the last sense the word is attested from the seventeenth century, originally applied to parts of musical compositions.

examples.vernacular: Il son y trave costroint toð y jorn.
examples.english: They've been doing the jigsaw all day.

et: from a specialised use of Middle French travé "crossed with wooden beams", via noun traf, tref "beam, mast" from Latin trabs "timber, beam, rafter". The puzzle sense is attested from the late nineteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Nos som travodant posc je semman ados!
examples.english: We've been in negotations since last week!

et: Backformation from Middle Borlish travodað "negotiation, discussion, barter (n.)" as if a past participle. In fact the noun comes from Welsh travodaeth "discussion, commerce", from travoda "I handle, discuss, deal with".
Old Borlish; from Old Borlish tre lamne < Latin tres laminæ "three blades" (the meaning of the noun shifting to "edge" by the Old Borlish period).

examples.vernacular: Caye trencaç yon jo venoy primer n'Ausbagn.
examples.english: It was freezing when I first came to Axbane.

et: adjectival derivation from trencar "cut, slice", of uncertain origin. Perhaps from Vulgar Latin *trinicō "I cut in three"; otherwise likely an alteration of Latin truncō "I maim, dismember" under Kelt influence.
Middle Borlish; univerbation of trenc sachet "slices pockets".
Middle Borlish < Old French < Vulgar Latin < Ancient Greek

1930s, phrase meaning "three <W>s", after the line <WWW> prepending any such alert (since the sequence was unlikely to appear in Borlish text for any other reason). More often than not written as one word since its genericisation in the 1960s.
portmanteau of trevold 'novel' and vogt 'outer space'

examples.vernacular: Jo te pieð, dig en mey rien – jo n'ay deja y cart trevold leit dell'oc cougl.
examples.english: Please don't tell me anything – I've not yet read the fourth book in the series.

et: circa 1640, from Dench bog trevold “octavo book” (that is, a book printed on sheets in octavo size). Literally “three-fold”, named as octavo parchment is produced by folding folios three times.
Old Borlish < Old French < Italian < Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Ða meðes nos poðau lou fornir d'aïðanç, il trocausn noc entrig tardessem.
examples.english: Even if we provided them with aid, they would not reciprocate later.

et: “to trade between”. Preposition from Latin inter “between, among”; verb possibly from an Old Boral trocar “to trade”, either an alternation of torcar < Latin torqueō “I twist, bend”, or more likely from Old Spanish trocar via Old French, of uncertain origin.
Old French < Medieval Latin < Classical German

examples.vernacular: Un truc par ados me fey gringlar a cainç.
examples.english: A shove from behind knocked me over.

et: Old Borlish deverbal from truccar "shove, jostle" (now archaic, superseded by truc fair), which reflects a Vulgar Latin extension trūdicō of Classical trūdō "I shove, thrust". In the latter senses it is attested from the nineteenth century.
from Old Borlish tuȝ "inclination, impulse, drive". This was borrowed from Old English tyge "a pull, a draw", which is related to the verb tēon "pull, drag, lead".
Middle Borlish < Middle French < Old French < Classical German
Middle Borlish < Medieval Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Lorry caum s'ubicqfein lon hiat.
examples.english: Their posts are always trending.

et: twentieth century, a derivation from adjective ubicq "ubiquitous, omnipresent" < Latin ubīque "everywhere" with the causative suffix -feyar < Latin -ficō "I make _". This was originally a somewhat derogatory term for annoying advertisement. The word has not entirely shaken off this connotation, partially due to its shared root with the totalising ideology of Ubiquity to which many of Borland's geopolitical rivals subscribed during this period.

late medieval borrowing from non-classical Latin ubīquitās "ubiquity", nominal derivation of ubīque "everywhere". Applied in philosophical contexts throughout the Latinate Vetomund from the sixteenth century, and used in particular for Ubiquity (originally as an insult) in 1848, in the translation of lady explorer Poshack Nerwaman's dismissive critique of political developments in Mashick.

ge: for someone to get used to (something)
as far as something is concerned

et: early modern Borlish, a backformation from earlier uscer "doorman, porter". The word was first used for changing the orientation of inanimate objects in the 19th century, and in the computing sense in theoretical work during the 1910s.
a borrowinng of Kentish usher "doorman", via synonymous ussier in Old French and ultimately ōstiārius in Latin. This etymon is an agentive formation from ōstium "door".

examples.vernacular: Luy sceye un min a vabiantað bogr mesveibr.
examples.english: He wore an unmistakable look of misery.

et: Middle Borlish-era nominalisation of now-archaic vabian "woeful, disconsolate", coming via synonymous Old Borlish vabȝan from Old English from Old English wābegān, literally "beset by woe". In the last senses it is attested generally from the fourteenth century until the eighteenth, and in specialised use thereafter.

alteration in Middle Borlish of former vacker (possibly influenced as a spelling pronunciation from other Romance languages? Consider Vascon vaquèr), from Vulgar Latin vaccārius, agentive derivation of vacca "cow"
Old Borlish < Old English wæġn "wagon, carriage"

examples.vernacular: Y masctig trovar sta un vajot imprefait.
examples.english: Finding the ticket was an unexpected bonus.

et: originally in the last senses, from a diminutive of Old Borlish uai "legal contract; salary, wage", from synonymous wadium in Medieval Latin (compare gage in Old French). This comes from Frankish wadi "stake, pledge", which is related to English "wedding". The word was displaced in its original sense by parsou "wage, rate; worth, value".

examples.vernacular: Tu atten cal compleis a vencr ny valcq sevent?
examples.english: Tu atten cal compleis a vencr ny valcq sevent?

et: eighteenth century, allied with Norman valque, Kentish or Willem walk, Saxon walke, and many others all meaning "bout; (racket sports) set". Use for less unpleasant periods of time is a Borlish innovation dating to the early twentieth century, originally with sarcastic force. The ultimate origin is almost certainly Boham [Czech] wálca "war", but influence from Kentish verb walken "to move, travel; to occur, take place" is not unlikely.

examples.vernacular: Se poð jo nolois cavir validað ag reu.
examples.english: I might lack the prereqs for the course.

et: from Middle Borlish validar, a borrowing from Scholastic Latin validō "I render (something) worthy or valid". This is a non-Classical derivative from adjective validus "strong, healthy, worthy, valid" originally used in legal settings.
Middle Borlish < Latin; not certain but usually taken to be a dialect descendant of Latin vernāculus "native, domestic, vernacular".

examples.vernacular: L'oç capparol verdey de broðoquin vanaglous.
examples.english: That chapter is full of jargony gibberish.

et: nineteenth century, adjectival derivation from vanagl "cant, jargon, slang".
Middle Borlish, borrowed from Willem Dutch verb vangen "to catch", a descendant (modelled after the preterite forms) from Classical German fanhō "I take, seize".

examples.vernacular: Vancheu toð vençabr dell'oc vessondry.
examples.english: Loot this clothes shop of anything we can sell.

et: early Modern Borlish, verbal derivation from vanc "catch, haul; loot, plunder". In the last sense the word is attested from the early twentieth century.
Middle Borlish < Norman < Old French < Frankish, Vulgar Latin
Old Borlish; verbal derivation from varm < Latin vermis "worm".
Old Borlish < Old English; borrowed from Old English wearriht with very little change in meaning.
Old Borlish < Old French < Classical German
from Late Latin vitellus/a "calf", a pleonastic diminutive of vitulus, of the same meaning.

examples.vernacular: I tenoy sy veðrdon n'oc ort e soureyeu.
examples.english: She held up her trophy and grinned.

et: the descendant of Old Borlish veðerdon "payment, reward", which comes from synonymous widerdōnum in Medieval Latin. This is a borrowing from Germanic (cf. Old English wiþerlēan "recompense", literally "counter-reward"), which the second part calqued as Latin dōnum "gift". Compare the Old French cognate guerredon "payment; spoils, booty, loot", whose first element was also adjusted to guerre "war". Conflation with unrelated Borlish veðr < Latin vitrum "glass" may have influenced the traditional concept of a trophy as made of glass or crystal.

examples.vernacular: Y torvegl indugs ec mesuranç suprem de veðrvent tras istr.
examples.english: The storm led to record windspeed measurements nationwide.

et: folk-etymological alteration of Old Borlish veðrevit "vane" under the influence of vent "wind" < synonymous ventus in Latin. The Old Borlish is a borrowing from Old Norse veðrviti "vane", literally "weather knower". Synchronically interpretable as "wind-glass"; though they are not normally made of glass, the word has been analysed as referring to glassware used for measurement. In metaphorical usage the word is seen from the eighteenth century.
from Old Borlish veȝre "straw; fodder", from a Borland Kelt form cognate to Welsh gυeir "hay". Perhaps influenced by Latin verb vegeō "I am active; I quicken".

examples.vernacular: Jo vis y fabr all'Auspeç Impareïbr noncupað.
examples.english: I saw the self-styled Peerless Seer's stage show.

examples.vernacular: Nos se ponau voud a sy vellisqment dehiscn.
examples.english: We looked forward to his plans falling apart.

examples.vernacular: Caye trencaç yon jo venoy primer n'Ausbagn.
examples.english: It was freezing when I first came to Axbane.

examples.vernacular: Cou je meis Juglot an smout de forest verdeyant.
examples.english: July came with a profusion of lush forest.

et: present participle of verdeyar "become green; flourish; abound"
verbal derivative of vert "green" (or directly from Vulgar Latin virdidiō "I turn green"). Metaphorical extensions parallel those in neighbouring Romance and Germanic languages.

examples.vernacular: Tu scencau y soup n'un bacin veronic.
examples.english: You poured the soup into a plastic tub.

et: 19C, former trademark also written as lacq Veronic "Veronic shellac". The word was borrowed from Medieval Latin veronīx "resin, varnish", perhaps from Byzantine Greek Βερενῑ́κη (Bereníkē), a city of Cyrenaica. In metaphorical use the word is seen from as early as the 1920s.
Norman < Kentish < Old English, Old French; phonetic respelling of Norman or Kentish waiscot, reduced from a compound of waist and coat (i.e. a coat reaching to the waist).
Toledan vierven, Late Latin verminem from Latin vermis "worm"
from now-obsolete vigl "cart, wagon". This descends via Old Borlish veiȝl from Latin vehiculum "means of transport". In metaphorical use attested from the sixteenth century.

examples.vernacular: J'oyeu y domn issar set viglour.
examples.english: I heard she has seven chauffeurs.

et: agentive formation from viglar "to drive (a vehicle); to set in motion", from now-obsolete vigl "cart, wagon". This descends via Old Borlish veiȝl from Latin vehiculum "means of transport". In metaphorical use attested from the sixteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Con tersur psolic poð l'yeustanç de vin lejar.
examples.english: Sulphites can arrest the fermentation of wine.

et: from Mediæval Tuscane viola, probably from Old Vascon viula, from Late Latin vitula (all with the same meaning).

examples.vernacular: Vos orreð viol cemtir moutessem, com dit, all'hour pre y lugnt.
examples.english: They say you will most often hear the graveyard fiddles the hour before dawn.

examples.vernacular: Il ern zaquesc visnous a tatover pascent.
examples.english: They were eating knobbly potato snacks.

et: Middle Borlish, adjectival derivation from now-obsolete verb visnar "to wither". This descends from an Old Borlish borrowing from Old English wisnian "dry up, shrivel". The arboreal senses (literally or figuratively) are now the most current, with a noun visn "knot in wood" having been backformed from the adjective.

examples.vernacular: Nos eu vitagl aðief por un meis dijarr.
examples.english: We have enough supplies for a month.

et: from Old Borlish vitaȝl "provisions", a borrowing from synonymous Old French vitaile, itself descended from Latin vīctuālia "nutritional things". This is a derivative of vīctus "living, diet", from vīvō "I live".

examples.vernacular: Y lamp se quïsceu, y coloir augtant ne vogt dy foscur.
examples.english: The light went out, plunging the hall into darkness.

et: idiom first attested in the poetry of 15C writer Drominir, literally "emptiness of darkness". The noun vogt descends from Vulgar Latin *vocitus "empty", a variant of the synonymous vacuus in Classical Latin. The noun foscur is a noun derivative of adjective fosc "dark" which descends from Latin fuscus "dimly lit, black".
Old Borlish, deverbal from volar "fly, steal", from Latin volō "I fly".
Old Borlish < Old French < Classical German

collocation meaning "anticlockwise spin". The noun voltisc "spin, rotation" is the deverbal of voltir "to spin, rotate; to linger", from Vulgar Latin voltus "rolled, tumbled". The adjective guyer is borrowed from Old French adverb guier "in the opposite direction, anticlockwise" from Frankish wither "back, against, again".

examples.vernacular: Casc ouvr pent ag ci mur stan vondrous.
examples.english: All the wall-hung paintings were hideous.

et: from Old Borlish vondrous "miraculous, awe-inspiring, unbelievable", adjective derivate of vondre "miracle, marvel" (now obsolete). This is borrowed from the synonymous wundor in Old English. The worsening semantic shift was entirely complete by the seventeenth century.

examples.vernacular: Scey zygom ag vrogs ny doit.
examples.english: There's a valve in the thin part of the pipe.

et: from Old Borlish vroȝse, vorȝse, voȝrse "waist; belt, girdle", showing extensive metathetic variation. This is thought to be borrowed from a Borland Kelt form vocris "belt" related to Classical Kelt crissus "shirt".
a backformation from noun vrollisc "entertainment, fun".
borrowed in the early modern period from a Willem or Saxon Dutch adjective like vrolic, frolich "merry, cheerful".

examples.vernacular: Y vrolliscour er pildr entisour cirteyant.
examples.english: The influencer was hawking boner pills.

et: nineteenth century, agentive derivation from verb vrollir "please, entertain". In the modern period, when referring to a person, the word often denotes someone who has an online audience.

examples.vernacular: Nos miraum y horam d'un vrugheç lað.
examples.english: We looked at the wide shot of broad moorland.

et: descendant of Old Borlish vruȝeç "heath, moor", which is a nominal derivation of vruȝ "heather" (modern vrug) with the suffix -eç < Latin -itia. The word vruȝ is borrowed from Borland Kelt vrūg "heather", cognate with synonymous frágh in Irish.

examples.vernacular: Un Honour de Hatfell gajannar gal vry moulous.
examples.english: Winning a Hatfell Honour carries great cachet.

et: nineteenth-century borrowing from a lenited form of Welsh bri "prestige, honour". This descends from pre-Classical Kelt brīgos "importance, weight", though to be cognate with Latin gravis "heavy". Originally a somewhat déclassé slang term, the word had passed into the ordinary register by the mid-twentieth century. A brief period of use as a approbatory interjection was over outside ironic mimicry by the 1980s.

examples.vernacular: Ja sco ne vugl router.
examples.english: I'm still in a traffic jam.

et: a Middle Borlish deverbal from vuglar
An alteration of earlier vugrar, borrowed in the Old Borlish period from Old English wyrġan "to strangle, worry".
Middle Borlish < Scholastic Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Sy xivol aye tug aglon de skisteç.
examples.english: He waltzed with more passion than grace.

et: via French xivole from Vascon xìvola /ˈʃi.vo.la/ "waltz". This itself is a borrowing from the earlier and slightly different Italian dance scivola "waltz, word stressed on the third-from-last syllable", from verb scivolare "glide, slip". This is plausibly a descendant of Latin exsībilō "I hiss forth".
twentieth-century coinage extracted from the earlier idiom par lamn a xyron "clutch, just in time, in an extremely fortunate way"

examples.vernacular: Sell'osceyan vil y cæros nos ovrir de lembic gostar.
examples.english: Her birthday will give us the chance to try alcohol.

et: idiom from the nineteenth century, literally "to open the opportune moment of".

examples.vernacular: Y joun a y sona fort hurstað cos nuverrem.
examples.english: The kid's really come into her own lately.

et: idiom from the nineteenth century, literally "to equip the role".

examples.vernacular: Tu te hoccovau y voç e cou ouç.
examples.english: You went "ahem" and silence fell.

et: idiom attested from the eighteenth century, literally "to cough the voice".

examples.vernacular: Ubicqtað ablegau mell'yam deur Ommad.
examples.english: Ubiquity drove my uncle from Ommad.

examples.vernacular: L'er mell'yam sleghant avant my rau!
examples.english: He was shamelessly slandering my uncle!

examples.vernacular: I s'yauvnau y cavel sborreyað cos van.
examples.english: He failed to pat down his messy hair.

et: originally in the latter senses, descendant of Old Borlish iawnar "to smooth, even, flatten". This is a borrowing from Old Norrish [Norse] jafna "to make even", a verbal derivative of jafn "even; equal, same". Specialisation to the act of tapping the flat of one's hand against something is seen from the fifteenth century.

examples.vernacular: Tanniscað casc ugnlac sou yedic.
examples.english: Pickle all the onions in vinegar.

et: descendant of Old Borlish iedic, edic "vinegar", borrowed from synonymous edic in Old Dutch. This is apparently a metathetic variant coming from late Classical German aceda, acita "vinegar", a borrowing from Latin acētum "vinegar" possibly influenced by related acidus "sour". The Borlish word is attested as an adjective in the modern sense from as early as the twelfth century.

examples.vernacular: My patron me lançau un scoul yemal.
examples.english: My boss glared at me without warmth.

et: Middle Borlish (h)iemal "wintry", borrowed from Latin hiemālis "pertaining to winter", from hiems "winter". The term lost its initial h- (unlike most contemporaneous Latin borrowings) due to contamination from native yarn "winter" < Latin hībernum "winter". Emotional extension of the term is seen shortly thereafter, in parallel to stival "summery, friendly".
literally "to get known", with verb yembr "to obtain, arrive" < Latin emō "I buy, acquire" and adjective scið "known, possible" < Latin scītum "learnt, approved".

via Middle Borlish yerað "farewell, goodbye" from Old Borlish vos ierað "may you fare well, be strong, abide, endure, persevere". This is a form of iereir "abide, persist, persevere", which reflects Latin haereō "I cling, adhere, remain fixed".

examples.vernacular: Jo montau ag tabr e clignau my bos yert a haut.
examples.english: I got up on the table and fired my gun into the air.

et: Old Borlish ieol "unpaved road" (as opposed to vei "paved road"), which given Welsh heol "route, passage" is presumably of Borland Kelt origin.

examples.vernacular: Y davarn façada y jogntur de dou yeul ovart.
examples.english: The hotel was at the intersection of two main roads.

et: Etymology: collocation first seen in the sixteenth century, literally meaning "open street". In the latter sense attested from 1977.

examples.vernacular: Con tersur psolic poð l'yeustanç de vin lejar.
examples.english: Sulphites can arrest the fermentation of wine.

examples.vernacular: Surcay l'ig marið de lorry dottr laur un yeustman.
examples.english: It turns out their daughter's married to a brewer.

et: from Old Borlish ȝeost manc/ç "beer seller", from the stem of ȝeostar "to ferment, brew" (modern yeustar), a borrowing from synonymous geostan in Borland English (cf. modern Markish yeast), and the element manc/ç "seller, vendor", either reflecting Insular Latin mantia "shop, household, inn" or Latin mangō "dealer, seller (of slaves)". In metaphorical use from the seventeenth century.
Middle Borlish, from obsolete yevar 'to measure'
Old Borlish, an extension of yon "where" < Latin ubicumque "wherever" by analogy to words like calscon "whichever" < Latin quāliscumque "of whatever quality".
Middle Borlish < Old French < Italian < Medieval Latin < Arabic < Aramaic < Latin

examples.vernacular: "Cay zar!" dis jo cant corrau nos.
examples.english: "It's not a game!" I said as we ran.

et: from sixteenth-century zar "risky, high-stakes", transferred from the name of a gambling dice game. This comes via Napolitan zara from Arabic زَهْر (zahr) "dice". Doublet of hasart "peril, danger", which comes via French. Used exclusively of games and competitions until the nineteenth century, when the idiom with cair is first attested.
Old Borlish < Medieval Latin < Ancient Greek
Old Borlish < Medieval Latin < Ancient Greek

examples.vernacular: Zi, sco'n bal n'oc ort.
examples.english: Yeah, things're looking up.

et: Contraction of standard es i [ɪˈzi] "is it", part of a series of similar contractions of the copula with pronouns, like sco "am I", sti "are you (sg)" which despite their verb-subject inversion are also nonstandardly used in declarative clauses (sti'n connart "You're a dick").
Old Borlish < Vulgar Latin < Latin < Greek ζίζυφον

examples.vernacular: Nos oyau zizania dereðr dy mur dy rajognoir.
examples.english: We heard arguing through the boardroom's wall.

et: seventeenth-century borrowing from Lombard zizania "ryegrass, weed; discord, vice", which displays a metaphorical extension dating back to its ancestor in Late Latin zizanium "cockle, ryegrass, darnel; vice", a borrowing from Greek. Its modern association with cacophonous noise is probably due to sound symbolism.
unknown, possibly from "es X" for some X; possibly just imitative.

clipping of earlier carrot zovay "taxi carriage", often mistakenly capitalised to carrot Zovay by analogy with other types of carriage named after places. The word was borrowed via French from Frule slang term zovaie "coach for hire with a taximeter", literally "convenience" (one did not have to pay up front, unlike earlier hired coaches). This is a derivative of verb zovà "be useful, be convenient", from Latin iuvō "I help; I please".

examples.vernacular: Nos coum zovay eð alandaum tost.
examples.english: We took a taxi and arrived early.

ge: follow the path of least resistance
et: late ninetenth century, literally "to get (a) taxi". In the metaphorical sense the phrase is seen only from the 1970s.

examples.vernacular: Sceyen zurç remiaçant precartaðer ag platabac.
examples.english: There was jelly wobbling dangerously on the buffet table.

et: early eighteenth century borrowing from French zurce "jelly, aspic", itself from sürze in Bavarn. This derives from a Classical German root sultiō "brine", related to English "salt". The word displaces now-obsolete veros "aspic" (apparently from veðr os "bone glass") in line with the substance's increasing use in sweet dishes.
